subdebateinfo.title: Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the 104th Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference, Jakarta and Bilateral Visit to Vietnam

talk.start.para: âI present the report of the Australian Delegation to the 104th Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference held in Jakarta from 15 to 21 October 2000, and the bilateral visit to Vietnam from 22 to 27 October 2000. I want to make a few brief comments and then allow others in the delegation to provide more detail.

speech.para: The Australian delegation played a major role at the IPU conference and was instrumental in formulating two of the resolutions adopted by the conference. The IPU is going through a critical period. If it is to remain relevant as a legitimate forum for international parliamentary debates, in my view and that of many others it must undertake a series of reforms to ensure that it operates within its budget and that the conference format makes for more effective use of time and limited resources. The Australian IPU group will do what it can to ensure that this occurs and that the IPU continues to be a respected and effective international institution.

The bilateral visit to Vietnam was particularly successful. The official program included meetings with the prime minister, the foreign minister, the planning minister and the chairman of the national assembly, as well as the chairmen from several other provincial councils and committees. The delegation also met with a number of Australian business people operating in Vietnam. These meetings enabled the delegation to discuss a range of issues, including the strength of the bilateral relationship; the progress of economic reform in Vietnam, in particular opening up the economy and increasing the level of foreign investment; the aftermath of the floods in the central and southern regions; the role played by Australian aid in various developmental projects, including the successfully completed My Thuan bridge; and the role played by both countries in the Asia-Pacific region.

The discussions were frank and informative and left the delegation with a very clear impression that Vietnam is making steady, if measured, progress towards the reform of its economy and access to its markets. Of particular interest to the delegation was the opportunity to see at first-hand the impact of Australian investment and the benefits to the social economy of Australian aid expenditure. Overall, it was a very informative and rewarding visit. The relationship between both countries is strong, and the delegation came away with a very positive impression about future relations between Vietnam and Australia. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: âI, too, in following those remarks, would like to comment very briefly on the IPU conference. I take on board, as do the other delegates, the changes that are occurring and will occur, not only to the structure of the IPU but also to its charter. One of the things I would like to mention in the House is that we have already commenced that process through the meeting of women parliamentarians. When we meet at the next IPU conference we will be adopting a different format. One interesting part that is very dear to my heart is that, following the executive council meetingâand it is noted on page 21 of the reportâthe council took note of a report by Mrs Murti from Indonesia, who chaired the proceedings of the women's meeting, when she called on all national parliaments to ratify the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women. I again appeal to the government to take that on board, bearing in mind that many national parliaments around the world have now taken that step.

speech.para: Without covering the IPU in detail, I would like particularly to turn to Vietnam. Mr Speaker, I congratulate you on your leadership there. It was a very trying time: we seemed to be perpetually and continually on the move. I found it very interesting to see what has happened with Australia's aid in Vietnam. We do realise and acknowledge that, over a period of four years, until 2002, some $236 million in aid has been pledged to Vietnam. On top of that, there is $11 million per year from Australian funding for regional programs, NGOs and emergency assistance. I can assure the parliament, as I and the other delegates have seen at first-hand, that they are certainly spending the money very wisely and well. I was particularly impressed in Hanoi where we visited a university where a special project is being undertaken by the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research. Scientists are researching various diseases with bananas, cucumbers, papaya, et cetera, and are working hand in hand with the university people there. I think it is an excellent project.

The other project I was particularly impressed withâand I know you mentioned the bridge project, Mr Speaker, at My Thuanâwas when we went into the rural areas to see the work being done by some of our Australian aid workers. On that early morning flight we visited Tra My, one of the four mountainous districts in Quang Nam province. We were able to witness at first-hand what the RIDEF project is doing there to alleviate rural poverty through investment in small scale, social and economic infrastructure in relatively poor and underequipped rural areas and provinces. I think the parliament can be very proud of how our money is being spent and of how well it is being spent. We are making a difference there. I think all of Vietnam is now acknowledging Australia as very much a major player in assistance to them. In particular, I think through the IPU conference, with our delegates being on the ground there, we were able to assist and help the Indonesian and Australian relationship. I thank all the staff who were there with us.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Ireland and China

talk.start.para: âI present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Ireland and China entitled An Australian parliamentary perspective. I led the delegation in Ireland, and the President of the Senate led the delegation in China. Australia has strong historical links to Ireland. Members will be aware that the Irish economy is boomingâa remarkable success story from which there are many important lessons to be learned. People are now returning to Ireland instead of leaving it, to share in and to contribute to its growing prosperity. There is also renewed optimism about the prospects for peace in Northern Ireland.

speech.para: Not surprisingly, the delegation found in Ireland a real depth of friendship towards Australia and Australians. In the report, the delegation highlights the need to renew our commitment to that friendship and to ensure that the strong historical and cultural ties translate into broader economic links between our two countries. On behalf of the delegation, I wish to thank the Irish parliament and all who contributed to the success of our visit. The delegation is sure that those who have primary responsibility for managing Australia's relations with Ireland will find the observations in the report useful in strengthening those relations for the mutual benefit of both countries. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: âIt gives me great pleasure to speak today on the tabling of the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to Ireland and China. The delegation visited Ireland from 7 to 13 July, and China from 14 to 20 July. I had the privilege of being the deputy leader of this delegation. Ireland offered us the opportunity to visit a country experiencing very high levels of economic growth and success. Where Ireland in the past experienced net emigration, it now enjoys net immigration. With the economic turnaround, many Irish compatriots are finding it possible to return home, with a part to play in the ongoing growth and prosperity in Ireland.

speech.para: Ireland is also a place of great attraction to many young Australians, who are travelling there, finding work there and enjoying wonderful opportunities. Our discussions, as a delegation, with members of government as well as officials outlined very clearly for us many of the strategies adopted which have contributed to the economic turnaround. These include a social partnership involving trade unions, employers, business associations and farmer associations. This partnership has now been extended to include community organisations. There was great emphasis placed on education, particularly technological and vocational education. The more highly educated work force is now an attraction to multinational companies. There was also the establishment of the Industrial Development Agency Ireland, IDA Ireland, an autonomous agency principally funded by the government.

This has all led to an Ireland held up as a success story to the rest of the world. Ireland now produces 33 per cent of personal computers sold in Europe, has become the European market leader in software, and so on. With the rapid rate of growth also come many new challenges for the Irish. They must find ways to keep up with infrastructure needs, housing demands and other similar stresses. There are some opportunities here for Australia to assist, and I hope that this is possible. The people of Ireland are a warm and welcoming people who go out of their way to offer hospitality and friendship. I would like to thank most sincerely the Irish Prime Minister, the Speaker, the Senate President and the members, senators and officials for their wonderful reception of us, and assistance to us, during this valuable and useful visit.

The week spent in China was also very valuable, and the delegation was received extremely generously by the government and officials of the People's Republic of China. The delegation met with senior representatives of the Chinese government and the National People's Congress. The Chairman of the National People's Congress, Mr Li Peng, generously spent considerable time with us, as did other senior officials. Whilst we were in Beijing, time was made available to enjoy well-briefed visits to sites of national importance. The delegation also met with regional and community representatives, and I believe we found the time spent in the regions to be of particular value. The delegation visited the regional cities of Xi'an and Guilin, where we had the opportunity to learn more about development at the regional level. This is an important aspect when understanding the development and future of China, given its obvious geographic size and diversity.

In Xi'an, we met with representatives of the standing committee of the Shaanxi Provincial People's Congress. This region regards itself as a gateway between the eastern and western regions of China and, as such, the national government's western development strategy is recognised as a priority. In Guilin, a very strong focus on tourism is evident as a part of the region's economic development and future. China is experiencing economic growth, and, of course, with this come many challenges. Environmental considerations now register more highly with more of the population than before, and I believe there are and will continue to be opportunities for Australia in this area as well as many others.

Whilst thanking those we met in both Ireland and China, I must also place on record my thanks to His Excellency the Ambassador of the Republic of Ireland, Mr Richard O'Brien, and His Excellency Mr Zhou Wenzhong, the Ambassador of the People's Republic of China, and their respective representatives, for their briefings, hospitality and assistance prior to our departure. Also, I thank the staff of the Parliamentary Relations Office, the Parliamentary Library, the officers from Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the staff accompanying the Speaker and the President and Mr Andres Lomp, the delegation secretary. In closing, this has been a valuable experience for me as a member of parliament.

talk.start.para: âI too rise to speak on the Australian parliamentary delegation bilateral visit to Ireland and China, and I endorse the comments of my colleague the member for Canberra. Mr Speaker, I would personally like to thank you for the way in which you led the delegation. The delegation was led with a great deal of dignity and to maximise the benefits to all members of the delegation. I would like to thank Andres Lomp for the work that he did in ensuring that the secretarial work flowed smoothly. I will not repeat the names of all the people who have already been thanked, because time is short.

speech.para: This was my first visit to Ireland, and what a delight it was. The predominant features of Ireland seem to me to be the energy, the enthusiasm and the friendliness of the Irish people. Ireland has progressed rapidly from a country that has seen many young people seek their fortunes abroad to one where people are returning to share in the new opportunities of prosperity and cultural achievements. Ireland has always been strong culturally, but the country has excelled in introducing its culture to the world, from dance to literature and drama and, of course, the pub cultureâthere really is one on every corner.

I was impressed with the way Ireland's leadership prepared the people for economic and cultural opportunities, due in part to its entry into the European Union. In discussion with representatives from the Department of Finance and the Industrial Development Agency, our delegation became aware that the prosperity now enjoyed by citizens of Ireland did not happen by chance; it was planned for and it was worked towards. The achievement speaks for itself. As a direct result of my visit, I have suggested a reference for the Trade Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade that includes the investigation of how Ireland planned for prosperity in the hope that we might be able to examine what they did and learn from that experience. In fact, one of the difficulties of the rapid and sustained growth of the economy has been a housing crisis. When I returned, I met with the Irish Ambassador, Richard O'Brien, to discuss how we might be able to contribute. We have builders, architects and town-planners who could make a great contribution to quickly resolving some of the problems in Ireland's housing crisis.

It was also a great privilege during this period to revisit China, particularly after last year's 50th anniversary of the establishment of the People's Republic of China. The effort put into Beijing and other cities in China was very noticeable. They had done some marvellous things there, and I think they are to be congratulated on the way they conducted their 50th anniversary celebrations. We were pleased to be able to visit a small village where we could see Australian aid in action, making sure that people in this tiny village, who formerly had to carry water from a long distance, have water on tap. We saw what a difference it made to their lives. We congratulate all of those people in AusAID and other agencies who have participated in providing water to this village. We were also lucky enough to meet with villagers and to see China begin to allow democracy to work at village level. There are so many things I would like to say about China, but time does not permit. I thank the Irish Ambassador, Richard O'Brien, and the Chinese Ambassador, Zhou Wenzhong, for helping us to make this visit and making it such a success.

talk.start.para: âI too rise in support of the tabling of the report on the delegation to Ireland and China entitled Ireland and China: an Australian parliamentary perspective. I also want to place on the record my thanks to you, Mr Speaker, for your outstanding leadership of the delegation to Ireland and also to Madam President, Senator Reid, for her leadership of the delegation to China. Without naming all of the individuals involved, I also want to place on the record my thanks to all those who organised the preparation before we left Australia and to all those in the Australian offices, the Irish offices and the Chinese offices for the absolutely fantastic effort that was put into the briefings while we were away on the delegation. They were first rate. They gave us enormous detail, and we were very well prepared before we went into all of our meetings. I would also like to place on the record my thanks to Andres Lomp from the Parliamentary Liaison Office, who did an absolutely superb job.

speech.para: This delegation was my first parliamentary delegation, and I can say it sets a very high standard. I would like to place on the record my appreciation of being taken into a regional area of Ireland. I understand that many delegations by their very nature will go to capital cities, but we were taken down to the Kilkenny district south of Dublin. There we were given an appreciation of the history and the culture of Ireland, which really gave us an important underpinning to our discussions. In the Irish segment of the delegation, I found the economic developmentâin particular the development of the public-private partnerships that are being well advanced in Ireland and how they have dealt with their deficiencies in education and the level of skills going back over the past decadeâof great value. In particular, the past eight years have truly seen the emergence of Ireland, as a Celtic tiger. We saw the advances that they have made for such a small, dynamic country in information technology in particular. We have brought back a wealth of information and of course those very important briefing materials. I was also particularly impressed with the advancement of peace in Ireland and, once again, with the overall question of regional development.

The second part of the delegation was, for me, a return visit to China. We had access to levels of Chinese government that one does not get unless one is a member of an official parliamentary delegation. I suppose the two areas in particular which I found of enormous value were the advances that China is making in environmental issues and its tackling of its enormous problem of reafforestation. On a personal note, I was able to have a business from my own electorate take part in a dinner and discussions with Madam Jiang, who is the President of the Academy of Forestry. Also, it was of enormous value to be able to see first-hand exactly how Australian government funding is being used in overseas aid. It was of tremendous value to see how a well has been built in one of the Chinese villages that we visited, to see how that water is now being piped into individual families' homes and to see the looks on all of those people's faces and the difference that that investment has made in their lives. I cannot speak highly enough of the organisation of the delegation and the value of the delegation to me as a member of this House.

talk.start.para: âOrder! The time allotted for comments on the report has expired.

âOn behalf of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I present the committee's report entitled Cracking down on copycats: enforcement of copyright in Australia, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: âThis report of the House of Representatives Standing committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs is the result of a prolonged study of the enforcement of copyright in Australia. Terms of reference for the inquiry were received from the Attorney-General in March 1999 and the committee commenced its work. In September 1999, when the Copyright Amendment (Digital Agenda) Bill 1999 was introduced into the House, the Attorney-General referred that bill to the committee for inquiry and report. The two inquiries complemented each other in part, because they both reflect a focus that is timelyâthat is, on copyright enforcement in a manner that is appropriate to the information age.

speech.para: The current inquiry followed a growing number of claims by some Australian industries that copyright owners and other members of the community are being deprived of income that is rightly theirs, because of infringement of copyright. Perhaps because copyright is an intangible form of property, its infringement or theft is not regarded with the same seriousness in the community as we regard thefts of other kind of property. It is also fair to say that copyright law is not well understood. This may also contribute to the broad lack of concern about infringement. Current attitudes to copyright law need to change. Many of the new jobs underpinning our economy involve the creation, manipulation, storage and use of information. It follows that adequate protection of intellectual property, including copyright, is essential for individual owners and also for our future prosperity.

In undertaking its inquiry the committee first surveyed the nature and extent of copyright infringement in Australia. It has concluded that, despite a perception in some industries that copyright infringement is rife, in fact it is low by international standards. I note in passing that evidence on whether and to what extent organised crime groups are involved in copyright infringement was conflicting. Most government bodies were not aware of such involvement, while some industry bodies told the committee they knew of some organised criminal groups that were involved. Whatever the frequency or source of infringement, the fact remains that it is a costly and significant burden to the economy. The committee heard evidence from copyright owners and industry groups that infringement is likely to increase in the future, especially in the electronic domain.

Facilitating proof of copyright ownership in both civil and criminal proceedings is the focus of one of the committee's key recommendations. The evidence received by the committee showed that proof of ownership has been a major stumbling block in actions for infringement. In response, the committee has advocated the use of an affidavit that outlines the chain of title, thus giving rise to a rebuttable presumption of ownership. The committee preferred this simplification over the reintroduction of a system of registration for copyright.

The committee has sought to strengthen criminal sanctions for infringement by advocating sentencing guidelines for copyright offences in the form of guideline judgments and by amendments to tighten the offence provisions in the Copyright Act. One recommendation aimed at deterring repeat offenders is for the provision of increased penalties for people who are convicted of subsequent offences. The committee also recommended new offences to target end-user piracy and bootlegging at public venues.

The committee was concerned to increase access by copyright owners to civil enforcement action as well as to enhance the effectiveness of such action. The main recommendation in this regard is for the establishment of a small claims jurisdiction within the Federal Magistrates Court to hear claims of infringement. The committee has also recommended a limited power of seizure to assist in the pre-trial process as well as calling for consideration of a system of statutory damages as an alternative to the requirement to prove actual damage. The committee considered it appropriate to lift the veil when enforcing copyright judgments against corporate infringers so that owners may recover damages from the directors of companies that are found to be engaged in piracy or bootlegging. Last, the committee examined the role played by government agencies and recommended some changes in this regard.

In conclusion, I hope that through this report, Cracking down on copycats, we can contribute to more effective enforcement of copyright throughout Australia and better education of all those involved. I thank all those individuals involved in the report, those who made submissions and the members of the committee for working in a constructive way to arrive at these recommendations. I thank the secretariat staffâin particular Andrew Grimm; the secretary, Catherine Cornish; and the administrative officer, Frances Wilsonâfor the work undertaken in support of the committee during this inquiry. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: âBefore I recognise the member for Denison, I indicate that the debate is supposed to conclude at 1 p.m. He may not have been aware of that. Some tolerance will be allowed, but it would be helpful if we did not run too far over time.

â Thank you, Mr Speaker. This report of the House Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs entitled Cracking down on copycats is a very important report. Firstly, I want to echo the words of the chair of that committee in congratulating those involved in the secretariat and on the committee. This was a very cooperative committee. The chair and deputy chair worked very well together to ensure that the procedures of the committee were streamlined. They worked very effectively. We had a wide opportunity to debate this internally. I think this is a vital report.

speech.para: Over a long period of time, this parliament's attention has been focused on the substantive copyright lawâmaking certain that we have legislation in place that correctly identifies legal rights and enables the remuneration of those who are rights holders. But giving people rights in law is only part of the responsibility of this legislature; the other part is making certain that those rights can be effectively enforced. There has been great weakness in terms of the capacity to translate a theoretical right into a practical right. This committee's starting point was that there needs to be some significant public education in relation to the importance of these copyright issues to make certain that the community understands the rights and responsibilities in relation to holders of copyright and how those rights can be enforced.

A number of recommendations go to the ease of proving mattersâremoving the procedural and technical difficulties that have hitherto made it difficult for copyright holders to establish their entitlements. There are some self-help measures included in this which particularly go to those who run stalls or flog goods outside concerts or the like which would enable copyright holders to seize those goods, but it would also give anyone who contests that right an opportunity at a later stage to have their case heard.

There are some practical measures in establishing a small claims tribunal, and this government has introduced a magistracy to the Federal Court. Hitherto, its focus has been in relation to streamlining the effectiveness of the Family Court. But, if we are going to establish a magistracy, there is no reason we cannot include within its jurisdiction a small claims jurisdiction of the kinds which operate in the various states and territoriesâand we suggested as models along the lines of the Tasmanian or ACT modelsâwhich would allow for small copyright matters to be heard in that very informal way.

âI move:

motion.para: That the House take note of the report.

speech.para: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, without wishing to intrude into the way in which you manage the affairs of the House, the Speaker, before you took the chair, indicated there might be some small latitude to conclude the remarks. If that is impossible I defer to you, of course, but I was getting to a conclusion.

âOn behalf of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, I present the committee's report entitled Six treaties tabled on 10 October 2000âReport 37, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: âThe report I have just presented contains the results of a review by the treaties committee of six proposed treaty actions tabled in parliament on 10 October this year. Five of them are: (1) a protocol concerning international registration of marks; (2) an agreement with Egypt regarding cooperation in the protection of children; (3) a double taxation agreement with the Russian Federation; (4) various acts of the Universal Postal Union; and (5) amendments to the schedule of the international whaling convention. In this report we express support for each of these treaty actions. However, there were two additional proposed treaty actions presented to parliament on that date in October on which we have not yet reported, because we have some misgivings about them. The first is a proposed Agreement on the Privileges and Immunities of the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea and the second, about which we have grave misgivings, is the 1998 statute of the proposed International Criminal Courtâwhatever that might be.

speech.para: I hope we will be able to resolve our position in relation to the first of these agreements by the end of this week. But, as parliament is rising for the summer adjournment on Thursday, we will not be able to present our findings on this until the new year. There is, however, much more work to be done in relation to our review of the statute of the proposed International Criminal Court. We have already held one hearing on this, and we are presently receiving written submissions from individuals and non-government organisations, all of which warrant very careful consideration. We are also keen to review the legislation that the government has already developed to give domestic effect to this so-called statute. Our view is that, if we are to report on whether ratifying the statute is really in the national interest, we also must consider the impact of ratification on our domestic lawâof which this bill will form part. Accordingly, we have written to the Attorney-General asking that the bill be referred to us for our consideration at the same time as we are examining the national interest analysis for the statute itself. We have not yet received a formal response from the Attorney-General, although the secretariat has heard informally that a response will arrive soon. I think it is unlikely that we will be able to report on this matter until late in next year's autumn sittingsâbut, then again, festina lente, as they say.

Turning back to report 37, I would like to focus on two of the six treaty actions we have reviewed: the protocol concerning the international registration of marks and the agreement with Egypt regarding cooperation in the protection of children. The first, the protocol on the registration of marksâthat is, trademarks, in effectâwill, we think, have a very beneficial effect on the handling of trademark registrations, because under the existing regime, in order to protect trademarks in overseas markets, an Australian trademark owner must register and maintain trademark protection in the trademark office of each particular country where he or she wants protection. This involves filing multiple applications in languages other than English and paying various government and legal fees every time. It is very time consuming and expensive, and not always fully effective. But under this proposed protocol this process will be streamlined, allowing an Australian trademark owner the ability to file a single application in English and pay fees to one office to obtain trademark protection in all or any of the countries that are parties to this protocol.

We also support the aims of the agreement with Egypt concerning the protection of children. This agreement establishes a mechanism to assist nationals of either country whose children have been abducted to the other country where difficulties with contact between a parent and a child have arisen. At present, parents seeking to re-establish contact with a child who has been illicitly transferred to and not returned from one of the countries really have access only to consular assistance. As good as Australia's consular officials are, in the case of these problems with children and marriage break-up this arrangement falls short of what I think we can achieve with a more formal mechanism via this treaty.

As we are nearing the end of the parliamentary year, I would like to say a few things about the work of the treaties committee. I think we can claim to be one of the more productive committees in this parliament. We have produced 20 reports, 10 since this time last year. We have six inquiries afoot, and they relate to the Kyoto protocol, Australia's relationship with the WTO, the extradition law, the Cartagena protocol on biosafety, the statute of the International Criminal Court and a smaller one into the treaty I referred to today, the Agreement on the Privileges and Immunities of the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea. This is a very substantial workload, but members of the committee from both sides of the House are made of very tough stuff. We look forward to performing those duties with the vigour we have up until now. I commend this report to the House.

talk.start.para: âReport 37 of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties deals with five treaties. There is a sixth that we are still dealing with. Those treaties relate to the protocol on trademarks, amendments to the International Whaling Convention, an agreement with Egypt on protecting the welfare of children, the double taxation agreement with the Russian Federation and acts of the Universal Postal Union. Those subjects are very diverse, as the treaty committee is in dealing with them. The report on the sixth treaty regarding the Agreement on the Privileges and Immunities of the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea is being reworked and will be presented later.

speech.para: The protocol on trademarks is based upon the Madrid Agreement Concerning the International Registration of Marks, although the Australian government is proposing to accede only to the protocol and not to the agreement itself. It was noted from submissions and other evidence that the cost of securing trademarks overseas is currently very high because of having to engage lawyers to go through the legislation of different countries in different languages. It has really worked against Australian trademarks being properly registered as it can involve filing multiple applications in languages other than English and the payment of government and legal fees on each occasion. This is a significant burden on small business and a real barrier to entry in some cases to international markets. This was made clear from the hearings we held and the evidence we took. Ross Wilson, representing IP Australia, spoke of the extensive process of industry, professional and public consultation undertaken by IP Australia on the potential impact and advantages of the protocol. The submission included a description of the access that has been made to information published on IP Australia's Internet site and a description of the industry consultation that has been undertaken in Tasmania. The signing of the protocol means that a person can establish their trademark in Australia once and it is accepted across the protocol signatories. It is certainly worth while for Australia and Australian industry.

The other agreement I wish to speak about is the amendments to the International Whaling Commission. Australia has been involved with a number of treaties on this issue and these amendments merely reinforce our position. The amendments arise from the annual requirement to take account of the dates listed in the schedule to the convention, which describes the moratorium on commercial whaling. In effect, these amendments maintain the moratorium for a further 12 months. But while mechanical in nature, this agreement is one for which amendments automatically enter into force for each party 90 days after the date of notification unless a party lodges an objection to the amendment within that period. Although in this instance the committee was happy to see the moratorium maintained and there is no objection to the treaty action, the automatic entry into force of provisions could make a mockery of the parliament's treaty making process.

In other treaties, it was noted that providing parliament with advice of amendments after they had been agreed by the parties to a treaty and shortly before they automatically come into force runs contrary to the treaty making reform process. The treaties committee looked at this in some detail and sought an earlier notification of amendments which automatically enter into force, and it is urged that the government respond promptly to these recommendations. The treaties committee plays an important role in these international agreements and it is a most rewarding and informative committee to be on. I would like to thank the committee members, the chairman, who is in the House today, and also the secretariat for another very good year. It has been a very interesting year, and we have dealt with very interesting subjects on behalf of the parliament. I certainly enjoy my work on the treaties committee, and I am sure that other members do too. It has been a very worthwhile year of work that that committee has put in place.
