motion.para: That this House:
(1) congratulates Iran regarding the completion of acknowledged democratic elections and the work of the new Majlis;

(2) nevertheless regrets that Iran's reputation continues to be marred by questions of human rights and denial of religious freedom, most particularly the persecution of Baha'is and the renewal of the death sentences of Mr Hedayat Kashefi Najafabadi and Mr Sirus Zabihi-Moghaddam, and the inception of another against Mr Manuchehr Khulusi;
(3) furthermore notes the persistent gaoling of numerous Baha'is for their religious beliefs and widespread discrimination in property, education, employment, civil and political rights;
(4) acknowledges grave concern for the fate of 13 members of the Jewish community presently in custody in Iranian prisons and facing charges of espionage; and
(5) urges Australia's continued vigilance and activity regarding human rights issues in Iran.

speech.para: This parliament has debated the situation of the Baha'is and religious freedom in Iran on a number of occasions, most recently in motions put before the parliament by the member for Reid and also by the member for North Sydney. The motions have been debated at length by some distinguished members of this House, including the member for Aston, the member for Hindmarsh and the member for Franklin. I welcome their involvement in those discussions. The general situation of the Baha'is in Iran is quite appalling. To give some credence to that, I would like to advise the House of a number of areas where they are unable to practise their faith and the resulting distress that it causes the community.

It is a matter of deep regret that Iran's conduct in this area continues to justify the concern of this parliament and, indeed, of the international community as a whole. The Baha'i community in Iran numbers around 300,000. It is the largest non-Muslim religious minority in that country, yet it continues to face systematic persecution by the Iranian authorities. Currently 10 Baha'is are imprisoned and one is under house arrest in Iran because of their religious beliefs. A number of these are under the death sentence. Baha'is have been systematically excluded from employment and higher education in Iran. An entire generation of Baha'i youth has been prevented from entering Iran's tertiary institutions. The Iranian government has sought to prevent Baha'is from undertaking their own education of Baha'i youth by arresting and intimidating teachers who voluntarily undertook to provide education the government has sought to deny them. These efforts have been unsuccessful and the Baha'is continue to run a correspondence based Baha'i Institute for Higher Education.

The most holy places of the Baha'i faith, Baha'i community properties and Baha'i cemeteries have been desecrated, destroyed or confiscated. No attempt has been made to restore or compensate the Baha'i community, as called for by the international community. Baha'is continue to be denied the right to bury their deceased relatives with dignity, being forced to use unmarked graves in areas of waste land. The `spiritual assemblies' of the Baha'is, elected lay councils of nine men and women which fulfil some of the roles of clergy in other religions, are sacred to the Baha'is and membership of these has been banned by the Iranian government. This is a significant restriction on the freedom of Baha'is to practice their religion in accordance with the tenets of their faith. It is also a denial of the freedom of assembly and association that every individual possesses. The freedom of association of Baha'is is regularly impeded by government interference in devotional and educational meetings of the community. Mr Maurice Copithorne, the UN Special Representative on the Human Rights Situation in Iran, in his latest report, notes continuing acts of intimidation carried out in order to prevent Baha'is from participating in religious or educational activities and an apparent increase in the number of short-term arrests and suspended sentences to be applied only if the accused participate again in Baha'i gatherings.

Baha'is encounter difficulties in obtaining passports, impeding their freedom of movement. One improvement that should be noted is that, although Iran does not recognise the right of Baha'is to marry in accordance with their own religious traditions, by removing questions on religion at the time of registration of marriage, Iran has now put in place measures to allow administrative acknowledgment of the marital status of a Baha'i couple. This removes a longstanding civil discrimination affecting the legality of family life of Baha'is and their inheritance rights and is to be welcomed. The treatment of the Baha'is in Iran is undoubtedly a key issue in terms of both religious freedom and human rights for that country.

In Australia, 12,000 Baha'is live in full religious freedom. They, like other Australians, are not subject to intrusive inquiry into their beliefs, nor to penalties because of their faith. They are a diverse religious community of a wide variety of backgrounds who seek to give expression to their religious convictions by worship and by service to society. Their beliefs include principles such as oneness of God, the oneness of humanity, the equality of men and women and the independent investigation of religious truth. They are known for their commitment to the promotion of peace. In 1986, the Australian Baha'i community received a peace award from the UN Secretary-General for its work in the promotion of peace during the International Year of Peace. In my electorate the members of the Baha'i community share my deep concern for their fellow believers in Iran. Many Australian Baha'is have relatives in Iran, including some among those imprisoned in Iran for their beliefs. They live in constant anxiety as to the fate of their relatives.

Recently there were parliamentary elections in Iran. The motion that is currently before the House also addresses those elections. The elections demonstrated the strong commitment of the Iranian people to parliamentary democracy and their aspiration for civil and political freedoms. Iran is to be congratulated for that achievement. It is to be hoped that Iran's parliament will be given the freedom to carry out its responsibilities as the representative of the people of Iran.

In relation to the death sentences and penalties that have been imposed by the courts, this motion also refers to the cases of Mr Hedayat Kashefi Najafabadi, Mr Sirus Zabihi-Moghaddam and Mr Manuchehr Khulusi, who have been sentenced to death because of their involvement in organising religious classes for Baha'i youth. I have been informed by representatives of the Australian Baha'i community that, in the cases of Mr Najafabadi and Mr Moghaddam, these sentences were recently set aside as unsound by the Iranian Supreme Court and that their cases were referred back to a lower court. This is the third time that even the Iranian Supreme Court has felt the injustice of these cases and quashed lower court decisions imposing death sentences on these men.

It is time that these men were released. They were first sentenced to death in February 1998, along with another Baha'i, Mr Ruhullah Rawhani, who was in fact executed by the regime for his beliefs. In March 1998, the Supreme Court rejected the verdicts, finding no evidence against them and that their religious beliefs did not provide justification for a death sentence. The case was referred back to a lower court. In September 1998, a lower Islamic Revolutionary Court again sentenced them to death, despite the findings of the Supreme Court. The men were tried againâthis time with a lawyer of their choice, which had been denied to them previously. In January 1999, the Supreme Court again overturned the verdict for the second time because of what were referred to as `technical deficiencies'. In November 1999, the men were again sentenced to death by the same lower court, leading to the latest Supreme Court decision quashing the sentence. Only one action should be taken in this case and that is the immediate release of these men.

Mr Manuchehr Khulusi was also sentenced to death in Mashhad but later released. No action appears to have been taken to revoke the death sentence which continues to hang over his head. There are other Baha'i prisoners facing similar fates. I would like to read an extract from the Iranian court decision in regard to Mr Dhabihullah Mahrami, recognised by Amnesty International as a prisoner of conscience, to make clear what his case is about and why he is imprisoned for life in Iran. It states:

quote.para: Concerning the charges against Mr Dhabihullah Mahrami ... ie denouncing the blessed religion of Islam and accepting the beliefs of the wayward Baha'i sect (national apostasy), in light of his clear confessions to the fact that he accepted the wayward Baha'i sect at the age of maturity, later accepted Islam for a period of seven years, and then returned to the aforementioned sect and because of the fact that, despite the most tremendous efforts of this court to guide him and encourage him to repent for having committed the most grievous sin, he remains firm in his baseless beliefs, he has, on three consecutive meetings, while being of sound body and mind and in absolute control, announced his allegiance to the principles of Baha'ism ... and he is not willing to repent for having committed this sin ... the accused is sentenced to death because of being an apostate. Furthermore ... in light of the fact that he does not have any Muslim heirs, a verdict is issued for the confiscation of all his properties and assets.

speech.para: There have also been the trials of Jewish prisoners who have received similar fates for very similar reasons. Obviously none of these imprisonments are justified, and action needs to be taken to ensure that these people are released as quickly as possible. I urge Australia's continued vigilance and activity regarding human rights issues in Iran. The Australian government must continue to take every opportunity in both multilateral forums and its bilateral relationships to promote the universality and indivisibility of all human rights, specifically the right to freedom of religion and belief. I thank the Baha'is community for their assistance in preparing today's presentation.

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)âIs the motion seconded?
âI second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

âI think this is a very interesting motion because it deals with issues that are pertinent to Australia's national interest. The position of Iran in the politics of the Middle East is significant and changes to the standards of human rights covenants within that country will have an effect on countries around Iran. Some of the things that we ought to take note of include some improvement in human rights standards in Iran, as acknowledged in the first part of the motion. Later clauses deal with some of the more unfortunate things that are still going on. Of particular interest to me is the treatment of 13 members of the Jewish community who were charged with various offences, 10 of whom are currently in prison, facing charges of espionage and so forth.

speech.para: What underlies some of the changes in Iran are some changes in its demographic trends. In 1996, Iran held a census and found that 40 per cent of the population was aged under 14 years. So now, with a few years passing, these citizens, who are approaching their twenties, perhaps represent Iran's best hope for the creation of a modern democracy in the country. It is important to emphasise, too, that, although the reforms are only in their embryonic stage and they still have much to achieve, there has been some noteworthy groundwork set down by President Khatami, who is described as a moderate and who was elected to office in 1997 with a groundswell of support from the voting public. He has made some progress in trying to remake what was an intensely theocratic state and to turn it into a much less restrictive one. This is why, with the support of a young population he is achieving some success.

There has been some degree of cultural liberalisation. The government in Iran now recognises marriages between members of the Baha'i community, and it is proposed that university places will soon be open to members of this minority group. Although that is a positive step forward, it is astonishing how intensely discriminated against this community has been in Iran. You cannot erase that over the course of just a few months. I do not know quite why the government of Iran has such an intense hatred of this minority group. They seem a very peaceful folk to me, but it has been the case. Although there has been some liberalisation in the treatment of these people, it behoves us, the Australian governmentâas the motion and its mover, the member for Swan, sayâto continue to scrutinise very carefully what is going on there and to speak up when the need arises.

President Khatami has also indicated his commitment to human rights in a more general sense and to creating a more open dialogue between nations. This is a very welcome movement in Iran because, compared with some of its neighboursâfor instance, Afghanistan, where the ultraorthodox Islamic militia, the Taliban, hold governmentâIran's human rights record is marginally more favourable. Next door in Iraq there are significant problems with Saddam Hussein still holding office, but, in the long term, Iran could have a democratising effect on some of its neighbours. Australia would welcome the opportunity to improve relations with countries in the Middle East generally, were this process to take place.

However, in spite of some of these reforms, there is obviously still within Iran an ongoing tension between reformists and very hardline elementsâthose who are stalwart defenders of the revolution that still maintains a stranglehold on some of Iran's institutions. It remains very much under the control of its clerics, who maintain control over the armed forces, the broadcasting authorities, the judiciary and so forth. So there is a conflict between these two groups: the clerics on one side and the parliament, or Majlis, on the other. This conflict is having an impact on the efforts of the president and the new parliament to effect democratisation that the majority of Iranians appear to support.

We have to encourage reform, but, at the same time, we must not be blind to the existing and continuing abuses. The most immediate human rights concern is the fate of what is called the `Shiraz 10'. These are Iranian Jews charged with espionage, and they are conspicuous victims of this bitter struggle between the reformist and the hardliners within Iran. Australia has acknowledged its concern for the safety of these people, who were arrested and imprisoned in the city of Shiraz, and we continue to argue for their release. The Iranian government's actions in targeting, arresting, incarcerating and, thereafter, trying and sentencing these Jews represent a significant blow to their internal reform processes, and to do something about it would serve Iran's reputation very well.

More alarming I suppose is the fact that the trials of these innocent people reveal an absence of democratic rights and due process for minority religious groups in Iran. Since their incarceration, Australia has made 27 separate representations to the Iranian government expressing concern about the fate of these people. In July this year 10 of the 13 people charged in Shiraz were found guilty and given sentences of between four and 13 years. These people included community leaders, religious teachers and a rabbi, and initial concern for the welfare of those convicted extends both to their immediate physical safety and to that of their families. Subsequent appeals have resulted in sentence reductions of two to six years for some peopleâindeed, for six out of the 10. While I suppose this is something of a demonstration of good faith, it is more appropriate that those convictions be overturned.

In a larger sense, this issue throws light on Iran's treatment of Jewish people in prison. It highlights the general issue of human rights standards and the problem of how we go about encouraging countries to meet those standards. Originally, the most basic principle of the law of nationsâor international law, as it is called these daysâwas that one nation would not interfere in the internal affairs of another. This enabled sovereign nations to navigate their way through trying to resolve world problems that cropped up from time to time without too much conflict. We dealt with each other nation to nation and did not interfere constantly in what was happening in a neighbour's territory.

However, particularly postwar, some of the conventions and agreements that established universal standards of human rights have sought to vary this basic notionâby declaring that such-and-such a manner of treating somebody shall be a violation of a basic human right, for example. That gives rise to the presumption that it is all right to interfere to some degree, or threaten to interfere, in the internal affairs of another country. The trouble is that, by setting these standards and then cloaking them in the costume of law without providing for an enforcement mechanism, we create endless frustration. On one side, we have these standards that must be met; and, on the other side, we have no real way of making sure that they are metâas we would be able to do in a domestic situation.

In the end, peer nationsâsuch as is happening at the moment in this parliamentâput pressure on another government to deal with its people, albeit religious minorities, in a more gentle and civil way. That is the only practical way of improving human rights, and it can be a good approach if we persist. However, we do not need so-called leadership from Euro politicians, appointed with grand titles, from the UN system telling us what we should or should not protest about. These are the sorts of things that sovereign nations and the elected members of parliaments in those nations can decide very well for themselves. That is exactly what we are doing in the case of those people who are suffering oppression within Iran.

talk.start.para: âIn seconding this motion, I congratulate my colleague the member for Swan on keeping the plight of the Baha'is in Iran in the public arena. I will give members a short history of the Baha'i faith. The Baha'i faith was founded in Iran in the mid-1880s and Baha'is have been persecuted there ever since. By religious standards, the faith is relatively new. The Baha'i understand that this type of persecution stems from the fact that their faith is new and that the traditionalist, or older faiths, misunderstand or fear a new religion.

speech.para: However, this understanding does not provide acceptance of the fact that, during the 19th century, 20,000 people died as a result of violence perpetrated on Baha'i followers by the Islamic religious authorities. That persecution and violence continued into the 20th century, with regular violence being experienced by the Baha'is in Iran. Different regimes over the years have even formalised policies of oppression against the Baha'is as concessions to the clergy and to garner support from the nation's Islamic leadership. During these years Baha'i literature was banned, Baha'i marriages were not recognised, Baha'is in the public service were demoted or sacked and Baha'i schools were even closed.

Another massive round of violenceâmurders, rapes and robberiesâoccurred following the decision of the Pahlavi regime in 1955 to allow Islamic clerics to broadcast on national radio denouncing the Baha'i faith, thus inciting further violence. The irony of the suffering of the Baha'i followers in Iran is that a major tenet of their faith is that loyalty to government is an essential spiritual and social principle. Even today, as Baha'i followers continue to face persecution in Iran, the faith pronounces loyalty to governments.

This motion also urges Australia's continued vigilance and activity regarding human rights issues in Iran. In this regard, particular importance is placed on the biannual resolution of the human rights situation in Iran at the United Nations General Assembly and the United Nations Commission on Human Rights. This resolution expresses international concern about a range of serious human rights violations occurring in Iran and provides recommendations to Iran to remedy these violations. The resolution has been of critical importance in discouraging even greater violations of the rights of the Baha'is by extremist elements in Iran. However, rather than addressing the United Nations recommendations for protecting the rights of Iranian citizens, the Iranian government has devoted its energies to defeating the resolution.

Successive Australian governments have consistently supported the resolution and Australia has been a co-sponsor of the resolutions since their inception in 1980. Given the wide range of human rights abuses in Iran detailed in numerous United Nations reports, there is no justification for any change in Australia's policy. Therefore, I am happy to congratulate the government on its decision to co-sponsor this year's resolution that is now before the United Nations General Assembly. I call on the government to continue this bipartisan tradition of defending the human rights and religious freedom of the Baha'is and other religious minorities in Iranâparticularly in light of the report on this important topic that was presented just last week by this parliament's human rights subcommittee. It recommended that:

quote.para: ... the Australian Government continue to take every opportunity, in both multilateral forums and in its bilateral relationships, to promote the universality and indivisability of all human rights, specifically the right to freedom of religion and belief.

speech.para: Co-sponsorship of the UN resolution on the human rights situation in Iran presents such an opportunity. Moreover, in light of this recommendation, I call on the Australian government to give priority to working with like-minded nations to ensure greater international support for the resolution of the human rights situation in Iran. Two decades is enough time for Iran to remedy this human rights issue, which justifiably continues to concern this parliament and the international community. I acknowledge my good friend Tom Jones, Secretary of the Newcastle Baha'is, for his continued support and friendship and for his ongoing local advocacy of world peace and international harmony.

talk.start.para: âIn responding to this motion from the member for Swan, I would like to first talk about the political situation in Iran, the encouraging things that we can say about Iran, and then focus on the treatment of the Baha'i community and the Jewish community in Iran. At the February 2000 elections for the Iranian parliament, President Khatami received the support of the Iranian people. The encouraging things about this occurrence are that President Khatami has a reformist program and he has emphasised the promotion of the rule of law, upholding the Iranian constitution.

speech.para: Iran's human rights record does compare favourably to those of some of its neighbours. As for improvements that we have seen, there has been greater government transparency; there has been increased women's access to education and to politics; and legislation covering reform of the marriage laws has been introduced into the parliament. A judicial reform has been canvassed but has not gone any further than that. Despite those things, which are on the good side of the ledger, we should be concerned about how minority groups, especially Jews and Baha'is, are being treated in Iran. I am pleased that the Australian government has sought assurances that minorities are protected by the constitution.

The Baha'i community of South Australia has its headquarters in my electorate. I was pleased recently to attend an evening its members organised, which celebrated the year 2000 as the International Year of Peace. I am also pleased that the foreign affairs minister, Alexander Downer, raised human rights issues, including the discrimination against the Baha'i community in Iran, during his July 2000 visit to Teheran. Australia has also co-sponsored the resolutions relating to human rights in Iran, both at the United Nations General Assembly just recently and also at the Commission of Human Rights. Australia has made representations on individual cases and for the Baha'i community as a whole in Canberra and Teheran. So we are continuing to make representations about this important minority, whose members have been persecuted in Iran.

In regard to the Jewish community, Australia has made 27 separate representations to the Iranian government in concern over the arrest and trial of 13 Iranian Jews and nine Muslims. I think, since this motion was put in, three members of the Jewish community have been acquitted, so it is now actually 10 members of the Jewish community. Thirteen of these representations to Iran have been made at a ministerial level. Australia has expressed concerns at the trial outcome for these 13 Iranian Jews and also at deficiencies in the trial processâand it will continue to make those representations.

In summary, some improvements are being made in Iran. We need to continue through motions like this, which are helpful, to co-sponsor the human rights motions in the United Nations General Assembly and also the Commission of Human Rights. We should also be prepared to take up individual cases, as we have done and which have been taken up at a ministerial level.

talk.start.para: âThe time allotted for the debate has not quite expired, but I think it would probably be in keeping with what the member for Swan had in mind if, in fact, we were to adjourn the debate.

interjection.para: Debate (on motion by Mr Wilkie) adjourned.

talk.start.para: âIt is not quite 1.45 p.m., but I think it would suit all members of the House if we were to have some additional members' statements. We will exercise some flexibility and pronounce it 1.45 p.m.

âI draw to the attention of this parliament a serious issue relating to a constituent of Greenway, Mr Keith Harrison. He served in the Australian Navy on the HMAS Hawkesbury during the atomic tests at Monte Bello. Keith is now suffering from leukemia but is unable to get any preferential medical treatment or a service pension, as he is not considered a `veteran' under the Veterans' Entitlements Act. The HMAS Hawkesbury was the only naval ship to remain in the atomic testing area for the duration of the testing period, except for a short trip back to Fremantle. When the Hawkesbury did dock in Fremantle during the testing period, there was considerable public concern about radiation contamination.

speech.para: Although Keith served a total of six years in the Navy, he is one of only three crewmen of the Hawkesbury who did not serve in an operational area during `specified dates'. Therefore, he is classified as an `ex-serviceman' and not a `veteran'. It is my view that a strong moral case exists for Keith to be considered a victim of the atomic tests at Monte Bello. I will be asking the various government departments to acknowledge this fact and grant Keith the necessary means to obtain medical treatment for any illness contracted during his service in the Australian Navy.

subdebateinfo.title: Capricornia Electorate: Rockhampton Post Office Award

talk.start.para: âThere is great news from Rockhampton this week. The post office in East Street, Rockhampton was named Australia's best country post officein the 2000 Australia Post National Excellence Awards. It is great news but not surprising. The post office is just down the road from my office, so it is the one that my staff and I rely on. I know that they are a highly professional and customer focused team of people. As well as that, they are very friendly and really great people to deal with or just have a chat to across the counter.

speech.para: The post office has three sectionsâthe mail room, the sales counter and the administration that looks after the LPOs in the region. The high standards of each section contributed to the win. I want to congratulate all the staff at the East Street Post Office. I am thrilled for you that you got the recognition that you deserve, and it shows what Rockhampton is capable of. Congratulations to Ken Clements, Nancy Norman, Michelle Doyle, Barry Counter, Peta Dawson, Dallas Harling, Sandy McMaster, Craig Jarmey, Merv Kenneally, Craig Golik, Laurel Vize, Arthur Cora, Hans Reid and Wayne Higman. The team was led by the manager, Shirley Wiley, who did a fantastic job of promoting Australia Post in Rockhampton. I have never met anyone so proud of their team. Shirley has just taken over as the manager in Bundaberg, and I wish her well. I know that the new manager, Ev Rose, will continue that spirit of enthusiastic leadership; and it is going to be hard for anyone to take this award away from the Rocky team in the years to come.

talk.start.para: âThe 15th Colac Six-Day Race is a world-class event and this year was won on 26 November for the second time by Yiannis Kouros of Greece. Kouros had previously won the six-day race in 1984 and showed his great courage in winning the event this year with a severe groin injury, proving his world dominator status.

speech.para: Cliff Young's epic win in the Westfield Marathon in 1983 proved the inspiration to stage a six-day race at Colac in the heartland of the electorate of Corangamite. The 400-metre track is around the memorial square in the centre of Colac, which allows members of the public to support the runners night and day during the race. Kouris ran 801 kilometres in six days of competition, which is an amazing effort

Some of the other competitors competing in this gruelling and testing event came from other states and overseas. All performed with credit and distinction. Congratulations go to Drew Kettle, the 80-year-old local legend who beat the world record in ultramarathon running for the over-80 age group, with a total of 388 kilometres. The thanks of the Colac community go to the chairman, Ian Lane, and his enthusiastic committee, particularly Pat Heffernan and John Farrell, who have sought sponsorship from the Colac people. The Colac community also thanks long-distance runner and personality Tony Rafferty for his enthusiastic support for the event.

talk.start.para: âEvidence received at a Senate committee inquiry indicates widespread tax avoidance through the abuse of superannuation schemes. The abuse of superannuation schemes is part of a family of avoidance schemes known as employee benefit arrangements. These are new generation bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. They are rampant. Yet the Treasurer is standing by his ridiculously low estimate that $1.5 billion is tied up in these scams. We have been told that one promoter alone has channelled $2 billion through the so-called non-complying superannuation schemes. The government's new generation bottom-of-the-harbour scheme could have perhaps $5 billion tied up in it. The tax office estimate of $1.5 billion was generated in April 1999 and the tax office is too embarrassed to update it. The scandal is that, if the tax office and the government will not admit the true size of the problem, they will not seek to recover the lost revenue.

speech.para: I am informed that one company, the Remuneration Planning Corporation, received a letter from the tax office advising that some of the schemes it was promoting were illegal. I am further told that RPC failed to alert its clients to the tax office advice. I am advised that, instead, RPC busied itself trying to obtain a favourable private binding ruling from the tax office to support its schemes and that RPC was successful in this endeavour. RPC might like to deny this, and I would welcome a public assurance that RPC has not received such a letter from the tax office and has not sought and obtained a favourable binding ruling. I know the tax office has issued favourable private binding rulings for schemes it considered illegal. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI would like to relate a positive and good news story. Last Monday in the grievance debate I raised the issue of the nine surviving members of HMAS Armidale, which was sunk on 1 December 1942. One of the members wrote to the Minister for Defence, who unfortunately said that the government were unable to assist them in transport and accommodation to attend the commissioning of HMAS Sheean in March next year in Western Australia.

speech.para: Through the tremendous support of Bill Birnbauer of the Age and 3AW's Neil Mitchell, a campaign of lobbying was undertaken and I am pleased to announce that the minister, through the lobbying of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs by members opposite as well as members of both sides of parliament in Victoria, was able to have the decision reversed. Those nine remaining members are now going to have their accommodation and transport paid for to go to the commissioning of HMAS Sheean, in commemoration of Teddie Sheean, in March in Western Australia next year. It is a great story and I do thank the government for finally reversing their decision.

talk.start.para: âI have just learned that another bank is to close in my electorate of Lowe. The Westpac branch in Drummoyne is to slam its doors shut in the faces of its loyal customers on Friday, 5 January 2001. It was only a little over a month ago that the National Australia Bank in Drummoyne closed its doors. The bank was right next door to the Westpac Bank in Victoria Road. I organised a demonstration and was joined by the shadow Treasurer, Simon Crean; the shadow minister for financial services and regulation, Senator Stephen Conroy; local mayors, councillors, angry business people and pensioners; and the leaders in the push for the establishment of community banks, Ashfield councillor Emma Brooks-Maher and Mrs Marlene Doran, President of the Homebush Main Street Committee. I have spoken out in this House on several occasions about the recent bank closures in my electorate of Lowe. Ten major branches have closed in the last two years.

speech.para: Like NAB, ANZ and the Commonwealth Bank, once again Westpac is showing it has no interest in our communityâjust in satisfying the greed of its shareholders with record profits and record fee increases. The big four banks are devastating our shopping centres and thumbing their noses at the most vulnerable in our community, who need access to bricks and mortar banking. The sooner we start opening community banks the better. I warn the banks that Emma Brooks-Maher and Marlene Doran are rapidly reaching their targets with pledges of financial support, and we will not stop the campaign to open community banks and encourage people and businesses alike to start moving their money away from the big four banks to community banks. Quite obviously, the banks have absolutely no conscience. They are greedy, they are avaricious and they are interested only in satisfying their shareholders. They are not interested in looking after ordinary people. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âOn Friday I witnessed a momentous occasion for all hospitals in Australia. I was present at the launch of a revolutionary waste system for Redcliffe Hospital, operated by Australian Waste Services. The company was established in 1995 to commercialise the technology of the Mark Costello Co., which was established in 1992. This new, automated, waste system developed and completed for on-site hospital waste treatment system was the first of its kind in Australia. It will cut harmful emissions from the disposal process to a fraction of the current level. The new, environmentally friendly system was developed and commercialised with the assistance of a $373,730 Commonwealth research and development START grant. The technology is now being used throughout the world. Representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Nick Minchin, I recognised the wonderful contribution that this company has made to research and development and its continued commitment in that area. The company is very well recognised throughout Australia and also throughout the world. Recently the World Bank recognised the company and endorsed it for its wonderful projects in West Bengal. The company is also expanding to the United States and Europe. AWS Clinical Waste is recognised in Australia and internationally as a specialist in treating clinical and quarantine waste by means of steam sterilisation, and this is reflected in its global sales. I was very pleased to be there and I am sure the company will move to bigger and better things.

âI would like to take a brief moment of the time of the House to talk about the registered clubs movement and the contribution of the Mounties chief executive, Mr Vic Smith. The club movement is part of the lifeblood of local communities. Clubs provide free or affordable facilities to the community. They provide encouragement and financial support to sporting and other interest groups under the club umbrella. They provide financial assistance to schools, hospitals, charities and other essential community services. They are democratic. They are great employers, offering career paths to the local community. They are consumers of local goods and services. They are run by the local community and provide a glowing illustration of cooperative purchasing power.

speech.para: One of the club industry's great general managers is about to retire. Mr Vic Smith of Mounties has shown terrific business sense and great sense of community. He is someone who got the balance right for his board of directors, the 45,000 members of the club, and the bigger neighbourhood of Mount Pritchard and the surrounding district. The enterprise he administered was not simply driven for profit. Mounties is first and foremost a community asset, so that makes him different from most other people in business. His shareholders, the membership and the board of directors are right there where he works. He has made a contribution to the community through his great management of a community owned asset. Vic, I wish you a great retirement. You will be greatly missed, especially by the community.

talk.start.para: âI would like to speak briefly today about agriculture. My electorate's boundaries have changed and now encompass a lot more agricultural area than in the past.
âYou will need your gumboots.

âI carry my gumboots in the boot of my car, and have done for many years, because I have always had a large agricultural sector in my electorate. Agriculture has been about 70 per cent of my electorate in the past, but that figure has now moved up substantially. As I grew up in the country, and my family were pioneers in Western Australia who came to the state in 1829 on the promise of land, I think that I have some understanding of some of the issues that confront farmers today. The future of agriculture in Australia has been the subject of a very wide ranging debate, and a very important debate because city people are becoming increasingly aware of the importance of agricultural production to their communities. The federal government's Regional Australia Summit held earlier this year has stimulated that debate quite a bit. There is no argument that everyone in this country has benefited from the infrastructure that was provided through the backbreaking work of the men and women of the land since early settlement until the present time. Agricultural regions and towns that support farm families are faced with a lot of challenges. (Time expired)

âOn Saturday I was delighted to open the Heritage Studio at Heritage FM, the local community radio station in Canning. The radio station is just coming up to its third birthday on Australia Day of next year and in such a short time has achieved many marvellous things. One of the things we are very proud of is that it is run solely by volunteers. I would like to take the opportunity today to congratulate Brett Tizzard and all the board who have worked over the years to build the Heritage FM radio station to the great success it is today. The Federation Studio that we opened on Saturday has given us new, up-to-date equipment and as the patron of the station I certainly take a great pride in what the volunteers have achieved. We often speak about how we need to build communities. As I said to the group on Saturday, they are a pure demonstration of what community people are all about. And how proud I am to represent them. Again, I say congratulations to the board and volunteers and wish them every success.

âIn the lead-up to the Year of the Volunteer I would like to add my congratulations to four community members who won the Kariong-Somersby Rotary Community Service awards and Pride of Workmanship awards. I was honoured to be the guest speaker and to present these awards recently. Time will not permit me to go into full details of the contribution these people have made to the community. The four winners were Mrs Diane Burling, Mr Ron Jollow, Mrs Merryl Stopps and Mr Michael Selfe. Each of these people has made a very significant contribution to the Central Coast community: Mrs Burling particularly with her work with the Girl Guides; Mr Ron Jollow with his many years of work with the Wendoree Bush Fire Brigade; Mrs Merryl Stopps, who has received a pride of workmanship award, particularly for her work with the Kariong Neighbourhood Centre and the particular role of making sure that the Kariong Connection is printed and distributed throughout the Kariong community; and Mr Michael Selfe, who has put in many years with the Kariong Volunteer Rural Fire Brigade. These four people are great examples to the community of contributing through volunteer work. The quality of our community is enhanced by the contribution that they have made to the Central Coast community.
âOrder! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106A the time for members' statements has concluded.

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade: Consular Services

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Minister, with the holiday season fast approaching, would you update the House on how the government is working to protect the welfare of Australians travelling overseas?

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr DOWNER
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Aston for his question and I particularly recognise his concern about the welfare of Australians who are travelling overseas. The House may be interested to know that during the last financial year 3.3 million Australians travelled overseasâ120,000 more than the previous year. I see it as an important responsibility for both me and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to ensure that high-quality consular services are provided to those members of the public who may need assistance. Almost 21,000 Australians in difficulty sought assistance from our missions around the world last year, including many who became caught up in trouble spots and areas affected by natural disasters. For example, we assisted many people in East Timor and the Solomon Islands, especially with the evacuations in September 1999 and June 2000; we assisted with those Australians involved with the sinking of a ferry in the Greek islands in October this year; we assisted with those affected by flooding in Thailand in November, and with those affected by the hostage crisis and civil coup in Fiji.

answer.para: Australians can access consular assistance through 154 points overseas. My department has also increased from 47 to 54 the number of locations overseas where Australians can call toll-free to the 24-hour call centre in Canberra. Our advice to Australians travelling overseas is monitored constantly to ensure that up-to-date information is available on travellers' safety and on specific problems in different countries. My department provides online access to consular information via the DFAT web site, and press releases are put out in the normal way. Australia now provides a better quality consular service than that of comparable countries such as the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada and New Zealand. We will endeavour to ensure that those high standards are maintained and that the best interests of Australians are properly protected when they travel around the world.

subdebateinfo.title: Liberal Party of Australia: Electoral Practices

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, in light of the public funding provided to the Liberal Party, and given the widespread claims and reporting of serial rorting in your partyâ
âThe Leader of the Opposition is entitled to the call, as is any other member of the parliament, and will be heard in silence.

âAnd, given the widespread claims and reporting of serial rorting in your party, including evidence of false enrolments, forged membership forms and interstate and overseas members of the Liberal Party branches in South Australia, Queensland, Tasmania and Western Australia, will you do as I have done with my party and order a national audit of the Liberal Party's membership?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âI thank the Leader of the Opposition for his question. It is worth pointing out to the House that the matters which are now the subject of a great deal of coverage in the Australian press arose from the conviction of a member of the Labor Party for a criminal offence. This constant attempt being made to compare a criminal treatment of the electoral roll with the vigorous exchanges that go on in all parties in relation to preselection is an utterly false analogy. The question of an audit of the membership of the Liberal Party is a matter for the party organisation, and whenever I have faced a difficulty in the party organisation in my time as leader of the Liberal Partyâas I faced with the Western Australian branch early in 1995 when I returned to the leadershipâI have not done what the Leader of the Opposition did: roll over at a national executive meeting. Let the Leader of the Opposition clean up the mess in his own backyard before making false allegations about my colleagues.

âMy question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Would the Deputy Prime Minister outline to the House how the government's workplace relations reforms have improved the reliability and performance of Australia's waterfront? How will these reforms benefit farmers and businesses in my electorate of Riverina? Have alternative policies worked in the past?

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Deputy Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member for her question. I am delighted to be able to say something about waterfront reform in this country. We have implemented reforms that have been focused on what is good for Australia. We are an export economy; indeed, as the Treasurer has pointed out, recent growth has been largely based on a stronger export performance. We are not a shipper nation but a shipping nation. We are dependent upon an efficient transport system and efficient wharves, whether it is for our farmers, whether it is for our miners or whether it is for our manufacturers who are exportingâand, of course, they have been doing very well.

answer.para: Our reforms have been focused on what is good for the nation. In contrast, Labor have not actually changed their policy position at all. They are still locked into the view that what is good for waterfront workers is good for Australia, and that is not necessarily the case. Not so very long ago, a couple of months ago, the member for Batman said:

quote.para: The Government has been boasting that its hard-line waterfront policies have been working, but these latest figures show that boast is a total sham ...

answer.para: It is not often that I get to agree with the member for Batman, but he is right to assert that we are proud of our waterfront policies. He went on to say at that time:

quote.para: The Government's current policies have taken productivity back to what it was in 1998 ...

answer.para: So I thought we had better have a bit of a look at this. Today sees the release of the December 2000 issue of Waterline, published by the Bureau of Transport Economics, BTE, in my department. It needs to be remembered that John Coombs always said that, in Australia, it would be impossible to get to the target that my colleague the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Peter Reith, indicated of a national average of 25 crane movements an hour. The member for Batman always agrees with his union colleagues, so he believed that we could not get to 25 movements either.

The BTE reports that, in the September quarter, the average crane rate productivity across the five major ports in this country reached a new, record high of 24.9 movements. That has all but achieved the benchmark set by the government of raising container productivity to 25 movements an hour, and it is worth reminding the Houseâand the member for Batman, if he is listeningâof how far we have come in waterfront productivity. In June 1998, the five-port average crane rate was a paltry 18.7 containers an hour. Since then, we have seen a 33 per cent improvement in productivity.

talk.start.para: âHe asks about costs. I will answer that, with great delight, in a moment. Increased crane rates are not the only good news to emerge. The national average ship rate, which is the rate at which a ship is worked by the stevedores, increased in the September quarter to a new high of 38 containers an hour, eclipsing the 1998 ship rate of 24.7 containers an hour. That is an improvement of 54 per cent. In addition to that, there is the issue of reliability. When it comes to your reputationâwhether ships are willing to come here, the rates at which they charge their work out and so forthâreliability is critically important. It shows that we have cracked yet another record. The September quarter berth availability in this country increased one per cent to 95 per cent.

answer.para: In conclusion, the member for Batman has also claimed this government's legacy is `bad management practices' and `low morale' on the waterfront and has suggested `Mr Anderson must be held accountable'. This stands in contrast with the comments of another Labor leaderâsometimes a more reliable figure on these sorts of national issues than the member for Batmanâand that is Premier Bob Carr. Reflecting on the success of the Olympics, Premier Carr said that our waterfront productivity is up with the world's best.

subdebateinfo.title: Liberal Party of Australia: Electoral Practices

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Prime Minister, and it refers to his earlier answer. talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âI am not familiar with the details in relation to Senator Hill. I will take that part of the question on notice, and if I have anything useful to say to the House I shall do so.
âDo you agree with Abbott? Answer the second part.
âOrder! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has asked his question.

âMy question is addressed to the Treasurer. Would the Treasurer inform the House of the contribution sound economic policy makes to improvements in the living standards and prospects of Australian families and small businesses?

talker.name: Costello, Peter, MP
Mr COSTELLO
talker.role: Treasurer

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member for Pearce for her question. I can tell her that the government putting its economic house in order has been very important in improving living standards for the Australian public. Members of the House would perhaps recall that last week was the 10th anniversary of the Labor Party putting the Australian economy into recession. The architect of that recession was boasting as recently as last week about how he had succeeded in producing recession. We remember how the Labor Party went about putting Australia into recession. It took the home mortgage interest rate to 17 per cent and the overdraft rate to 22 per cent, trying to bring on a recession, which it successfully managed to do.

answer.para: Good economic policy has started to produce benefits for the Australian public. Today, home mortgage interest rates are around eight per cent, and you can get introductory home mortgage interest rates of around seven per cent. There are improvements in real wages. Under the coalition, real wages growth has averaged 2.4 per cent per year whereas, under Labor, it was 0.3 per cent. Of course, another one of Labor's great boasts was that they managed to depress real wages, which made things tougher for working people.

Today the unemployment rate is at 6.3 per cent, compared to a peak of 11.2 per cent when the Labor Party put the Australian economy into recessionâa deliberate policy which they put in place some 10 years ago. Since the government has been elected, there have been nearly 800,000 new jobs created in Australia. The secret of improving wages, creating jobs, getting growth and keeping interest rates low has been good economic reform policy, good budget policy and a new taxation system which will take us into the 21st century. We had some evidence about this from the Governor of the Reserve Bank in Wagga last Friday, who, in a very up-beat assessment of the Australian economy, concluded that we have avoided the boom-bust cycle in economic policy and have an excellent outlook for the coming year.

talk.start.para: âI can see that the Labor Party endorses the good economic prospects. But the important point to make is that this was done in spite of Labor. If Labor had had its way, it would have kept the budget in deficit. You fought us every step of the way when we were putting the budget back into balance. If Labor had had its way, Australia would have a 1930s tax system. I do not think we have heard the `r' wordâ

answer.para: Government members interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âNo, not the `rort' word. We have heard that `r' word pass his mouth quite a lot over recent days, but I do not think we have actually heard the `roll-back' word pass the lips of the Leader of the Opposition now since 16 July. Australia waits breathlessly to hear modern Labor's plan for reforming the Australian taxation system. This was a political party which fought us every step of the way. When he was defeated, the Leader of the Opposition said, `Wait till we're elected; we are going to roll back GST.' You never hear the word `roll-back' pass the lips of the Leader of the Opposition for one reason: his stand was always that of the opportunist. There was never any principle in his stand on tax reform. He never had a policy, he has nowhere to go and the best thing that can be said is that he failed in his efforts to stop Australia moving forward.

subdebateinfo.title: Liberal Party of Australia: Electoral Practices

talk.start.para: âMy question is again to the Prime Minister. Do you recall that Jim Elder announced his resignation on Wednesday, 22 November, stating that there have been `issues raised involving my family' and that, on Thursday, 23 November, media reports appeared detailing the false enrolment of family members at the personal, private residence of Jim Elder? Are you aware also that on Friday, 24 November, the very next day, the two persons falsely enrolled at the personal, private residence of Senator Hill changed their electoral address to Sydney? Prime Minister, didn't they remain registered at Senator Hill's residence to be eligible to vote in a bitter factional brawl in Senator Hill's branch at Unley Park and weren't they only taken off the electoral roll because Senator Hill knew that he was about to be caught out?

talker.name: Howard, John, MP
Mr HOWARD
talker.role: Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âI mentioned in answer to the question first asked by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that I would take it on notice. I will do that, and when I have something further to say I will come back to him. As to the first part of the question, I am generally aware of what Mr Elder did and I would take the opportunity of again reminding the House, because there is a clear pattern of statements by the Labor Party to seek to liken a preselection battle inside a political partyâand they go on inside all political partiesâwith criminal behaviour. It is not criminal behaviour to have a preselection battle. It is not even criminal behaviour to recruit people to membership of your party. It is criminal behaviour to do what the member of the Australian Labor Party in Townsville did that led to her conviction and her jailing. That is criminal behaviour, and that is what started all of this going.

answer.para: I think those opposite, in order to somehow or other protect the name of the Australian Labor Party, seek to liken criminal behaviour with competitive behaviour for preselections. People who seek to do that are of course hiding behind their own vulnerability. I think it is worth while again reminding the House that the Leader of the Opposition boasted about how he was going to clean up the preselection system in the Labor Party but, when there were objections at the federal executive, he rolled over in the face of those objections.

talk.start.para: âI would remind the Leader of the Opposition that he would expect me to intervene if the Prime Minister were interjecting and I expect the same courtesy to be shown by him.

âMy question is addressed to the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Would the Deputy Prime Minister inform the House of local government's response to the federal government's $1.2 billion Roads to Recovery Program? Is there any impediment to the benefits of the Roads to Recovery Program being delivered to the general public?

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member for her question and acknowledge that she has been a champion for the people that she represents in terms of their needs for road funding. It is worth touching on some of the more recent responses, since we commented on quite a few last week, to the government's roads package. For example, reporting on the area covered by the electorate of Capricornia, the Morning Bulletinâor the `Bully', as I think it is known up thereâreported:

quote.para: The $22 million additional federal government funding announced for Central Queensland roads yesterday will be welcomed by all road users.

answer.para: It went on to say:

quote.para: Local authorities have hailed the additional spending capacity that yesterday's $1.6 billion national roads package provides.

answer.para: It mentions that Rockhampton, Livingstone, Winton and other shires will each get more than $500,000 additional funding each year. The Livingstone Shire felt compelled to speak out about this and said that they were delighted with the $538,000 a year federal government boost to its roadworks fund for the next four years. Problems such as Browns Lane and a couple of other roads they mentioned have already been named as possible beneficiaries.

To come to an alternate view, it is interesting that in that context the Leader of the Opposition felt it necessary to say something about that part of Queensland as well. He said that road maintenance in Capricornia was ignored in the latest round of federal road funding. He said that there was not any, and that got him a headlineâperhaps a very relevant oneâ`Rural roads were ignored: Beazley'. This is pretty astonishing really when you stop and think that the Australian Labor Party when they were in government were spending around $350 million on local roads. That is in very stark contrast indeed to our Roads to Recovery Program where Commonwealth funding will not only be boosted to record levels but be over double what Labor were putting into local roads. So, while we are increasing expenditure on this vitally important part of the national infrastructure, Labor's cake was getting smaller.

It appears nothing is set to change. You asked in your question about alternative policies or whether there were any impediments to the way forward. Yes, there is one. Yet again, the Leader of the Opposition refused to confirm whether or not he would support the Roads to Recovery Program in Queensland. The reality is that we have made a very substantial commitment to this particularly important piece of national infrastructure. It is quite apparent that the Leader of the Opposition still sees it as trivial and unnecessary. People right across Australia are wondering whether or not they will see any commitment at all to their local roads needs from the Leader of the Opposition.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for Trade. Can the minister confirm that a virtual ban has been placed on Australian companies tendering for projects surrounding the 2004 Olympic Games? Can the minister further confirm that, as a result of this ban, the planned Austrade stand at the Infralympics International Exhibition in Athens in November of this year was cancelled at the last minute? What action is the government taking to overcome this outrageous discrimination by the Athens Olympics authorities, which is likely to cost Australian companies hundreds of millions in export dollars?

talker.name: Vaile, Mark, MP
Mr VAILE
talker.role: Minister for Trade

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Calwell for his question. The issue of tendering for the Athens Olympics is one of great significance to the government. All members would be aware of the great technological and contracting expertise that was accumulated in Australia in the lead-up to the Sydney Olympics. We took the view that we wanted to take commercial advantage of that with regard to the Olympics in Athens in 2004. The issue the member alludes to is that some Australian contractors are being excluded from tendering for projects for the Athens games in 2004 because of a government procurement agreement that our nation is not a party to. We have taken a number of steps in addressing this. On 19 October I wrote to my counterpart, the Greek minister responsible, expressing our extreme concern with regard to the exclusion of Australian firms from that tendering process. I have also written to the EU Trade Commissioner, Pascal Lamy, in the same regard. He has responded in a positive tone in terms of the consultations he is going to have with the Greek authorities on this.

answer.para: We have all seen the departure of the former Olympics minister from the New South Wales government to take up a position elsewhere. We are certainly hopeful that he may be able to exercise some influence as well with his new-found connections in that part of the world with regard to Athens in 2004. For the interest of the member for Calwell, we will continue to actively prosecute, through all avenues that are open to us, the case of Australia's contractors in their getting access to this market and being able to use the expertise. As I say, I have already engaged the assistance of the Trade Commissioner in the EU in this.

subdebateinfo.title: Workplace Relations: Employee Entitlements Support Scheme

talk.start.para: âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, on Friday the Workplace Relations Ministers Council met in Melbourne. Would you inform the House of the outcome of that meeting. Are you aware of any alternative plans being proposed to the federal government's groundbreaking Employee Entitlements Support Scheme?

talker.name: Reith, Peter, MP
Mr REITH
talker.role: Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Macquarie for his question. As I advised the House last week, the groundbreaking Employee Entitlements Support Scheme has now helped over 1,000 workers. It is the only national and viable scheme available to help workers. The government are obviously pleased with the progress we have made in the last 12 months to introduce this extension of the safety net. We did have a meeting of the Workplace Relations Ministers Council. I am sorry to say that the states are still fighting amongst themselves. The states still have no viable alternative. They have no agreed alternative. They are bickering amongst themselves as to the design of any alternative, leaving it more stark, more clear and more obvious than ever that there is only one alternative and that is the scheme that the federal coalition have put in place.

answer.para: We have put this scheme in place against the fierce resistance of the frontbench of the Labor Party, who have not been prepared to support workers in their hour of need. Why? For one simple reason: because a Howard government was prepared to help workers and they do not want to publicly acknowledge their own shortcomings in being prepared to stand up for workers in their hour of need. I was therefore pretty interested to see a report in the Daily Telegraph on Saturday. Usually, the Daily Telegraph is pretty good on these issues. Members will remember this headline back in June: `Reith: workers' friend'.

talk.start.para: âI take the volume of interjections as a mark of respect from the Labor Party for the fact that we are prepared to do something.
âThat may be the view of the minister, but it is not the view of the chair. The minister has the call to respond to the question.
âMr Speaker, I know you support it.
âI do not know that I should be enlisted.

âOne of the reasons the Labor states are not too keen to support this is that the federal leader of the Labor Party is saying to the state Labor parties, `Don't support the Howard government's scheme because it would make us look as if we weren't prepared to help workers.' So I was pretty amazed to read in the Daily Telegraph, this time on Saturday, a heading which says `Beazley buoys workers' hopes'. This apparently followed a meeting between the Leader of the Opposition and the AMWU with the workers at STP. We have a scheme for eligible workers to assist them. What did the Leader of the Opposition say to these workers? The state secretary of the AMWU said:

quote.para: Mr Beazley has indicated quite clearly to us that he will go after this lot in parliament.

answer.para: Rather than standing up for workers, rather than saying to workers, `We will help you,' the fact of the matter is that the Leader of the Opposition, the leader of the Labor Party, is using every ounce of influence he has to prevent these workers getting some help. You are prepared to say, `Oh yeah, I'm full of sympathy,' when you have got the workers there, but you are not prepared to honestly say to them that, when you are in the parliament, you and your lot do all that you possibly can to prevent these workers being assisted. If you take one of the last payments made to some workers in New South Wales, they got just under 40 per cent under our scheme. They would have got nearly 80 per cent if the Labor Party in New South Wales were prepared to support them.

It is gross hypocrisy for the Leader of the Opposition to be saying to workers, `I'd like to help you,' but when he is here in Canberra to do everything he possibly can to make sure they do not get any help. This is a disgrace for the Labor Party. They are not prepared to support the coalition and match us on a dollar for dollar basis. That is what the Labor Party ought to do. You may not like our scheme, but it is no good saying to these workers that you are prepared to help them. The fact is that you are not prepared to help them and, worse still, you are working against the interests of workers in their hour of need. You ought to be ashamed of yourselves.

subdebateinfo.title: Liberal Party of Australia: Electoral Practices

talk.start.para: âMy question is to the Minister for Sport and Tourism. I refer to the minister's obligations under the Prime Minister's code of conduct, specifically that section requiring ministers to be honest in their public dealings and not intentionally mislead the public or undermine public confidence in the government.
âThe Deputy Leader of the Opposition will come to his question.

âHe's been reading the Australian.

Miss JACKIE KELLY
talker.role: Minister for Sport and Tourism and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

talk.start.para: âThat is right: he obviously has been up early this morning reading the Australian.
âThe minister will come to the question.

âIt is incumbent on the Labor Party to come in here and uphold the high standards of this parliament. But it appears to me that, every time they are wailing in the doodoo, they tend to thrash around and splash it right around this chamber, `Let's fling it around and see if it will stick elsewhere.' âMy question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Would the minister inform the House about the importance of the schools funding legislation and its early passage through this parliament? What is causing the delay in the passage of this legislation?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member for Forde for her question. The schools legislation currently in the Senateâa $22 billion billâis the biggest investment in schooling ever by a federal government. It greatly increases funding for both government and non-government schools. Members of this House should be aware that Commonwealth funding for all schools dries up on 31 December unless the Senate passes the legislation this session. quote.para: The States Grants legislation puts in place Commonwealth funding for Australian school students for 2001-2004. It should be passed without further delay so that all schools can adequately plan for 2001.

answer.para: The Most Reverend R.H. Goodhew, in a letter to the Prime Minister on 22 November, said:

talk.start.para: âFor most farmers, the past year has been one of considerable achievement. A number of new records have been broken in relation to farm exports. In fact, in each of the last three months agricultural exports have exceeded the previous record. Wool exports are up by 31 per cent, and I hope that that demonstrates a beginning of a change of fortune for this great Australian industry. There have been significant increases in wine exports. Our dairy producers continue to expand their share of world markets. Our exports of fresh horticultural produce have grown yet again; in fact, they are up 30 per cent over the last five years. answer.para: But as the honourable member mentioned in his question, there are some cases where farmers have had a difficult year, where problems have arisen, and this government has responded to those concerns. We have been ready to assist farmers who are facing difficulties and have been prepared to devote substantial resources to help them through those difficult times. They have had a sympathetic government in Canberra which has been prepared to listen. Again, as the honourable member referred to in his question, often they have had to come to Canberra because their states have failed to take the action that would normally be expected of a caring state government. An example is the sugar industry, which I referred to last week, where the federal government has provided a substantial package of supportâin fact, an $83 million package, levering something like $400 million worth of loan assistance. I mentioned last week that the state government also put up a package in Queensland and they had only three applicants, none of whom had yet been approved. Mr Palaszczuk, the state minister, has taken me to task and told me that he now has five applications. I gather he has still not spent a single cent. So the Queensland government's response to the sugar industry crisis was, at best, tokenism and really a sham.

When it came to the dairy industry, again the states that acted to deregulate the industryâthe three states that abolished quotas that were worth tens of thousands of dollars for many farmersârefused to pay any compensation. They refused to do anything. The Commonwealth government facilitated a $1.74 billion restructuring package to assist the industry through these difficult times. The states did absolutely nothing, with the exception of Western Australia. Only the coalition government in Western Australia have provided any support for their dairy farmers. New South Wales and Queensland stripped the quotas away at great cost and provided absolutely nothing. It is to their shame that they have refused to do anything to support their dairy farmers. I think it is appalling that weâ

talk.start.para: âNot a cent of federal money.
âBut there is none of your money in the $1.7 billion.

âIt seems as though those on the other side are defending the state governments for ripping away the value of the quota. Are you defending this action, member for Corio? You are shameful. In addition, we have reformed the tax system, we have lifted the wholesale sales tax from farm costs and we have lowered income tax for virtually all farmers. We have also lowered the fuel tax for all farmers. All farmers in Australia will be paying less fuel tax this year than for very many years as a result of the action of this government in relation to dealing with farm cost issues. The Farm HelpSupporting Families through Change program helps those individual producers who are facing difficulty. It helps them through the difficult times, puts bread on the table and of course, if need be, supports them with retraining and assistance out of the industry. So this is a government that cares and has been prepared to respond in those circumstances where difficulties are being faced, in stark contrast to state governments which have walked away from their responsibilities.

âMy question is address to the Minister for Trade. Would the minister inform the House how his forthcoming visit to Malaysia will strengthen commercial links with that country?

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member for Hindmarsh for her question. Later on this week, I will be participating in the annual joint trade commission meeting with my Malaysian counterparts in Kuala Lumpur. I will also be accompanied by the National President of the Australia-Malaysia Business Council, Alexander Gosling. The objects of the exercise are to continue the healthy trade relationship that we currently enjoy between our two countries on a bilateral basis and also to continue the pragmatic approach that our government is taking to trade policy, particularly within the Asia-Pacific region where we are seeing significant growth again in our exports to that region and, of course, Malaysia is no exception.

answer.para: Two-way trade in goods and services for the 1999-2000 financial year with Malaysia stood at $7.35 billion. In the last 12 months, our exports to Malaysia have increased by 15 per cent. And that is across all sectors, which I am sure all members will be interested to hear, particularly the member for Hindmarsh because one industry in her electorate has just secured a new $10 million contract to supply automotive parts to Malaysia's national car manufacturer, Proton. The company, Castalloy, will be supplying 75,000 cylinder heads a year to the Malaysian automotive industry, and that is an indication of the benefits that can flow from market openings and tariff reform, particularly in relation to the markets into which Australia exports. That will be good news for the people in that seat in Adelaide who work in the automotive industry. As we all know, Australia's automotive industry is now one of our great export performers, exporting almost $4 billion worth of cars and automotive components.

Other notable companies that are doing well in the Malaysian marketplace include Note Printing Australia. Malaysia will soon be using plastic polymer banknotes made with technology developed in Australia by Note Printing Australia. We are opening up the services market to Australian companies in Malaysia. Recently the Australian law firm, Freehill, Hollingdale and Page, was appointed to advise Malaysia's electricity utility on the restructuring of the electricity market.

One of Australia's fastest growing export sectors is the services sector. An integral part of that is the education area. At the moment, Malaysia has 18,000 students studying in Australia, which is quite significant, not just in an economic sense by also in the overall bilateral relationship. âMy question is addressed to the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts.
