Mr McGAURAN
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: âI thank the honourable member for New England for his question. I know the time, effort and work that he has invested in extending the telecommunications network throughout his electorateâas so many members, at least on this side of the House, have done.

answer.para: Since this government came to office in 1996, it has had a clear vision of what it wants to achieve in this area of communications. Firstly, we want to introduce a competitive market that will provide an array of products and services at a more affordable price and in a more efficient way; secondly, we want to have an innovative regulatory regime that protects the interests of consumers and the public; and, thirdly, we want to target programs that will fund the roll-out of telecommunications in areas where there is market failure.

Since 1997, when the area was opened to full competition, more than 50 carrier licences have been issued, and a whole range of new products and services is now available to Australian families, businesses and consumers. The effects of this competitive market are being seen in the prices. Earlier this year the ACCC reported that the prices of local, national long distance, international and mobile calls had fallen. All of this is underpinned by the regulatory regime, including the customer service guarantee. The CSG, which was introduced by the coalition government, has been strengthened recently. It imposes tighter requirements on carriers for the provision of services and the repair of faults. It also requires the automatic payment of CSG compensation by a carrier when service standards are breached. We have other consumer regulatory safeguards, such as the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman and the universal service obligation, to provide that protection. Consistent with its election commitment, the government has looked at ways of improving the delivery of the universal service obligation, and we now have a contestable provision for the universal service provision.

As to targeted funding, there is a whole range of programs, such as Networking the Nation and the Telstra social bonus, totalling some $1 billion. These programs include building additional rural networks, extended mobile phone coverage on highways, untimed local calls in extended zones, the extension of SBS funding, television blackspot funding, local government fund, building IT strengths, remote and isolated islands fund, Internet access fund and a range of other programs designed to assist people who are in a disadvantaged location or positionâespecially in rural and regional Australia. So, while we have a clear vision and a determination to bring this about, we are still waiting for the Labor Party to articulate any serious or credible telecommunications policyâparticularly in the important area of regional and rural telecommunications service.

âI move:

motion.para: That this House:

(1) expresses its dismay at the ongoing violence and incitement to violence in the Middle East and calls on both sides to immediately stop all violent acts and for the restoration of calm to the region;

(2) takes note of the far-reaching and courageous proposals made by Israel's Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, at Camp David and its disappointment that this historic opportunity was not successfully seized by all parties to the peace process;
(3) calls on all partners to resume negotiations without the threat of violence and without the premature announcement of unilateral declarations;

(4) expresses its grief for the innocent lives lost on both sides and condemns the unacceptable inclusion of children in violent activities on the front line and expresses the hope that violence will be stopped in accordance with the Sharm el-Sheik agreement;
(5) hopes that the conflict will be resolved in the framework of agreement and compromise;
(6) calls on the leadership of the Israeli and Palestinian people to restore trust and confidence in order to pave the way for the resumption of peace negotiations;

(7) calls on all countries surrounding the conflict between Israel and the Palestinian territories to ensure their sovereign territory not be used to promote aggression into an already turbulent area; and
(8) believes that peaceful coexistence is the only option for both Israelis and Palestinians now and into the future.

speech.para: The ongoing conflict and incitement of violence and retaliation we are witnessing in Gaza and the West Bank and Israel is a devastating setback in the long road to peace in the Middle East. It is devastating on two levels. The first is the senseless violence and loss of life which has resulted from the vicious circle of incitement and retaliation and the failure of the Palestinian leadership to take all steps to pacify their supporters. The second is the enormous damage done to prospects of achieving a lasting peace. I sincerely hope that every member of this House can agree that the first priority is for the violence and bloodshed to stop and for negotiations to resume. It is the only way to salvage any prospect of a lasting peace in the Middle East.

Present developments in Israel and the West Bank and Gaza over recent weeks resemble a tragic paradox. At the Camp David summit, Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak offered the most generous, far reaching and indeed unprecedented concessions to Yasser Arafat and the Palestinian National Authority. The proposal has, however, elicited the most violent and militant reaction from Palestinians since the beginning of the peace process. It is fundamentally disappointing that such a historic and progressive opportunity was not successfully seized upon by all parties involved. Since that time, the `peace partnership' that has been evident in recent years has broken down to the extent that the incitement and retaliation of teenage stone-throwers and armed militia now represent the progress of the Middle East peace process. The result has been the loss of innocent lives on the front line, the death of children and the ever diverging possibility of future agreement. Such tragic consequences following the rejection of the Barak offer are all the more distressing considering that the generous terms set out in the proposal came exceedingly close to meeting stated Palestinian demands. Indeed, on the strength of this a resolution seemed imminent.

The significance of Ehud Barak's steps should not be underestimated. The position presently taken by Israel has proved to be the most accommodating to date, to the extent that no such concessions would have seemed conceivable to previous Israeli prime ministers. The proposal included offering the establishment of a Palestinian state in all of Gaza and almost all of the West Bank, Palestinian sovereignty in the great majority of Arab areas in East Jerusalem and an arrangement of joint control over the remaining land. A further offer included vacant land within Israel's 1948 borders as compensation for the continued Israeli control of heavily Jewish portions of the West Bank.

That the proposal has resulted in both violence and the breakdown of agreement and compromise helps no-one. Despite declining the Israeli proposal, it seems the Palestinian leadership provided no substitute proposal nor even an indication of what would presently be acceptable to the Palestinians. Quite apart from the tragically needless waste of life and resources on both sides, the recent combined efforts of both parties have cast a grave shadow over the peace process, damaging the prospects of a lasting peace. It is essential that the leadership of the Israeli and Palestinian people take swift action to restore trust and confidence in the peace process. Once re-established, such trust will pave the way for the resumption of peace negotiations in a framework of agreement and compromise. Encouragingly, and despite provocation, Israel has been forthcoming in offering a series of confidence building measures if the campaign of sniping, bombing and violence is called off. These measures include the reopening of crossings, a pulling back of forces and the reopening of the Gaza airport. It is by the extension of such goodwill that a framework for peaceful coexistence can develop. It is clear that such coexistence is the only acceptable outcome of any Palestinian-Israeli agreement, now and in the future.

Importantly, Israel's likely election in the coming months does not change the fundamental need for an end to violence. Indeed, it highlights the urgency for renewed negotiations and a development of confidence in the Israeli state. It is apparent that the Israeli electoral culture and Ehud Barak's internal political difficulties have not inhibited his enthusiasm and commitment in pursuing the peace process. It is also clear from prominent Jewish sources inside and outside Israel that he would most likely have received the backing of both parliament and the electorate had Yasser Arafat agreed to the Israeli concessions at Camp David last July. Both Palestinians and Israelis, in their quest for rights and sovereignty, have a fundamental interest in making peace and immediately avoiding intense and widespread conflict. This is particularly so considering that in this particular period, unlike any other in the modern history of the Middle East, the influence of external world powers upon the outcome is at its lowest. For the first time since Napoleon Bonaparte's conquest of Palestine, Palestinians and Israelis have the opportunity to settle their own affairs and build upon the confidence and security which such an outcome would bring. The only way to overcome the devastating setback to the peace process, to put an end to incitement, violence, the senseless loss of life and the killing of children is for both aggressors to re-enter the Middle East peace process. This must be done with a spirit of cooperation and conciliation, in recognition that peaceful coexistence is the only option available for both Israelis and Palestinians.

Can I also thank members of both sides of the House for the bipartisan way in which they have approached the serious questions facing the Middle East peace process in the last few months. On a number of occasions the Jewish community here in Australia have brought speakers, academics and others to Parliament House to meet with members of both the coalition and the opposition, and the Australia-Israel Parliamentary Friendship Group, chaired by me and with the member for Melbourne Ports as secretary, have worked tirelessly to try to include as many coalition and opposition members as possible in our meetings to spread the opportunity for information to each of the members of the parliament.

One of the most obvious aspects of the current situation is that the media have not reported the goings-on in the Middle East in such a way as to provide us with the facts surrounding much of the situation facing the Middle East. There are countless examples. I think of one particularly: the photograph published in, I think, the Melbourne Herald Sun of a so-called Palestinian boy, bloodied and beaten, being stood over by an Israeli soldier. As it turned out, in fact the photograph was of a Jewish boy in Jerusalem who had been beaten up by a mob of angry Palestinians, and the Israeli soldier had come to the boy's rescue. But it highlights the role the media plays in the information that is sent out to the public. In that case the photograph, I think, was on page 1 or page 3 of the Herald Sun, but the retraction was, as usual, a small piece somewhere back in the newspaper.

I also draw attention to the Australian'scoverage of the Middle East process. The way they have reported it on occasions almost suggests that actions taken by the Israeli state were designed to inflame passions amongst Palestinians. I think it has been obvious from the efforts being made by Ehud Barak and his government that the last thing they would want to do is inflame passions amongst the Palestinian leadership, and that is why they made the concessions that they did at the Camp David summit which resulted in a failure on the part of both to agree, and they then attended the Sharm el-Sheik discussions to try to bring an end to the violence. One thing is for certain: I think all members of the House wish to see a speedy conclusion to the problems facing the Middle East and the settling down and the stability that will lead to a peaceful, happy coexistence between both Israelis and Palestinians in that part of the world.

talk.start.para: âI second the motion. How far we seem from those days when Mr Rabin, the late Prime Minister of Israel, shook hands with his long-time adversary, Mr Yasser Arafat, the President of the Palestinian National Authority in the rose garden at the White House, Washington. The last few weeks are tragic for all those around the world who follow events in that part of the world where our civilisations began. The current situation is that we have, apparently, the two sides as intractably apart as ever before. At the end of the Cold War we saw an apparent solution to the problems in South Africa and Ireland, and lots of people around the world were very pleased to observe that the Middle East seemed to be part of this process where Cold War tensions no longer heightened the conflicts in those parts of the world where conflict was very high.

speech.para: The recent historical background to the last few weeks is, I think, worth examining. The current Israeli government is a Labour government led by Mr Ehud Barak. Mr Barak in his election program proposed and promised a number of radical measures for achieving peace. One of them was the unilateral withdrawal from Lebanon that was completed about halfway through this year. That withdrawal was designed to solve the problem of the people in south Lebanon and northern Israel being involved in constant conflict. That was achievedânot with the greatest of grace, but it did happen. One of Mr Barak's chess pieces was moved in the direction of peace.

The second offer came with negotiations that American President Clinton had with the then and now the late President of Syria, Hafez al-Assad. Those negotiations arose following the election of the Barak government and were designed to see a withdrawal of the Israelis from the entire Golan Heights. I might say that many Australian parliamentarians who visited that area over the decades since it was the scene of conflict in the 1973 war and the 1967 war remarked on the generosityâsome people would say the wisdomâof Mr Barak in making that offer. It was an offer which anyone who has stood in the very small spaces we are talking about and looked down into the valley of Galilee below understands is a big risk for peace. That was the second chess peace that was offered but was unfortunately not pursued by Mr Assad.

The next and most important part of this saga was referred to by the member for Sturt. That was the offer in those long days of negotiation between Mr Arafat and Prime Minister Barak at the American President's retreat at Camp David. The extent of that offer, to people who follow in detail the Middle East, was very surprising. As the member for Sturt said, it involved an independent Palestinian state alongside Israel, 95 per cent of the territories, all of Arab East Jerusalem, shared sovereignty over the holy sites in Jerusalem, and an exchange of territory for the remaining five, six or seven per cent between Israel proper and those heavily populated areas of the West Bank that were contiguous with Israel but were heavily populated by Israeli Jews.

I note, by the way, that the Israeli Arabs, who are proposed to be part of this exchange of territory, are not very happy with this idea. Despite their support for the Palestinian Arabs and their concerns about the violence in the territories and the deaths in the recent conflict, they are not enamoured of the idea of being part of any population or land transfer.

Mr Arafat, for reasons that are best understood by him, did not accept this most comprehensive offer ever made. If this House, as a responsible House, is seeking to add to the responsible discussion of this troubled part of the world in seeking political solutions, it ought to focus on the kinds of political solutions that it might help bring about. The American President, who presided over these discussions, Mr Clinton, was very disappointed. The Chairman of the Palestinian Authority, Mr Arafat, proceeded on an international visit where, to his surprise, the leaders of both France and Russiaâtraditionally supporters of the Palestiniansâinformed him that the Palestinians should accept the deal and that they would not support a unilateral declaration of a Palestinian state, the alternative for which Mr Arafat was hoping to get their support.

Very interestingly for me, the Labor Party national conference took place around this time, and those participating in the Labor Party conferenceâwho have previously held different points of view on the Middle Eastâtook a unanimous view and did not support unilateral declarations. We supported negotiation through peaceful discussions between the parties. Since those attempts at getting international support for a unilateral declaration of a Palestinian state, there has been an awful messâthe death of many innocent people on both sides in past months. Like any human, when I saw the picture of the boy who was shot at the Netzarim crossroads, my emotions were stirred. The shooting was a tragedy. That children are being involved in this kind of conflict is something all of us regret. I later saw an aerial photograph of crossfire taking place between a Palestinian police station and an Israeli strong point. This fact is neither here nor there: the tragedy of the boy is not relieved by the circumstances in which he died.

As responsible friends of both peoples in the areaâand Australia has a very honourable record in helping to achieve a just and peaceful solution to the conflict over thereâwe ought to be focusing on the political solutions to this conflict. Any examination of the peace plan as advanced by Camp David ought to lead this House to supporting it, as the motion moved by the member for Sturt outlines. It is regrettable that, in the last few days, the Palestinian Legislative Council has voted for a continuation of the intifada, or the uprising or violence in the territories. A slightly encouraging aspect is that it has also voted for the continuation of negotiations. I do not think both can occur at the same time. I hope Mr Barak's gamble on calling early elections will be supported by the Israeli population. He has offered about as much as I think any Israeli leader has ever offered in the past or will offer. I hope that the measures that he has taken to resume negotiations with the Palestinians bear fruit and that the Israeli population, in an election, support those peace moves. It is in the hands of the people who live in the area, through peaceful negotiations.

talk.start.para: âI wish to support the motion moved by the honourable member for Sturt. In the last few months, we have witnessed an outbreak of violence in the Middle East. This violence has led to the death and injury of many innocent Palestinian and Israeli men, women and children. The loss and suffering of both sides in this conflict is deeply felt by this parliament. The tragedy is compounded by the fact that the Middle East peace process seems to have all but collapsed. The diplomatic triumph that brought with it great hope and potential reward today lies all but abandoned.

speech.para: Since his election victory last year, Israel's Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, has dedicated his administration to securing peace for Israel. In the last year, the government of Israel has withdrawn Israeli forces from Lebanon and has offered Syria a peace proposal that included all of the Golan Heights. To the Palestinians, the Israeli government offered a peace settlement at Camp David that was both generous and brave. A fortnight ago, our Prime Minister, during his address to the annual dinner of the Australia/Israel and Jewish Affairs Council expressed the Australian government's view on that peace proposal when he said:

quote.para: I do not believe that any Prime Minister of Israel could have offered more than did Ehud Barak at Camp David. It was an offer that should have been accepted and it is tragic in the extreme that it has not been accepted.

speech.para: Since the Palestinian Authority's refusal of Israel's offer, we have watched as talk of peace by Yasser Arafat and other Palestinian leaders has been replaced by the rhetoric of violence and conflict. When the peace process commenced in 1993, the Chairman of the PLO renounced violence. At that time, he stated:

quote.para: ... the PLO renounces the use of terrorism and other acts of violence, and will assume responsibility over all PLO elements and personnel in order to assure their compliance.

speech.para: In recent months, despite repeated requests and calls from the international community and Israel, the Palestinian leadership has done little to call for an end to violence. It is also disturbing that Yasser Arafat chose to release from jail many known terrorists from various extremist organisations. As a consequence, we are now witnessing the return of terrorist bombings of buses and public places in Israel and an escalation of civilian deaths.

The Palestinian people have a legitimate aspiration to realise their own state. We recognise and support that aspiration. But the most effective vehicle to deliver that outcome is the peace process. Since the signing of the Declaration of Principles, the peace process has brought the Palestinian people closer to nationhood and delivered more tangible benefits than at any time in the last half century. Today, more than 97 per cent of the Palestinian population live under Palestinian rule. The Palestinian Authority controls more than 40 per cent of the West Bank and Gaza. Since the Oslo agreement, the Palestinian people have also been the recipients of huge capital inflows and aid contributions from the international community.

Australia is a strong friend and a staunch ally of the state of Israel and the people of Israel. There are few nations in the world which have overcome so much, fought so hard and sacrificed so many of their sons and daughters in the search for peace. Five million people in a sliver of land that would fit into Victoria 10 times continue to live with the daily reality that they face hostile neighbours still intent on their destruction. Yet, in a nation where every square mile carries with it serious strategic consequences, Israel continues to propose peace initiatives and concessions that increase her strategic vulnerability. I think we can all appreciate the frustration felt by many in Israel that, after having taken great risks in the search for peace, they are today faced with the same insecurity and violence that beset their nation before the peace process commenced. As Israel goes to the polls in a new election, it is my hope that, despite the current climate, her people continue to search for a renewed path to peace. I commend the motion to the House.

talk.start.para: âIn speaking in support of the member for Sturt's motion, I join my colleague the member for Melbourne Ports and other members in supporting peaceful negotiation rather than force or violence as a resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The Australian Labor Party has a long and honourable record of supporting both Arab and Jewish rights in that part of the world. Australia was involved in the original decision to partition Palestine into an Arab-Palestinian state and the Jewish state of Israel. That fair partitioning is the underlying basis for this motion. Dr Evatt, as chairman of the UN General Assembly, saw the partition of Palestine, which was and is the wise and right manner in which this matter should be and might be resolved. Like King Solomon, we have to support the parties who are willing to make a political compromise, not the party that wants to have everything.

speech.para: At our ALP national conference, we called on all parties to not make unilateral declarations that would pre-empt negotiation. Peace can come only as a result of negotiation between the parties, not from us. Mr Arafat was told the same by the governments of Russia and France, which have been traditional supporters of the Palestinian cause. It is obvious that this is an emotional topic, with children being captured on television dying in crossfire. We also see mobs desecrating religious sites and lynching individuals. In Australia, we should be contributing to a political solution, not to emotional appeals on one side or the other.

In my contribution, I do not really want to talk about who is right and who is wrong, because in these matters that is a fine line to distinguish. I do want to pick up on a point about the media and about the citing of individual cases. The media has portrayed at times very graphic sights and has, I believe, with those images taken one side or the other and sometimes both. I do not believe that these grim pictures and people witnessing these events actually help the cause; rather, they destroy the negotiations and the potential for peace. In the very recent past, we have seen people like President Clinton with Ehud Barak and Yasser Arafat having discussions, having negotiations and genuinely working towards what might be a peaceful solution in the Middle East.

The battle between the Israelis and the Palestinians has been going on for many years, and it is one that obviously does not have an easy solution and cannot be easily resolved by combined negotiations, but I think negotiations are the only way that it can be resolved. At some point, both sides must sit down and both sides must give and take. There was just recently some of that giving and some of that taking, and I think Ehud Barak has made some generous concessions in working towards what might be a solution. At the end of the day, the negotiations will have to come to the point where they actually find what will be the area of Palestine or a Palestinian state. As the member for Kooyong rightly pointed out, the Palestians do deserve their own state, they do deserve to have their own territory and they do deserve to be the masters of their own destiny. At some stage, the two must come together to find where that point is.

I will quickly refer to point 3 of the motion moved by the member for Sturt. It `calls on all partners to resume negotiations without the threat of violence and without the premature announcement of unilateral declarations'. For these negotiations to continue, they must continue in peace. Violence must end. Violence is not benefiting one side or the other; it is only ensuring more graphic pictures in the media. I would also like to highlight point 5 of the motion, which says the House `hopes that the conflict will be resolved in the framework of agreement and compromise'. I would also like to highlight point 7, which `calls on all countries surrounding the conflict between Israel and the Palestinian territories to ensure their sovereign territory not be used to promote aggression'. Other countries should not contribute to the violence and the current problems in the Middle East.

There is one good thing we are doing through this parliament, and that is the Australia-Israel Friendship Group. It is a good group chaired by the member for Sturt and deputy chaired by the member for Melbourne Ports. I am a member of that friendship group and am glad to be. I fully support the good work being done here in support of the peace negotiations and in support of both sides finding a resolution. All we can do in this place is lend our support and offer any advice and assistance that we can to both parties and hope that, in the very near future, a solution is found and peace is brought to the Middle East.

subdebateinfo.title: HMAS Armidale: Ordinary Seaman Teddy Sheean

talk.start.para: âI move:

motion.para: That this House:
(1) recognises the extraordinary deeds of Ordinary Seaman Teddy Sheean and his crew mates upon the sinking of HMAS Armidale on 1 December 1942 off the Timor coast;
(2) implores the government to award a posthumous Victoria Cross of Australia to Ordinary Seaman Teddy Sheean to properly recognise his courageous deeds on 1 December 1942; and

(3) encourages the government to establish a mechanism to address outstanding issues and anomalies in the military honours system such as recognising the courageous deeds of people such as Ordinary Seaman Teddy Sheean on 1 December 1942.

speech.para: Mr Deputy Speaker, picture if you will a fatally stricken warship under intense fire from enemy aircraft. Upon the order to abandon ship, those crew who survived the initial explosions fling themselves into the sea to escape the fiery inferno that is their ship. Unfortunately, in the sea they are gunned down by those enemy planes. Many are seriously wounded or lose their lives. As their ship quickly sinks about them, one of their colleagues returns to his anti-aircraft gun to engage the enemy, distracting the fighter planes from their murderous intent. In the certain knowledge that his action will lead to his death and while mortally wounded, the sailor literally goes down with his ship with his guns blazing. His valour and self-sacrifice helped save many of his colleagues battling to survive in the sea around him.

To the best of my knowledge, what I have described is historically accurate and happened at least twice in World War II. In the first instance the courageous sailor was Leading Seaman Jack Mantle of the Royal Navy, who, although mortally wounded, kept firing his gun right to the end when a swarm of Nazi stuka dive bombers attacked HMS Foylebank at Portland off the south coast of England in July 1940. The second was the action of Ordinary Seaman Teddy Sheean, Royal Australian Navy, now famously and poignantly captured on canvas at the National War Memorial in Canberra.

I am speaking of the tragic yet heroic events surrounding the sinking of the corvette HMAS Armidale on 1 December 1942 off the coast of Timor, some 58 years ago. Rightly and fittingly, Jack Mantle RN was posthumously awarded the Victoria Cross for his remarkable gallantry. On the other hand, Teddy Sheean RAN only received a mention in dispatches. Why? Why is it that, unlike the RAAF and the AIF, no member of the Royal Australian Navy has been awarded the Victoria Cross? Why is it that almost identical acts of valour are not accorded the same military honours?

I can cite further instances of Captain Fogarty Fegan of the Royal Navy, who was awarded the VC for his courageous diversionary action in HMS Jervis Bay in November 1940 in the face of fatal fire from the German battleship the Admiral Von Scheer, and Lieutenant Commander Robert Rankin of the Royal Australian Navy, who did a similar act on 4 March 1942. Rankin courageously sailed his command, HMAS Yarra, into a Japanese squadron of three cruisers and two destroyers south of Java. Robert Rankin was not even mentioned in dispatches. Why? I am not trying to create a them and us argument by citing these instances. I am trying to understand why, in the light of verifiable evidence, we as a nation with the means at our disposal do not correct these wrongs, whether they be administrative, personal or as a result of outright bureaucratic pig-headedness.

I have told this remarkable story of 19-year-old Teddy Sheean before in this House. Indeed, I am just one of many who have heard his story, been inspired by his selfless act and joined the crusadeâfor that is what it isâto have him posthumously awarded the highest military honour this nation can bestow on one of its own, the Victoria Cross. The Victoria Cross for Australia was established as part of the Australian system of honours and awards on 15 January 1991. According to Michael Shoebridge, Defence Adviser to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the Hon. Bruce Scott, on 25 October 1999, the Victoria Cross `accords recognition to persons who perform acts of the most conspicuous gallantry, acts of valour or self-sacrifice, or display extreme devotion to duty in the presence of the enemy'. Mr Shoebridge goes on to say:

quote.para: Awards are made with the approval of the Queen by an instrument signed by the Governor-General on the recommendation of the Minister for Defence.

speech.para: It was not always like that and I believe this is perhaps one reason why Teddy Sheean's case was never really argued.

Mr John Bradford of Adelaide, author of In The Highest Traditions, in correspondence with me on this issue pointed out that much of the confusion and angst surrounding Sheean's case stems from the fact that `mentioned in dispatches' was the lowest grade of award for gallantry that could be awarded posthumously. The only other award was the Victoria Cross. There was no in between. Sheean's case relied heavily on the report of proceedings provided by his commanding officer to the board of inquiry following Armidale's loss. Unfortunately, Sheean's conspicuous gallantry was only briefly recorded by his CO. The process of recommending awards for gallantry in the Royal Australian Navy, as opposed to the Royal Navy, is a story of comparative discriminationâdiscrimination it should be pointed out which did not exist for the AIF or the RAAF.

In his search for justice for Teddy Sheean, Frank Walker, author of HMAS Armidale: The Ship That Had To Die, has pointed to the inadequacy and absurdity of the award system as related to the RAN. Unlike the AIF and the RAAF where awards were decided by Australians in Australia, RAN awards were not. The Australian Commonwealth Naval Board, headed by a seconded RN officer, had to send recommendations to the Admiralty in London where the awards and honours committee made the decision. Furthermore, Walker points out that commanding officers of RN ships were entitled to recommend sailors for certain awards but the captains of Royal Australian Navy ships were instructed that `the nature of the award is not to be suggested'. It is Walker's and others' contention that it was impossible for Australian offices to recommend Australian sailors for a VC.

The trail of administrative misadventure on this issue has lingered on long after these events, even up to the present. Mr Bradford points out that a month after the Armidale was lost a royal warrant gave dominion governments the authority to make recommendations for VC awards. He writes:

quote.para: Surprisingly, there is nothing to suggest our Government ever exercised these powers throughout the rest of the warâand certainly not on Sheean's behalf, even though the Government was in possession of both the findings of the Board of Inquiry into the loss of the Armidale and her final Report of Proceedings.

speech.para: What can we do today? Time is passing, and so too are those who directly witnessed the deeds of Teddy Sheean on 1 December 1942. Teddy's sister, Ivy Hayes, was 91 in November and his brother Bert is 87. If justice is to be done, it must be done soon. It would seem that bureaucratic stonewalling and deadlines stand in the way. In a letter dated 25 October 1999âfull of bureaucratic speak, I would addâSenior Defence Adviser to Minister Bruce Scott, Mr Michael Shoebridge, pointed out that the End of War List for World War II has been completed, and because Teddy Sheean was not recommended prior to this he therefore stands ineligible. I quote:

quote.para: It is not practical for better judgements about individual actions or merit to be made at this time than were made by contemporary authorities who had direct access to eye witness reports and could test evidence when it was fresh.

speech.para: The adviser recognises the fact that Sheean should have been awarded `a gallantry award of a higher stature' but not now in hindsight. The danger? According to the adviser:

quote.para: Creating a precedent for unwanted and perhaps divisive comparisons between these `hindsight-awards' and those recommended and granted at the time.

speech.para: In a remarkably condescending paragraph, the adviser, again stressing the great courage of Sheean, writes:

quote.para: ... the reality of military life under operational conditions is that men and women enter life threatening situations as an integral part of their duty. That some of those individuals are singled out for gallantry awards is fitting; but again, the reality is that many who do perform acts of great courage are never recognised.

speech.para: Clearly the only thing stopping Teddy Sheean receiving this country's highest military honour for bravery is an unwillingness to tamper with a bureaucratic filing process; an unwillingnessâdespite the overwhelming public evidence and desire to do the right thingâto reopen the End of War List. Unlike the adviser's steely conclusion, the reality should be that some of those who did perform acts of great courage can still have these recognised.

In the spirit of the Centenary of Federation, I am calling on the government to reopen the End of War List to deal with anomalies and issues related to the awarding of military honours in cases such as Teddy Sheean. I know there are others. We should not shy away from this. After all, I am talking about a nation honouring one of its nationals, one of its own. If it does not fit the bureaucratic mould, so what? I am certain that if this attitude prevailed in 1901 we would not have a federation at all.
An Armidale survivor, Mr Roy Cleland, goes to his local pub and buys two glasses of beer on 1 December each yearâone for himself and one is left. He wrote:

quote.para: Sometimes when I am leaving, the barmaid will ask me about the other glass, and I tell her: `My mates will be along to take care of that.'

speech.para: Only nine survivors of the Armidale exist today, but many more mates exist to take up their causeâthat is, to commemorate each other's courage and to recognise this in the name of them all through the posthumous award of the Victoria Cross to Ordinary Seaman Teddy Sheean RAN. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)âIs the motion seconded?
âI second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

âI rise today to very strongly support the member for Braddon in his bringing of this issue to the attention of the House. I would certainly like to pledge my support for all we over here can do to take the issue to the appropriate minister to make sure that that which is expressed in the motion happens. There is absolutely no doubt in my mind that Edward Sheeanâ`Teddy' Sheean as he was knownâdeserves to be posthumously awarded the Victoria Cross for his outstanding bravery under fire during the Second World War. As we have heard on a number of occasions from the member for Braddon, while Teddy Sheean was born at Barrington in Tasmania on 28 December 1923, there is a strong and enduring link with the city of Armidale in my electorate of New England. I have mixed emotions whenever I reflect on the actions of Teddy Sheean during one of the most important times in our history as a nation, particularly as we have just celebrated the 58th anniversary of the sinking of the Armidale, for which there was a church service in Armidale, in the middle of my electorate. My emotions are mixed, because my youngest son is about the same age as was Teddy when Teddy enlisted in the Royal Australian Navy on 21 April 1941 at just 17 years of age.

speech.para: He was initially attached to HMAS Derwent at the naval depot at Hobart. Whilst attached to Derwent, he also served on board the auxilliary minesweeper, HMAS Coombar. On his 18th birthday, he joined HMAS Cerberus at Westernport, Victoria, to undertake further training. From Cerberus he was posted to HMAS Penguin, joining on 11 May 1942. While serving on Penguin, he was posted to the new Bathurst class corvette, HMAS Armidale. I can only imagine the pride he must have felt in working on a sleek, new warship that the crew had helped commission. On 22 August 1942, HMAS Armidale, with Teddy Sheean on board, departed Sydney for the last time. In November 1942, the Armidale was attached to the 24th Minesweeping Flotilla in Darwin, and on 29 November, in the company of HMAS Castlemaine, she sailed for Betano in Portuguese Timor. Her mission was to reinforce the guerrilla forces on the island and to evacuate Dutch troops and Portuguese civilians. She had on board three Australian and two Dutch officers and 61 troops.

On 1 December early in the morning the two ships arrived off Betano but withdrew because they failed to make contact with our forces onshore. Later the same day, they met HMAS Kuruâunder the command of Lieutenant J.A. Grantâa wooden patrol vessel requisitioned by the RAN from the Northern Territory administration in 1941. Kuru had 70 evacuees on board and was bound for Darwin. It was decided to transfer the passengers to Castlemaine, which then returned to Darwin. Kuru returned to Timor independently of Armidale. She survived heavy Japanese air attacks and returned with only minor damage to Darwin a few days later, on 3 December. After Armidale left Kuru, she was attacked twice by Japanese aircraft but escaped undamaged. But her luck had run out, and at 3 p.m. she was attacked by nine bombers, three fighters and a float plane. This force split up and came in from different directions. The gunners of Armidale fought back with all their might, shooting down one bomber and one fighter.

But then the Armidale was hit by two torpedoes and possibly a bomb as well. She sank within five minutes, taking with her 10 crew and most of the troops. Survivors were machine-gunned while in the water. After the order to abandon ship was given, the 19-year-old Sheean, like the rest of the ship's crew, went to the side, but he was hit twice by bullets from the returning planes that were strafing the survivors. I can understand how seeing his mates killed by the planes must have triggered such anger in him that, although wounded himself, he returned to his gun, strapped himself in and started firing at the attackers. He brought down one plane and was hit mortally in the chest, but he kept on firing, hanging in the straps as his legs gave way. Even after the ship had slid beneath the waves, he continued firing and he died with his ship.

But his sacrifice was not a folly, because his decision enabled some of his colleagues to survive the onslaught. The survivors boarded a damaged motorboat, while others clung to Carley floats and a couple of rafts. At sundown, sharks took their toll on the men in the water. Later the ship's whaler was found. She must have broken free when the ship went down and came back up to the surface. She was water logged but was bailed out, the men using the raft as a sort of pontoon to lift her free of the water, and was patched up using strips of canvas. I have heard the graphic detail from one of the survivors about how they actually went about that; it was a most extraordinary feat of bravery on its own.

On 2 December, 22 men, including Lieutenant Commander Richards, who was the only one who could navigate, and 12 wounded, left towards Bathurst Island in the motorboat to obtain help. Three days later they were spotted by friendly aircraft in the Arafura Sea and rescued on 6 December. Two men had died in the meantime from their wounds. The whaler, with 29 men on board, was located and rescued by HMAS Kalgoorlie on 9 December. After having been adrift for seven days, the occupants were in a very bad way. The rafts with 49 men were sighted by searching aircraft, but an extensive search later failed to locate the rafts again. All in all, the sinking resulted in the loss of 100 livesâtwo RAN officers and 38 soldiers, plus two Dutch officers and 58 troops. One has to wonder what would have happened and what the death toll would have been if Teddy Sheean had not gone down in the way that he did.

The Armidale was lost after only six months of service and was the last major Royal Australian Navy loss as a result of enemy action during World War II. In honour of Ordinary Seaman Teddy Sheean and his heroic deeds during World War II, the Australian Navy has named one of the Royal Australian Navy's six new Collins class submarines after him, the HMAS Sheean. The HMAS Sheean was the first ship in the British and Australian navies to be named after an ordinary seaman, the Navy's lowest rank. Last year Armidale and Latrobe in Tasmania jointly adopted HMAS Sheean, due to the strong links that the two have with Ordinary Seaman Teddy SheeanâLatrobe was where Teddy was born, and Armidale through the HMAS Armidale. The HMAS Sheean will be commissioned in late February next year with her sister ship, the HMAS Dechaineux, at Fleet Base West HMAS Stirling. Last December, the federal government fast-tracked the HMAS Dechaineux and the HMAS Sheean, the fourth and fifth submarines of the class, to bring the two up to operational capability by the end of this year at a cost of over $266 million.

I would like to thank the member for Braddon for raising this important issue. I would also like to thank my colleague the member for La Trobe for his efforts, together with the member for Braddon, to bring this to the public notice. I also praise the efforts of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Bruce Scott, for providing the federal funding for the trip to Perth for the surviving crew of HMAS Armidale and their partners or carers to attend the very important commissioning of the HMAS Sheean. I really do commend this motion to the House. It is important, as the member for Braddon said, that the question of the medals be reopened; Teddy Sheean being awarded a Victoria Cross for his services should be beyond question.

talk.start.para: âI congratulate the member for Braddon, Sid Sidebottom, for his motion and for his determination to support the cause of Teddy Sheean. I also congratulate the member for New England for his very strong support. It is again a privilege to be involved in a bipartisan way in a debate of this nature. Members are trying to create a situation where we can endeavour to rectify an injustice which many members of our community see in relation to military or wartime awards which recognise bravery. There is no doubt that there are anomalies in our system of awards, particularly when it comes to the Victoria Cross. There is no doubt too that in the course of trying to rectify these anomalies passions arise, as do controversy and sensitivities. There is always a danger too that in trying to rectify one anomaly or injustice another is created. These concerns, however, are not reasonable cause for doing nothing. I believe that we should be prepared to examine these matters and see, even so many years later, if we can achieve justice where justice has been denied.

speech.para: Not only is this the situation with Teddy Sheean, but others come to mind too, such as Simpson and his donkey, whose story is celebrated as part of our Anzac tradition. This was an issue raised by the member for Shortland a short time ago. In listening to petitions today, I noticed that a number of them relate to that situation. We have to pose the question: why was John Kirkpatrick denied the VC for which he was recommended? There is the case of Gary Cooper, a veteran who was highly decorated by the American forces in Vietnam but ignored by his own country. I am sure too that members will remember just a couple of years ago the long running fight to obtain justice for the six Vietnam diggers whose awards were downgraded and who encountered significant opposition within both government and particularly the bureaucracy when they sought justice. Why? We are aware too of the ongoing battle by veterans of Long Tan as they fight to achieve the right to wear decorations denied them because of government interference then and today. They are decorations which other Vietnam veterans have been given the right to wear, a right which is still refused them by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I pose the question: why? I join others in asking how we can rectify these situations and these anomalies.

We should rectify these situations with great caution and in consultation with the veteran community, who must have a say in any procedure or process of review, and with caution in relation to the integrity of our whole award system for, despite its flaws and some obvious shortcomings, there are many hundreds of men and women who have had their bravery duly recognised, and that must be respected. But we do have an opportunity to revisit some of these situations, and that occurs with the celebration of our Federation next year. Given the tremendous contribution made by veterans in our 100-year history, perhaps we should take time to review the circumstances of Teddy Sheean, the veterans of Long Tan and John Kirkpatrick. We should use that celebration as perhaps the last opportunity for all time to rectify the injustices that history has ignored for too long.

I encourage the government, particularly the minister, given the very strong bipartisan support we have here today, to enter into a dialogue with the veteran community, the Navy Association, the Royal Australian Air Force Association, the Returned and Services League and other relevant bodies in an effort to create a process where this can occur. I pose the question: which one of us here would be prepared to look into the eyes of those people who were saved by Teddy Sheean or of those people who were saved by John Kirkpatrick and say, `It is too difficult. It is too late'? I would not be prepared to look into the eyes of any one of those men and say, `We can't do anything.' We can do something. It might be a bit late, but next year, the year of our celebration, is probably the last opportunity we will have to do it. I compliment Sid Sidebottom, the member for Indi and the member for New England. I wholeheartedly support their passion and support for this motion.

talk.start.para: âI wholeheartedly support this motion and commend the member for Braddon, Sid Sidebottom, my colleague the member for New England and also the member for Cowan for their very appropriate words and summary of the unassailable facts in this matter. I would also like to thank my colleagues Bob Charles, the member for La Trobe, and state colleague Steve McArthur, the state member for Monbulk, who recently drew to the attention of Bruce Scott, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, and, in turn, John Moore, the Minister for Defence, the predicament of relatives not being able to attend the commissioning of the Collins class submarine in Perth, I understand, early next year. I would like to thank those two ministers for their prompt agreement to assist with transport and meeting the costs for those people and their carers to be at this most appropriate event.

speech.para: I will not go over all the facts again. I think they have been very well told. Of course it stirs the heart, and you cannot but feel strong emotion when you hear about this incredible act of sacrifice, of bravery, of example, of gallantry. There is no question at all that the award of the Victoria Cross is made to recognise just these sorts of acts. I feel almost resentment and anger, but I contain myself, to think that recognition of this great Australian cannot occur because someone has said that the list has closed. I have always been taught to believe that where injustice occurs, where an error occurs, whether you make it yourself or someone makes it on your behalfâa government, an administrationâyou have the courage to stand up and put it right. No-one is infallible. I am not on a witch-hunt, but I cannot stand here today, as we approach the centenary of our Federation, and allow an arbitrary bureaucratic judgment to rule against what is right. We have to fight for what is right and not acquiesce in what is wrong.

Clearly, the earlier bureaucracy and rules prevented an appropriate decision being made. Those rules were there, but it is possible to deal with something that is wrong. We are, after all, Australians. We have no reason to be told by others that you cannot do something which is right and just. Furthermore, I have tested this issue with many people from all walks of life as I move around the community. Indeed, my elder brother Braham raised it with me in a very eloquent and passionate letter last year because of his contacts from being very much involved in boating in Sydney. I would challenge any bureaucrat anywhere in Australia to produce an Australian, an ordinary Australian, who would not wish the member for Braddon's motion to be passed. I cannot find any Australian who would not wish it to be passed. There is not any decent Australian who would want that not to occur. Why don't we take a stand and respectfully ask all of those in responsible authority on behalf of the people of Australia, on behalf of this parliament, to put it right? Don't, whatever we do, go into our centenary year with an omission like this allowed to live simply because the End of War List has closed. I cannot accept that and I hope that others will hear this motion and act very speedily.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)âOrder! The time allotted for the debate on the motion moved by Mr Sidebottom, the honourable member for Braddon, relating to Ordinary Seamen Teddy Sheean, has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

motion.para: That grievances be noted.

talk.start.para: âWe have heard recently about many rural and regional communities complaining that services have been taken from their local communities, and that it has had a consequent effect on the standard of living of those people in those communities. This is true not only of regional and rural communities, however. In my electorate, which is a metropolitan electorate, the withdrawal of banking services from a number of suburbs has had a very detrimental effect on the people whom I represent. There has been round after round of branch closures in my electorate. Of course, with those branch closures come staff losses. But with those branch closures also comes rising inconvenience for the people who have relied on those banks until now. The exorbitant fees and charges that many of the banks have been charging, particularly people with low account balances, have had a very detrimental effect on my constituents.

speech.para: The Australian Banking Industry Ombudsman received 22 per cent more complaints in 1999-2000 than in the previous year. This is just a small indication of the frustration that many ordinary Australians are feeling on this issue. The Prime Minister is said to be a supporter of battlers; he calls himself a supporter of battlers in Australia. Yet his inaction on the issue of banks and the fees and charges that they are levelling on my constituents, and the fact that he has taken no clear line on the number of bank closures, would suggest that he is a bit more interested in the large donations that the big banks make to the coalition parties.

talk.start.para: âAnd the Labor Party.
âThey make much bigger donations to the coalition partiesâvastly bigger.
âProve that.

âIt is very easy to prove it, in fact, if you have been putting your returns in properly. Between 1993 and 1999, Australia's big four banksâWestpac, the National Australia Bank, ANZ and the Commonwealthâhave closed a quarter of their branches nationally. Over the same period, the combined net profits of the big four nearly tripled. In the first six months of this year alone some 355 bank branches closed across the countryâthat is a rate of about two branch closures almost every day of the year. The Finance Sector Union is very upset about the branch closures.

speech.para: In my electorate of Sydney, the Commonwealth Bank has recently closed branches in Waterloo, Alexandria and Erskineville. Last month I was informed that the bank would be closing yet another branch in my electorate, at Railway Square. That is due to close just three weeks before Christmas. On Friday I received another notice from the Commonwealth Bank that it is about to close another branch in my electorate. This one is on one of Sydney's busiest streets: Oxford Street. It is very difficult to argue that they are closing because they do not have customers. In fact, I know that they are overwhelmed with customers. The Commonwealth Bank has closed over 75 branches in the first half of this year alone, or 680 branches since 1993âmore than any other bank. Westpac, however, has also been closing branches in my electorate. Recently, they have closed branches at Waterloo, Camperdown and in the southern part of the central business district.

Moving on to fees and charges, in 1999 fees and commissions charged by the banks increased by $1.32 billion. The recent Reserve Bank and ACCC report entitled Debit and credit card schemes in Australia: a study of interchange fees and access demonstrates clearly that the banks are profiteering on fees and charges. Interchange feesâimposed when a consumer withdraws money from their bank at another bank's automatic teller machineâare around double the average cost of providing these services. Similarly, issuing credit cards creates revenue well above the average cost of providing these services. One week after the release of the report, the banks announced plans to raise fees and charges by as much as 50 per cent, and to introduce new charges where there were none before. These increases saw the Commonwealth Bank increase fees for over-the-counter transactions from $2 to $3 and giroPost transactions from $2 to $3. The National Australia Bank announced an increase in the fee for over-the-counter transactions from $2 to $3 as well, at the same time announcing that it would close 100 branches in metropolitan areas. Likewise, Westpac increased its over-the-counter fees from $2 to $2.50.

These charges make a significant impact on the lives of pensioners and people on low incomes, for whom every dollar must countâespecially after the introduction of the GST, which has hit these vulnerable people particularly hard. The majority of the 6,199 cases put to the banking ombudsman related to complaints by consumers that their bank had charged fees and charges contrary to the terms and conditions of that account. The problem with this, of course, is that consumers must be eternally vigilant to make sure that their banks are not, in fact, charging fees contrary to the terms of their account. But it puts a vast onus on pretty vulnerable consumers to take on large financial institutions.

In respect of jobs, since 1993 the number of employees at the big four banks fell by over 21,000 people, and the rate of profit made by the banks per employee has increased. However, workers and the Finance Sector Union have had to fight a protracted campaign for even the most basic wage rise. In 1998, it was reported that the head of Australia's biggest bankâMr Don Argus of the National Australia Bankâwas calculated to have been paid some 103 times the wage of a first-year teller. The closure of bank branches not only affects the staff of the bank itself, it has a dramatic impact on the community surrounding the bank and particularly on the shopping centres that surround banks in suburban shopping strips. There can be up to a 40 per cent downturn in retail trade in those suburban shopping centres when a branch closes.

There is a particularly stark illustration of this in my own electorate, in Waterloo. As I said, it has lost two banks recently and a post office. Suburbs like Waterloo are almost becoming ghost suburbs, as people have to leave the area to do all of their shopping and all of their banking and postal transactions. Elderly people and people with mobility difficulties in particular are disadvantaged by fewer branches, higher fees and charges and a reduction in face-to-face services. Closing a bank branch means that pensioners have to spend part of their precious pension money on actually getting to a bank in a neighbouring suburb.

One of the problems in my electorate is that there is quite a high number of bag snatchers in the inner city. Pensioners are forced to travel from Waterloo to Redfern, for example, to access their pension payments. If they want to do that only once a week or once a fortnight, they must carry quite large amounts of moneyâperhaps their entire pension. Unfortunately, the bag snatchers in the area know when it is pension day and many older people are attacked for their pension money because they have to carry it quite long distances as bank branches closer to home have closed.

It is easy to identify problems, but I think it is incumbent upon us to start discussing solutions. The banks have spent an enormous amount of money on advertising and I remind honourable members of the cash for comment scandal. These are not solutions to the problem of the poor standing of banks in the community. If banks are to improve their relationship with consumers and the community, they must start providing a better serviceâparticularly for those on low incomes with low account balances. Banks have an obligation to society as well as to their shareholders, and people on low incomes cannot be excluded from financial services simply because their business may not create as much profit for the banks as do wealthy people and wealthy corporations.

With the top four banks enjoying more than 80 per cent of the banking market and making a combined total of $9 billion between them, the `leave it to the market' answer is clearly unworkable. The government must direct the ACCC to continue to monitor bank fees and charges. We also have to bring the banks to the negotiating table with consumer groups and pensioner groups to create a social charter for banks. A social charter is important in ensuring that every Australian can access simple banking services. The social charter must be binding, otherwise it will be just a toothless tiger. It should include a requirement to provide a fee-free account for pensioners and social security recipients. We must also address the problem of banks that have closed branches thus making it impossible for their customers to access local branches or even ATMs.

talk.start.para: âThe Queensland branch of the Australian Labor Party might as well rename itself the `birthday party' because, as has been proved in evidence brought before the Shepherdson inquiry and in public debate in recent months, it believes in many happy returns from the electoral process. There is operating in Queensland a new Peter principle: anyone but meâmeaning the Premier of Queenslandâis to blame for what has been going on. This Premier has shut down the Queensland parliament. These matters cannot be debated there and scrutiny is being avoided. All too often, a similar technique is practised here: last week quorums were called and withdrawn and those opposite introduced umpteen other disruptions to debates and the parliamentary processes exercised by responsible members of parliament.

speech.para: The Peter principle operating in Queensland is to sacrifice anyone but the Queensland Premier. The Premier is telling everyone that he knows nothing, but of course he knows everything. In his book, In the Arena, which was published some 10 years ago, he talks about his attempt to be preselected in 1986 in the Redlands by-election, and says:

quote.para: Doorknocking the area was an interesting experience. One female party member was not at home when I called on her at the vacant allotment where she purportedly lived.

speech.para: This is the key part of the quote, which continues:

quote.para: To my not particularly great surprise she later voted in the preselection.

speech.para: When the current Premier, Mr Beattie, wrote his book some 10 or 12 years ago about a matter that occurred 14 years ago, he was not particularly surprised when a bogus member voted in a preselection. This leaves me and everybody else in Queensland wondering why, when he had the power and the responsibility as State Secretary of the Labor Partyâhe was the keeper of the membership listsâhe failed to do anything about it. Of course history shows that he lost that particular plebiscite to the current member for Bowman, and it would be interesting to discover which candidate that bogus member of the Labor Party voted for.

But there is still no excuse for Peter Beattie. He had the opportunity to clean up, but instead he covered up. It is interesting to reflect upon a recent article from the Sydney Morning Herald that referred to former Labor Party State President Ian McLean, who said:

quote.para: ... a 1993 report by a lawyer, the late Hamish Linacre, detailing evidence of electoral rorting was given to the state ALP's disputes tribunal, but it was ignored.

speech.para: So the evidence has been before the Australian Labor Party in Queensland on umpteen occasions, yet nothing has been done. Of course now, like a house of cards, it is tumbling down around them. I find it astonishing that, when the Queensland Premier had the opportunity to do something about it all those years ago, he did nothing. Yet, years later, he wrote about it, like an old war story.

It is worth reflecting on the fact that the area in which Mr Beattie was seeking preselection is the same area were Jim Elder and John Buddâboth of whom have been publicly disgraced and revealed as electoral roll rortersâwere members and which they contested over the years. Sadly for the member for Bowman, that area is completely within his federal electorate. Peter Beattie did nothing at that time, and the people of Queensland deserve to know why he did not act all those years ago.

The Queensland Premier is a well-known opportunistâeven those opposite understand that his history shows the extent of his opportunism. When I worked for Channel 7, we disclosed in a story in early 1988 his attempt to meet in 1987 with the then Premier Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen when the Nationals were looking to change the leadership of their party. Sir Joh and Peter Beattie met behind a tin shed in Kingaroy to discuss the possibility of the Australian Labor Party's actually helping Sir Joh to stay in power in Queensland. That is the sort of opportunist this man is. He was once a member of the left wing of the Australian Labor Party, but he then resigned from that faction. It is my understanding that, if you have no faction in the Labor Party, you have virtually no friends and that you need something on someone to survive. Of course, that is exactly what Peter Beattie was able to do as State Secretary: he picked up all the information he needed to survive.

talk.start.para: âWas he a rearguard fighter?

âHe is the mudguard and the vanguard. In fact, the know-nothing Peter principle practised by the Queensland Premier is part of the ongoing deal that Peter Beattie did all those years ago with the Australian Workers Union faction. That is why he is Premier and that is how he stays on as Premier.

speech.para: In the 1980s, Peter Beattie's price for silence was endorsement in Brisbane Central, a plum safe seat in the middle of Brisbane. He even briefly joined Labor Unity just so he could get the selection, but he resigned from that faction too. The deal with the AWU in those days meant that the now member for Lilley, Wayne Swan, became state secretary of the Labor Party and, of course, he was able to gain the know-how to know everything as well. I guess that is why state secretary Wayne Swan always opposed attempts in Queensland to clean up the electoral roll. The now member for Lilley even threatened legal action against the Cooper government in Queensland when it started efforts to track down Labor's electoral rorts.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I rise under standing order 76. Any reflections or imputations against another member of this House must be done by way of a substantive motion. He has now moved from the Premier of Queensland to the member for Lilley. That is quite inappropriate, without the appropriate form being complied with.

(Mr Jenkins)âI will listen very carefully to the honourable member for Moreton, with that standing order in mind. I think he is aware of the requirement that, if he were to make any allegations, he would have to do so by substantive motion.

âMy learned friend from Barton is just simply playing the game of delay and diffuse as much as possible with any attempt by members in this place to raise issues of great concern and matters of great grievance to the people of Queensland. But the Premier of Queensland in particular must come clean. He can no longer masquerade under this cover of `know nothing'; he cannot continue to claim this. His own words from his own book condemn him. He is, after all, a captive of the AWU that he claims to be trying to fix. Facts are emerging about the AWU slush fund that was organised and the big fundraisers that were run to top it up. The organisation made use of the member for Bowman's office, and the member for Bowman knows that. Peter Beattie, of course, over time will be exposed.

speech.para: This particular slush fund, in itself, is pretty interesting reading. It was used by the AWU to pay for `dodgy' enrolments, used to stack out Labor Party plebiscites. A large volume of the funds has been allegedly raised at functions held at the Sheraton and Hilton hotels in Brisbane during 1993 and 1994. Those functions were attended by the then Queensland Premier, Wayne Goss; by the current Attorney-General in Queensland, Matt Foley; by the then federal Attorney-General, Michael Lavarch; and by the current shadow minister, the member for Kingsford-Smith, Laurie Brereton. So fundraisers were all part of the AWU's approach. That matter will bring down Peter Beattie and others associated with the AWU in Queensland and in the Australian Labor Party.

But, to sum up, we simply cannot trust Peter Beattie and the Australian Labor Party to clean up this mess. If we do not get Commonwealth legislation to clean up the electoral processâidentification needs to be demanded of those who come to claim the right to vote as well as those who enrol to voteâwe will find a continuation of this particular rort that has been going on in Queensland for how many years none of us are sure. Mr Beattie needs to reconvene the Queensland parliamentâbut he will not, because he is afraid of the scrutiny and the accountability that will come from opening up the Queensland parliament.

talk.start.para: âHe doesn't have the numbers.

âOn that, as the minister at the table says, he simply does not have the numbers. If he does the right thing and follows the same principle as was applied in the other place during all the matters relating to former Senator Colston, the Premier of Queensland would not count the votes of Elder or Musgrove or any of these others who are going to come out in the wash over the weeks and months ahead. But the Premier of Queensland does not understand that sort of propriety.

speech.para: This is about more than the $1.60 or thereabouts a vote that is gained from the Commonwealth electoral process and goes into the Australian Labor Party's coffers. The people of Queensland need to be satisfied that this `know nothing' Premier does somethingâand the most honourable thing he can do is to reconvene the Queensland parliament to allow a proper debate on these issues to be discussed. This is a matter of organised criminal activity. He leads a corrupt organisation. He knows everythingâhe does not `know nothing'; he knows everything. His claims to the contrary will not stand the tests ahead. Is it any wonder that the people of Queensland are seeing those who joined the Labor Party in an honest decision making process leaving that once great workers' party in droves?

talk.start.para: âI get the feeling that many of my Queensland colleagues would rather be in the state parliament. Perhaps we would all be better off if they were: we would not hear such drivel on such regular occasions. What goes around comes around, and Queenslanders know that. They sat back and watched corruption for decades. To hear an ex-media person talking about his political views at the time is, indeed, a very good insight.

âMr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I would ask the member for Newcastle to withdraw that suggestion. As for my record as a journalist practising in Queensland, he will know that I stood very strongly againstâ
(Mr Jenkins)âOrder! The honourable member will resume his seat. There is no point of order.

âIn this debate, firstly, I want to refer to the circumstances of the men and women who work for Steel Tank and Pipe in Newcastle and other locations across the country. The events of this company apparently are becoming now normal in corporate Australia as ways of minimising payroll tax, company tax, personal liability and a whole range of other issues in improving their access to borrowings. In this way, when borrowing money, they do not disclose the company's liabilities but only put forward the assets. It seems to me that the clever people who advise these companies have something to answer for. But, equally importantly, so has the governmentâbecause nothing is being done to stop this obvious fraud from taking place.

speech.para: A group of companies cannot, on the one hand, trade on a daily basis, using all the group's resources, both assets and liabilities, in terms of balancing their affairs, and, at the same time, suggest that the liabilities are not linked to the assets because they are in separate companies. So either the directors of the companies employing the work forces throughout the country were trading insolvently when bills were not being paid on behalf of the men from whose wages the relevant money was being takenâsuch as for deductions for taxation or health insuranceâor the same resources that have stopped them trading insolvently should be available to the group as well.

It seems to me that the rush by companies into these corporate structuresâand we understand that Steel Tank and Pipe may have had as many as 32 companies operational in one form or anotherâis clearly with intent to misrepresent their real liabilities and circumstances. I would have thought that the government would have been much more active than it has been to date in looking at how these structures are working and whether companies are able to trade in the way they are, and in trying to make sure that companies wind back such arrangements. Clearly, it has been done, we gather, by thousands of companies all over the country. It is time it was undone. People who were working in those organisations are facing absolute poverty in the next few months whilst their directors maintain their assets across the country and quite substantial living styles. I call on the government to initiate an inquiry by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission not just into this one company but into company processes that allow the destruction of employees' entitlements and funds in this way.

I want to move on to the results of a survey that I had conducted in Newcastle back in November for clients of Job Network. This is a survey that the Minister for Employment Servicesâthat loose-tongued member for Warringahâmade some rather unpleasant remarks about a few weeks ago. The survey has produced a lot of interesting information. I have had quite a number of people respond. The majority of respondents have identified themselves, which means they want to be known and to be contacted. I want to read a letter from a Mrs Suzanne Hudson from Georgetown. The letter was written to Mr Michael Beisty, the manager of Centrelink at Mayfield. It says:

quote.para: Dear Mr Beisty,

This letter is in response to the activity test breach imposed on me because I did not attend an interview at a legal office in Cessnock which was arranged by my case manager at IPA in June of this year.

I would like to point out to you that after initially refusing to attend the interview I did agree to go because Toni, my case manager informed me that by refusing, I would be breaking my activity agreement under the Social Security Act 1991. She said she would report my refusal to attend the interview to Centrelink because she considered Cessnock to be within reasonable distance from my home. I then advised Toni that I would attend the interview if it resulted in breaching my activity agreement and causing the suspension or reduction of my Newstart payment. Toni then told me that my attitude was too negative and that she would not arrange the interview. Later that day a second interview was arranged at an Accountant's office in The Junction which I attended. However, I was not successful in gaining full time employment in that office, I believe, because of my long term unemployment and lack of recent experience in an office.

In the last four years since completing a Bachelor of Arts at Newcastle University I have been applying for office positions without success. When it has been possible for me to ring the employer or employment agency acting for the employer, I have been advised that the successful applicants had had at least six months recent experience. In most cases I was told that this was an essential requirement for the position because of the overwhelmingly large number of applicants applying for the positionâone example being Impulse Airlines who received over 1,000 applications for the position of call centre operators.

I realised that I would have to look at other areas of employment where age and long term employment would not be a barrier. I have since been employed as a telemarketer with a wine society, and last year, after completing a Get Skilled course at TAFE in aged care/cooking, I worked in an age care facility until I injured my neck and had to resign. When my neck improved sufficiently, I worked as a cleaner for Dial An Angel. Ideally I would have preferred to work in an office and I did do computer courses at TAFE, WEA and the Hunter Community College to update my computer skills in the event that an office position would one day eventuate. However, because I have not had the paid office experience, my skills were not up to standard. That is why I started to do voluntary work in the University Legal Centre and Legal Aid, because it gave me the opportunity to become accustomed to an office environment and gain adequate skills and confidence. You can speak with Mary Brehe at the University Legal Centre on 49 218666 for confirmation.

I explained to Toni on that day that I felt I would rather continue working as a cleaner until my computer skills had improved, but she insisted in sending me to office positions. I also explained to Toni that I needed to complete a Legal Procedure course at TAFE before applying for jobs in the legal sector, but she refused to listen. That is one of the reasons why I did not want to drive all the way to Cessnockâon what I believed to be a wild goose chaseâbecause I did not have legal experience.
