I enquired at TAFE about enrolling in a Legal Procedure course and was told I would have to complete Certificate I in Office Administration first. This would have taken several months.

Also, I did not believe my old car could cope with a 60 klm drive to Cessnock and back, five days a week. I also believed that my health would suffer and I was prepared to get a medical certificate from my doctor to confirm this.

Finally, I arranged and attended another interview at Tinonee Gardens as a House Manager without any assistance or interest from Toni who I did advise about the position. As she showed no interest I did not inform her about being successful in my application until the interview with her on 21st June. Unfortunately, the position is only casual and I do not know how many shifts I am rostered on for from fortnight to fortnight. Therefore, I am not in a position to forfeit my Newstart payments until the position becomes more permanent and consistent. Because of this I am seeking a second casual position.

If I had not been successful in obtaining my position at Tinonee Garden, I would have requested to change my job network provider, because I believe there was a personality clash between myself and Toni, which was negative and unproductive for the both of us. I feel this clash has influenced Toni's decision to involve Centrelink in this âCessnock incidentâ. IPA have not assisted me in finding a job, nor understood my needs and barriers to employment as a mature person and long term unemployed person. The only credit she can be given is to cause conflict between myself and Centrelink over this incident, which has resulted in an 18% reduction in my Newstart payment. It has also put a âblack markâ on my record which has caused me much stress and anxiety over the past two weeks.

speech.para: That letter was written on 15 August and submitted to Centrelink. I received a copy of it at the end of the first week in November. I was horrified at that letter, because it really does indicate a woman who has tried enormously hard to gain employment and had gained some casual employment from her own endeavours. I have contacted Centrelink and spoken to Mr Beisty as late as this afternoon. He advised me this afternoon that she was actually breached a second time without her knowledgeâshe was breached twice out of that incidentâbut that both had been revoked. But it has taken from August until now, and it has occurred only because of my intercession. The letter only arrived because I issued a survey and asked people to respond.

I have dozens of responses and I was hoping to read more of them into Hansard. They make you weep. The comments from people who have been through the Job Network system and the individual and personal hurt they have suffered are enormously depressing. It is about time the government recognised that people out of work are still human beings with needs and concerns. Treating them the way they are being treated at the moment is not good for them and it is even worse for the country. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âA comprehensive retirement income policy that helps guarantee financial security for our older Australians is an essential feature of the social contract that operates in Australia. A nation's commitment to looking after its elderly is a reflection of the strength of its society. Since coming into office in 1996 the coalition government has introduced a variety of initiatives to give older Australians a better deal than they experienced under Labor. At the moment our superannuation reforms are a work in progress. We cannot afford to sit still. The global economy is continually evolving and Australia's demographics are constantly changing. Australia's retirement income system consists of three components: the age pension, the compulsory superannuation guarantee and individual private savings.

speech.para: Credible estimates put our total national bill for age pension payments at $17 billion per year, or about three per cent of gross domestic product. Unless current trends change, the demand for the age pension will continue to increase over the next decade. The primary reason for this projected increase is our ageing population. Currently, approximately 12 per cent of Australians are aged over 65. Advances in health services and medical treatment mean that by 2010 this figure could double to nearly 25 per cent. Unless initiatives are introduced to promote lower reliance on the age pension, the taxation system will be faced with an exponentially increasing burden that is likely to prove unsustainable over the longer term. It is essential for the long-term viability of our retirement income system that we promote shifting the responsibility for providing retirement income from the public sector to the individual. The social and economic benefits of encouraging individuals to save for retirement are twofold: it will ensure more public funds will be available for other public services and it will improve the financial situation for individuals and give them increased consumer choice during retirement.

A report published last month by the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry effectively endorses the coalition's reforms to date and suggests that the most important features of a retirement income system include a reduction in the importance of the age pension, greater reliance on institutional savings arrangements such as voluntary superannuation contributions, additional emphasis given to private investments and individual savings, encouragement of greater home ownership, introduction of measures to encourage ongoing employment past the historical retirement age and graduated retirement, and funding for the provision of a world standard health care system.

The coalition government has created the economic conditions that encourage individuals to save and invest, including home ownership. The coalition government has been a great friend of all Australians with a home mortgage. Since the coalition came to government interest rates have reached historical lows. This has been welcome news to many Australians with mortgages, including my wife and I, who well remember the high interest rate policies of the Keating-Beazley government and the `recession we had to have'. The government's $7,000 kick-start for first home owners is another important initiative that encourages home ownership.

Australia also enjoys the highest level of direct share ownership in the world. Since 1996 when the coalition came to office the number of Australians who own shares has doubled. In 1997, 20 per cent of adult Australians owned shares directly. In 1998 it was 31 per cent and, according to the Australian Stock Exchange, 40 per cent of adult Australians now own shares directly. That is the highest level in the world, with the United Kingdom at 39 per cent, the United States at 32 per cent and New Zealand at 31 per cent.

The coalition government is also committed to policies that promote graduated retirement and the introduction of measures to encourage ongoing employment past the historical retirement age. As we continue to move towards a service based economy there is a greater scope for people who have reached retirement age to continue working on a full-time or part-time consultancy basis. There are several social and economic benefits of having older Australians continuing to participate in the labour force. Firstly, it will significantly help improve the skill level of the labour force, which can increase the productivity of business. Secondly, it will assist greater interaction between older and younger Australians as valuable skills and workplace experiences are passed on from one generation to the next. Thirdly, it will help reduce the demand for age pension payments and increase national savings. There is a very real challenge for the government to implement the economic conditions that will encourage an increase in national savings. But a sound economy in itself does not guarantee higher national savings. For instance, two national economies of comparative strength over the last decade have dramatically different national savings ratios: Japan enjoys one of the highest in the world while the United States has one of the lowest.

The coalition government has canvassed many of these specific issues in an issues paper entitled Employment for mature age workers. The paper is part of a series recently published under the heading of `A National Strategy for an Ageing Australia'. There are some legitimate concerns that there are a number of disincentives which act to discourage individuals from continuing to work past retirement age. It is important that additional earnings should not unfairly limit or restrict entitlement to government benefits, but should offset these progressively.

There are several other schools of thought regularly raised by interest groups with regard to retirement income reform. One commonly advocated position is that individuals who are able to save for retirement should be rewarded. The argument follows that those who did not prepare for retirement should not be as well off as those who did. In the interests of equity and fairness there is a need to strike a delicate balance in this area. The Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia advocate raising the compulsory superannuation contributions from the projected ceiling of nine per cent of salaries in 2002 to between 12 and 15 per cent. I have some concerns about this proposal. How much is `enough' for superannuants ultimately depends on each individual. Some individuals may choose to enjoy greater consumptionâand therefore expenditureâduring their working life, while others may prefer to save hard for their retirement when they may want to enjoy greater consumption. I believe that once the contribution rate is sufficient to reduce the budgetary cost of the age pension the normal market oriented solution would be to let individuals decide for themselves how much they want to save and for what purpose. I also support the principle that individuals have the right to choose the superannuation fund to which they contribute. Giving consumers the ability to exercise market discretion will foster competition and encourage greater individual returns. It is also important that income streams be encouraged and lump sum payments discouraged.

The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and other interested parties have also called for changes to the taxation treatment of superannuation. The Chamber of Commerce and Industry believe that the current approach to taxation of superannuation needs to be reviewed. The Chamber of Commerce and Industry contend that if retirement incomes are to be maximised taxation should occur only upon receipt. I am not fully convinced of the merits of this suggestion, although it is possibly something that the government should further explore. The provision of an adequate retirement income system is an essential feature of the social contract that operates between individuals, business and government. It is an important challenge for us all as legislators to ensure that the retirement income system continues to evolve so that it remains sustainable as the ageing of our population continues. It is the responsibility of this government to implement public policy that encourages private savings and preparation for retirement.

talk.start.para: âEarlier today a petition was tabled from my electorate containing 4,335 signatures, if my memory is correct. It is a petition in relation to fuel prices. I think it is important to speak to the petition because, as powerful as a petition can be, a petition cannot tell the whole story about the damage that the Prime Minister's broken promise on fuel prices is doing in Central Queensland. Among other things, the petition that was tabled today calls on the government to honour its commitment to Australian motorists to reduce the petrol excise by the equivalent amount of the GST. As I said, 4,335 people in Central Queensland have signed the petition so far. But it is not just the petition coming into my office over the last few weeks that tells the story. There have also been letters, notes and phone calls that have come in in response to the petition. For example, these are some of the letters I have selected to bring to the attention of the House. One letter from a woman in Longreach says:

quote.para: I would like to add to the petition the extra strain that it has on families who have to travel to Rockhampton, Brisbane and Townsville, as well as out here, for medical purposes.

speech.para: They are considerable distances that we are talking about around Longreach. Another woman wrote to me on behalf of her small business and says:

quote.para: In addition to the effect on all Australian families, I have no doubt you are well aware of the gross impact the high cost of fuel has on small to medium businesses. Although our business began as a small family business, we now currently employ 20 local people, including our family members, and we have only survived because family members have always worked very long hours for little pay and the loyalty of our employees.

speech.para: I guess the message there is that you can only survive on that for so long when you are up against rising business costs. Another letter here is from a parent on the Capricorn coast who says:

quote.para: The rising cost of bus travel may be having an effect on local interschool sports. Some parents are starting to weigh up whether to pay for their children to go to activities like Friday afternoon interschool sport, which require bus costs, or to go to an educational excursion because they cannot afford both in the same week.

speech.para: Finally, I have a letter from a pensioner in Rockhampton:

quote.para: Dear Kirsten,

I have most willingly signed this petition. Being a 72 year old aged single pensioner I look like I might have to give up my dear old car. You see, it uses super petrol and I am having trouble affording the petrol to just help me get around on my messages and to keep my independence.

speech.para: As I said, petitions do not tell the whole story. Those letters give some indication of the effect that high fuel prices are having on ordinary people and small businesses in Central Queensland. Those people know that John Howard's broken promise is contributing to their pain and difficulties.

Further to the petition and those letters, on 15 November Labor's fuel price inquiry went to Rockhampton to hear evidence from Central Queenslanders about the effect of high fuel prices on ordinary families and pensioners and, as well, on other members of the community. The effect on families and ordinary people is easy to think about, and we are all quite familiar with it, but when the inquiry went to Rockhampton it was a chance to hear how it is impacting directly and indirectly in ways that I had not fully appreciated. There is a big ripple effect starting to emerge from these high fuel prices. One example was from the representative of the tourism industry in Central Queensland. Tourism is one of Central Queensland's emerging industries. Eighty-four per cent of tourists in Central Queensland arrive by car, so it is not hard to imagine that the cost of fuel impacts very heavily on whether they come and also on how long they stay and what they do in our region. The main source for tourists to our area is country New South Wales and Victoria. We were told that the loop through the western Queensland region and then back down the coast was just getting established for that caravan and driving market, and that that was becoming a popular route. It now seems that the coastal route will again dominate tourism in Queensland, and those little towns west of the Great Divide will miss out because the cost of fuel limits the amount of travel people can do, and also those towns have a reputation for having higher fuel costs.

The other evidence that we took was from transport companies around Rockhampton. We found that fuel accounts for 30 per cent of the costs of those companies. One large transport company told us that they have been absorbing the extra cost of high fuel prices but that they are now about to impose a surcharge for their customers to pay. They told us that as companies are getting squeezed by high fuel prices the pressure is on to cut corners, and that safety suffers as a result. I know that this company really does pride itself on its rigorous adherence to safety standards and fatigue management, but it said that it is already losing business to other cheaper operatorsâand we can guess where those cheaper operators are picking up the advantage on larger, very reputable transport companies. Another smaller local transport company does the run out to the western towns in my electorate. Its customers are farmers and small businesses in those country towns. Of course, that transport company finds it impossible to pass on its higher costs to businesses and people who are suffering similarly in this environment.

The local charity group Meals on Wheels also came to talk to us. That was very interesting. I was not aware of just how much these high fuel prices are impacting on every aspect of our community. The people from Meals on Wheels told us that they are finding it harder to get drivers and to fill rosters. They have traditionally offered petrol vouchers to their volunteers. Those petrol vouchers were valued at $4, but now they are having to look at increasing those to $5. People are dropping out of volunteering for Meals on Wheels or are reducing the number of days they work per week. So it is a real double whammy effect: Meals on Wheels are struggling to find volunteers, and the volunteers, who see Meals on Wheels as an opportunity to contribute to their community in retirement and as a form of social contact, are having to give up something that they really value.

The message is pretty clear that, every time someone fills up their tank in Central Queensland, they are thinking of the Prime Minister's broken promise. We will not forget that he said that fuel prices would not go up as a result of the GST. Everyone now knows the truth. John Howard continues to refuse to admit it and continues to refuse to do the right thing. He refuses to reduce fuel excise to counteract the GST price rise in the way that he said he would before the last election. If the Prime Minister did what the ALP is suggesting, which is what he promised in the first placeâthat is, to reduce excise by enough to counteract the GST or, alternatively, to take the inflation effect out of next February's excise increaseâit would lead to a drop in fuel prices of around 2c a litre. When the Prime Minister says that that does not amount to much, he is very much out of touch with life on a pension or a budget or in a small business.

The second part of the petition is about the role of the ACCC in monitoring fuel prices, and that would strike a chord with motorists in Central Queensland as well. The petition calls on the government to reverse the 1 August 1998 decision, under the Prices Surveillance Act 1983, to remove the price oversight role of the ACCC for the petroleum industry and, also, to formally declare petroleum prices under the Prices Surveillance Act, enabling the ACCC to consider whether proposed price increases are justifiable. Even before we copped the extra slug of the GST on our fuel, the price of fuel in Central Queensland was a scandal because of the discrepancy between what we paid compared with our closest neighbours in other provincial cities in Queensland.

Recently, I received a letter from the RACQ as part of the campaign about fuel prices. When I looked at a table of all the fuel prices in Queensland, I was shocked. For example, from September 1999 to September 2000, the price of fuel in Rockhampton went from 76.6c a litre to 96.5c a litre. Over time that comparison is bad enough, but when you look at the comparison across our fellow provincial cities it is outrageous. When we were paying 96.5c a litre in September, Townsville was paying 90.9c a litre, Bundaberg was paying 88.5c a litre and even Warwick was only paying 91.6c a litre. I am as mystified as my constituents about why we in Rockhampton pay so much more than even those in Mackay and Gladstone, our nearest neighbours.

Motorists in Central Queensland need answers. The oil companies obviously are not going to give those answers voluntarily, so we need the involvement of the ACCC in the petroleum industry, making sure that petrol companies cannot hold entire towns, including local service station operators, to ransom the way they have been holding Rockhampton and the towns to our west ransom. We hear a lot from the Prime Minister about leadership, but we see no evidence of leadership from him when it comes to acting on fuel prices.

talker.name: Worth, Trish, MP
Ms WORTH
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs

talk.start.para: âI am pleased to have the opportunity to speak in the grievance debate today. While portfolio responsibilities provide me with opportunities to improve the lives of young Australians, they do also restrict or limit my opportunities to speak on broader issues of importance to my electorate, and today provides me with one of those rare opportunities. Deals and secret arrangements about preferences have had some public airing in recent days. Governments are won and lost in marginal seats, and marginal seats are decided on preferences from minor parties and Independents. In my experience, few members of the public understand the flow-down effect from minor party and Independent candidates to the major party candidates in electorates such as Adelaide. Few understand that, for instance, if a Labor Party candidate gets a minor party or Independent candidate's sixth position preference and the Liberal Party candidate gets their seventh position preference, a voter for the minor party or Independent candidate has just as surely voted Labor as if Labor had secured their number one vote. The temptation for deals and secret arrangements are therefore obvious.

speech.para: Allegations about such arrangements have been made against the Australian Labor Party in Queensland and there has been one criminal conviction in that state. Today, I would like to talk about a few things that have occurred in my own electorate which are, at best, questionable. In doing so, I note that the Leader of the Opposition has made certain claims in a doorstop interview. Those claims were quoted by Dennis Shanahan in his article in the Weekend Australian of 2-3 December 2000:

quote.para: Beazley also said: `It is not unusual, down the line, for the agreement to be mutually assisted by one party giving assistance to another. There's nothing illegal about that.' He also said it was not unusual for financial assistance to be given between parties.

speech.para: I beg to differ. I have never known money to change hands in return for a good preference deal. No doubt as a result of the publicity given to electoral rorting, a number of people have provided me with information which, if it is true, is certainly unethical and possibly contravenes section 326 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, which states:

quote.para: A person shall not, in order to influence or affect ... any support of, or opposition to, a candidate, a group of candidates or a political party by another person ... give or confer, or promise or offer to give or confer, any property or benefit of any kind to that other person or to a third person.

speech.para: At the last federal election in 1998, seven candidates contested the seat of Adelaide: the Democrats, Labor, Liberal, National Law Party, One Nation, the Greens and an Independent candidate, Ms Rita Hunt, running on a no-GST platform. Liberal booth workers have reported that they encountered members of the Labor Party handing out how-to-vote cards for the Greens candidate. Greens preferences benefited the ALP. Of greater significance is the information provided to me that Rita Hunt has told others that she did not pay for her own campaign material, which consisted of not only printed material but also posters. This raises the question: who did pay for Ms Hunt's campaign material? It has been put to me that Labor paid for that material. Further, I know that a former ALP legislative councillor took responsibility for removing Ms Hunt's signs and material when the booth he was looking after for the ALP was being closed. Again, Ms Hunt's preferences benefited the ALP.

The ALP in South Australia is controlled by the machine. The machine is a strange combination of powerbrokers of the Bolkus Left and the Labor Unity right-wing faction run by the Shop Assistants Union. Bill Hender, as he resigned from the Labor Party recently, said:

quote.para: The machine does not like policies which have competent, practical solutions.

speech.para: He went on:

quote.para: They are so full of their own self-interest ...

speech.para: The machine has presided over massive branch stacking. Aboriginal people whose names were allegedly obtained through the Omoona CDEP found themselves with addresses at a certain PO Box 300 and with addresses of members of the ALP. The anticorruption branch of the South Australia Police is still investigating this activity. It should be of interest to the people of Adelaide that my Labor opponent at the next election was a defence lawyer for the ALP when Ralph Clark, a member of the state parliament and a constituent of mine, took the ALP to court over branch stacking and won. The people of my electorate have a right to know of any deals, any exchange of money and any other assistance by the ALP for a minor party or an Independent candidate. They are also entitled to know if someone is being run as a dud candidate to benefit Labor. These matters are of significance in the current debate but not just for the current debate; they are significant in the democracy that we must treasure and nurture here in this country.

While time allows me, I would like to mention another issue which is important to perhaps a smaller group but a very important group in my electorate. I am a patron of the Justice for Cyprus Coordinating Committee and so is the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia, Mike Rann. On public occasions, he is particularly active in supporting the cause of justice for Cyprus. Cyprus was invaded by Turkey over 26 years ago now, and the only country in the world to recognise the occupied territory as a separate state is Turkey. There are United Nations resolutions about this. Australia, with the rest of the world, certainly condemns that invasion and does not recognise the occupied territory.

I have visited Cyprus twice, once with the member for Watson and others. I would be very surprised to find that, while some members of the Labor Party are publicly being very supportive of the cause of justice for Cyprus, a Labor frontbencher should write to the Minister for Foreign Affairs with a different point of view. While recognising the relative strength of the Turkish people internationally, he talks about the fact that some years ago a delegation met the former Minister for Foreign Affairs, Gareth Evans, about a variety of issues affecting the community. He is putting forward the fact that there could be an office for the TRNCâthat is the area of Cyprus which is not recognisedâand asks the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether he would consider that. That is a fairly strange thing to be doing. I wonder if that means there is a change of Labor policy in this area, because as recently as July the Labor Party was passing a resolution, part of which reads:

quote.para: Labor reaffirms its longstanding and unequivocal support for the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of the Republic of Cyprus.

speech.para: There has been a small delegation acting in an unofficial capacity in this country from the northern part of Cyprus, and I understand that has been hosted in the New South Wales parliament, accompanied by the same Labor Party frontbencher who wrote that letter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and by Mr Peter Nagle, who is the state member for Auburn. They were given a tour of Parliament House, and I understand Mr Nagle subsequently issued an invitation to the leader of the Turkish Cypriot delegation to attend a parliamentary conference in Australia in 2001 on the subject of the legal structure of national parliaments. While Mr Nagle could perhaps be excused, being a member of the state parliament, he obviously has not considered the fact that Australia does not recognise occupied Cyprus as a separate state or as a separate government and consequently has not given any consideration to the fact that Australia may well not issue visas for such people to attend such a conference.

I think it is a particularly important issue. I have spoken to the Prime Minister's office and the Minister for Foreign Affairs about having the issue of justice for Cyprus and the ongoing struggle there put on the agenda for CHOGM. CHOGM will be held between 6 and 9 October next year in Brisbane. It will provide another forum for airing these issues. As we have seen other difficult areas around the world resolve their problems, we can only hope that that will occur in Cyprus, where Australia still has a peacekeeping force with other United Nations countries.

When I visited Cyprus last, I managed to get into the occupied territory. I did so with mixed feelings because I knew that so many of my constituents just could not do thatâthose who still own land in that occupied territory or in some cases those whose parents are buried in that area and who cannot visit their graves or the churches that they once knew and loved. But it is important that we resolve this. It is important that we keep it on the agenda in every public forum where Australia can have influence. I have been very encouraged by the attitude of the Prime Minister's office and the Minister for Foreign Affairs in putting forward this issue as an agenda item for the CHOGM meeting. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Northern Territory University: Courses
Rail: Alice Springs to Darwin Railway
Country Liberal Party: Northern Territory

subdebate.1.title: Rail: Alice Springs to Darwin Railway
Country Liberal Party: Northern Territory

talk.start.para: âFirstly, I would like to acknowledge to our massive audience this afternoon two friends from Christmas Island, Noorani and the President of the Shire of Christmas Island, David McLane, who are here for the local government discussions which are taking place. I would like to welcome them to the parliament.

speech.para: There are a few issues I want to address today very quickly, the first of which is that, on 8 November this year, I was quoted in the education supplement of the Australian as saying that it was impossible to do a degree in history at the Northern Territory University. This statement was in connection with my concern about the failure of the Northern Territory University to gather adequate funds and the resource implications of that, the fact that a number of courses had been cut and the fact that it was no longer possible to do a major in physics or mathsâand I included history. I must advise the House that that was wrong. In fact, you can do a history course at NTU. History is available to Bachelor of Arts students. It is taught at honours level. I am advised by Professor Carment at the university that it is `one of the strongest areas for postgraduate research' and that there are a number of PhD students.

Another matter I want to talk about briefly is an article which appeared today in the Daily Telegraph written by my colleague the member for Werriwa in relation to infrastructure expenditure. The heading is `Fast Track to a New White Elephant.' He was referring to the Darwin to Alice Springs railway. Whilst I understand that the member for Werriwa has a view, it is not a view that I share, and I have to ask a number of questions. He says in his article that the viability of the railway has never been proven. Frankly, I am not sure what inside information he has, if he has had discussions with the financiers who will underwrite the private sector involvement in this railway or if he has had the benefit of detailed analysis of any cost benefit studies which have been done into the potential railway development. But I have to say that I disagree with him for other reasons as well. They are that I do not think he understands or comprehends the impact of major infrastructure expenditure and investment of this type on regional development. Nor do I believe that he understands the possible spin-offs that might arise. Nor can he foresee the benefits that would flow from the stimulus that this investment is likely to provide to what might otherwise be marginal economic activityâparticularly, for example, in the resource sector. Whether or not it pays for itself immediately is not the point, because we have to look at the long term and at the strategic importance of this sort of major development for the economy and, indeed, for the infrastructure of this community. I think, as I know others do, that this railway has potentially very important strategic benefits for the Australian community.

Two other matters that I want to address relate to the hypocrisy that abounds within the government ranks on the issue of honesty in election matters. I want to refer, in the first instance, to a submission dated 9 October to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters from Andrew Coward. Mr Coward was a long-time senior employee of the Northern Territory government. Indeed, for 10 years or thereabouts he was a ministerial adviser to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. Since leaving the Northern Territory, Mr Coward has been the subject of vilification by various persons in the Northern Territoryânot the least of whom is the current President of the Liberal Party of Australia and former Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, who has attacked Mr Coward for raising issues about governance in the Northern Territory and for calling for a royal commission into governance in the Northern Territory. Mr Coward has made a number of very strong allegations and I understand that he is in a position where he can provide substantial and substantiated evidence for his allegations.

In Mr Coward's submission of 9 October to the joint committee, he alleges a number of things which ought to be of concern to this parliament, not least of which are questions which are raised about the member for Eden-Monaro and the current President of the Liberal Party, Mr Stone. In his submission, he says that during the Stone and Nairn presidencies of the CLP in the Northern Territory, the party secured research benefits via clandestine subsidies of between $150,000 to $200,000, none of which have been disclosed to the Australian Electoral Commission. He also asserts that in 1994 the use of push polling in Darwin was authorised by the then CLP president, the current member for Eden-Monaro, and in later panic the cost was buried in a transaction chain with a third party. He also alleges that the CLP has operated a secret cash fund, paying some electoral workers cash and therefore contravening both the electoral and tax laws. He also says that there have been strenuous efforts by the Northern Territory governmentâand I can vouch for thisâto avert an independent judicial inquiry into a string of allegations about CLP governance and into the misappropriation and misuse of Northern Territory funds. Mr Coward wrote to Gary Nairn on 25 February this year stating:

quote.para: I have perused the CLP's returns to the Commonwealth Electoral Commission for the two financial years where income and expenditure for the June 1994 election would normally be expected to appear ... it does seem that, through inadvertence or for some other reason, the returns for the 1994 election may be incomplete.

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: ... the single matter of a southern contractorâa woman, to assist your memoryâwho undertook contractual work immediately prior to the election in the cost range believed to be $40-$60,000. This does not appear to have been declared, nor the source of finance, which ... might well be regarded as a breach of the truthful and total disclosure requirement.

speech.para: I wonder if these matters are going to be referred to the Federal Police, along with the other issues which were raised by the Leader the Opposition this afternoon in question time. There are plenty of documentary submissions from Mr Coward.

The other thing is the question of supporting Independent candidates. During the last Northern Territory election, in 1997, the CLP gave major assistance to a candidate in the seat of Macdonnell. His name was Ken Leichleitner. Mr Leichleitner worked for the Northern Territory Office of Aboriginal Development and was a candidate in that election as an Independent. Mr Leichleitner was escorted and squired around the electorate by a staff member of the then Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Shane Stone. This staff member was his campaign manager. Mr Leichleitner travelled in light aircraft provided to him by the CLP candidate, Mr Elferink, who travelled with him. This was a substantial payment in kind to his campaign. They were seen at various polling booths swapping and exchanging how-to-vote cards. It is no surprise to learn that Mr Leichleitner's preferences went to the CLP and subsequently the CLP won the seat. It is no further surprise I am sure to learn that not only did he go back to work with the Office of Aboriginal Development but, some time later, he too moved into the office of the Chief Minister. Now not only does he work in the office of the Chief Minister but he has nominated as the CLP candidate for the seat of Stuart in the forthcoming Territory election.

The hypocrisy of the government on this issue is breathtaking. It is very clear from an examination of Australia's electoral laws that this is inappropriate behaviour. The Labor Party are not saying that we have not been involved in assisting with the candidature of other parties or even of Independents, but we do not come in here and make the sorts of allegations which have been made by the government without substantiation. It is very clear that, in the case of the seat of Macdonnell, the CLP, under the leadership of Shane Stone, have worked hand in glove with an Independent candidate to the detriment of the Labor Party and the community and financial assistance has been providedâand I am sure that that financial assistance was provided on the basis that the preferences from this Independent candidate would flow to the CLP.

The Prime Minister has the gall to act in such an unctuous way when talking about the performance of the Labor Party, yet when the Liberal Party president is involvedâthat is, Mr Stoneâhe sits and stays mum. I wonder when Mr Coward's allegations involving Mr Stone and the member for Eden-Monaro will be referred to the Federal Police. When will the Prime Minister hold the President of the Liberal Party and the member for Eden-Monaro to account for the way they have misused taxpayers' funds in the electorate of the Northern Territory or the way they have misled the Northern Territory population? (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Parkes Electorate: Commonwealth Recognition Awards for Senior Australians
Collins, Bishop Barry

talk.start.para: âI wish to bring to the attention of the House some of the exemplary citizens of my electorate of Parkes in western New South Wales. The presentation of the Commonwealth recognition awards for senior citizens recently was an opportunity to acknowledge the good works of 10 civic-minded individuals. In addition to this, the Broken Hill Businesswoman of the Year event highlighted the commercial successes of 14 female entrepreneurs from that far west region of the state.

speech.para: Firstly, to the second year in which an outstanding group of selfless seniors was identified and given tokens of our appreciation for their service. In Broken Hill, Pat Leonard, Lily Anspach and Winifred Gould were presented with commemorative medallions and thanked for their contributions. Mr Leonard was rewarded for 40 years community service that included extensive committee work and a lengthy and pivotal role in St Vincent de Paul. Mr Leonard was most moved, but he particularly made comment of the fact that his certificate was signed by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Aged Care, Mrs Bronwyn Bishop. Mr Leonard took a lot of delight in that, because for a long time he was a very active member of the union movement out at Broken Hill. 84-year-old Lily Anspach highlights her many years of volunteer work with the honour of being the longest serving member of Meals on Wheels in New South Wales. She has worked for Meals on Wheels for 41 years. Winifred Gould's efforts include promoting the city of Broken Hill through her work as a civil marriage celebrant, in addition to years of kind service assisting the elderly and the ill in her community. Mrs Gould performs some of her wedding ceremonies up at the Pinnacles, which is a well-known landmark in Broken Hill.

From Dubbo, Isa and Jean Boland joined Jack Goss as award recipients for that district. Sisters-in-law Isa and Jean Boland have gathered approximately $10,000 each year for Lourdes Hospital, a local hospital, through volunteer fundraising over many years, working street stalls, selling tickets, cooking, doorknocking and many other activities, including until recently selling lamingtons around the street, including in my office. But apparently they are no longer able to do that. Mr Goss is an 88-year-old ex-servicemen. He has made a name in Dubbo both as a successful bakery operator of 47 years, providing employment for many local people, and as an extremely generous man to families doing it tough.

Maurice Wild from Condobolin was rewarded, at age 75, for his artistic talent and his outstanding successes as a veteran athlete in recent years: for example, running the Sydney Morning Herald marathon in 1997 and the Sydney to Surf event in 1996, along with other numerous Australian titles.

From Forbes, Gladys Johnson, Molly Neilsen and Meg Drane had their substantial efforts acknowledged. A prolific committee member, Gladys Johnson has also been keenly involved in bowls and golf administration over many years, along with the town's Meals on Wheels organisation and Manchester Unity. Molly Neilsen is a former Forbes citizen of the year due to her extensive work for children, mostly those with serious illnesses, including 35 years raising funds for the Far West Children's Home in Sydney. At 75, Meg Drane continues to shine as a committed community member in activities ranging from fundraising, committee work and hospitality to running an impromptu refuge at her home and leading research into salinity in her area.

The honour of being Broken Hill's Businesswoman of the Year eventually went to Maryanne Trinder who, with her husband David, has developed a chain of five restaurants in the city, employing about 50 local people. I had the honour of being on the judging panel for this award, and it was certainly a very difficult decision. There were three different categories, and in each category extremely accomplished people were nominated. Dorothy O'Connor was named the Regional Woman of the Year for her 46 years as a pastoralist, during which time she also home-schooled her children, completed an accounting diploma by kerosene lamp and was an active member of several health related committees. Dorothy O'Connor was very interesting in talking about the building up of her business. Some of the practices that she followed are those now espoused by various business gurus who travel around the country being paid enormous amounts of money. If they could have spent some time with Dorothy O'Connor 40 years ago, they would have saved themselves a lot of research. The Executive Woman of the Year was Linda Hearne for her work as General Manager, Business Services, of Australian Inland Energy and Water. She is responsible for about 20 staff.

Also nominated for awards were: thriving beauty salon proprietor Francis Stephens; outstanding self-made businesswoman Zonia Miller; talented musician and computer business manager Marilyn Harris; renowned artist and gallery operator Joyce Condon; accomplished administrator and medical service coordinator Noreen Byrne; community worker and successful racing club secretary Cheryl Krutli; and award winning White Cliffs bed and breakfast co-owner Joanne Pedler. I personally know Joanne and often have stayed in her bed and breakfast in White Cliffs. She is also involved in just about every community activity in White Cliffs that I know of. Pastoralist, health service pioneer and elected councillor Barbara MacMillan was also one of the nominees, as was committee member, long serving administrator and civil servant Carol Eglington. So, too, was vocational trainer and innovative prison educator Nolene Delatovic, who was spoken very highly of by the chief of the prison in Ivanhoe when I visited there recently.

It is always an honour to be involved with expressing the community's gratitude for the tremendous contribution these outstanding citizens have made over the years. It is on occasions such as these that it becomes clear what a huge role these generous individuals play in making our community a better place and often without much credit or fanfare. When presenting the awards for the senior Australians of the year, I often draw attention to the fact that it is not possible to present awards to every senior Australian who has contributed significantly to their community; it is more a recognition of the role that senior Australians have played and continue to play in our community. The continued prosperity of our regional areas is reliant on the recognition of outstanding achievement and promoting its rewards for the community. I thank and congratulate all the aforementioned for their role in making western New South Wales a better place to live for generations past, present and future.

On a more sombre note, I feel it is appropriate to mention my attendance recently at the funeral of Bishop Barry Collins, who was the Bishop of the Diocese of Wilcannia-Forbes until his sad death recently. Bishop Collins was only a very young man and his funeral at Parkes was attended by almost every priest whom I have ever come across and then some, as well as by most bishops in Australia and even visiting bishops from New Zealand. The Archbishop of Sydney spoke about Barry Collins and his sister delivered the eulogy. Both of those people and many others I talked to spoke of Bishop Collins's passion for young people and education. Bishop Collins was renowned for his use of computers, emails and other forms of technology, but both his sister and the archbishop pointed to his decided lack of talent in the kitchen area. He was quite happy to allow people who were better skilled at preparing meals than he was to do so, but he certainly embraced any other form of technology with gusto.

I recall one of my dealings with Bishop Collins at the opening of the science labs at the Red Bend Catholic College at Forbes where he spoke glowingly of the contribution and the role the federal government played in the funding of independent schools. The same thing happened at a function at St Laurence's school in Forbes, which both of us were involved in the opening of. But no matter how much he thanked the government for their contribution, he never let a moment go by without geeing up the students of the schools to say in unison, `The money is fine, but we need more capital.' That is one of the things that I recall in my time with Bishop Collins. He was certainly, as I said, passionate about education. He was born and raised in Sydney but he quickly adapted to the life of a bishop of a diocese which encompassed Parkes in the east right over to Broken Hill. It covers a lot of my own electorate; in fact, it is a great deal bigger than my electorate, I understand. One of the things that perhaps led to his early demise was the gusto with which he performed his duties. He used to travel extensively throughout the diocese. He probably pushed his body further than it needed to be pushed, but everyone spoke glowingly of him. He was well loved and he contributed an enormous amount to the people in western New South Wales.
