talk.start.para: âI say at the outset of my speech on the Roads to Recovery Bill 2000 that I will limit my time today because, unfortunately, as a result of the opposition's actions last Thursday, a considerable amount of debating time for this important bill was lost. So given the time constraints and the need to get this bill into the Senate for their consideration and to get the money out on to local roads, I will keep my comments very short. I received a letter on 29 November, which stated:

quote.para: Dear Michael,
Hepburn Shire Council thanks you and the Federal Government for the very positive funding boost for local roads.

As you are aware we and other Councils have not had the resources to adequately maintain the extensive local road network. Your sympathy and support on this issue over recent years is very much appreciated.

We will ensure that this funding is used effectively and strategically. Council already has detailed lists with priority assessment. We expect that much of the funding will be channelled into resealing of local roads and gravel re-sheets of unsealed roads. This would provide more extensive benefits than concentrating the funding in a small number of projects.

The problems with infrastructure require long-term solutions. Our community has recognised that ongoing rate increases will be needed together with improved Federal and State funding. We request that this four year funding program be progressively assessed for effectiveness and benefits with a view to becoming ongoing.
Thank you once again Michael, for your support.

speech.para: The letter is signed by Victor Szwed, Chief Executive Officer, and Max O'Shea, the Mayor of Hepburn Shire Council. An article in the Ballarat Courier last week quoted City of Ballarat Mayor, John Barnes, following the federal government's announcement of the Roads to Recovery Program. Councillor Barnes was quoted as saying:

quote.para: âI think it's very generousâ, he said.
âWe're very happy about it.â

speech.para: The Mayor of Hepburn Shire Council, Max O'Shea, was again quoted as saying that the funding was a `wonderful boost for local roads'. The Moorabool Shire will be receiving some $3.279 million over the four-year period. The article stated:

quote.para: Chief executive officer Chris Gillard said the funding would contribute to closing the council infrastructure funding gap.
âIt will mean some projects will be able to be brought forward,â

speech.para: In the Ballarat Courier againâit is a marvellous newspaper that covers a broad range of interests to my communityâthe `Farmers' Weekly' section stated:

quote.para: Victorian Farmers Federation president Peter Walsh said the increase represented about a 75 per cent increase in the annual funding for local roads.
âThe deterioration in local roads is a major constraint on growth in rural Australia,â Mr Walsh said.
The Commonwealth has called upon the states to also increase funding for local roads. The VFF endorses this call for the Victorian Government to increase its allocation to rural local roads.
âThe Labor Party made an undertaking prior to the last election to `commit resources to rural local roads' but so far this commitment has not been met.

speech.para: The state government did make that comment prior to the last election, but since then any requests for an increase in local road funding has fallen on deaf ears. It is my understanding that the Victorian transport minister, Peter Batchelorâand this is from a press release by Minister Andersonâis quoted as saying `local roads are the responsibility of local governments'.

The simple fact is that weâand I am sure honourable members on the other side do likewise and if they do not they are not doing their job properlyâspeak to our local government representatives to ascertain from them what the real issues are. I hit the circuit about 12 months ago to speak to all my mayors, shire CEOs and shire presidents, again, to ascertain what their needs were, and the single biggest issue was local roads. It was local roadsâtens the field after that. It was the only issue confronting my local government representativesâit was not the only issue, but it was the key issue that they wanted addressed. This is a very significant contribution to infrastructure in rural and regional Australia. This is a very significant contribution to local road infrastructure in my electorate of Ballarat and the general region. In the wider region, some $25 million has gone into local roads.

There will be some, I suspect, who, through ignoranceâand I do not say that in a negative senseâwould not understand the importance of local roads to not only rural and regional economies but also national economies. There are 1.7 million Australians who depend on the export industry for their jobsâthat is one in four people in rural and regional Australia. These jobs are primarily generated from produce that begins its journey on local roads. I was speaking to a constituent on Saturday night who advised me that a road near him carries a school bus and he got one of the children to hop out of the bus the other day and step into a pothole on this road and he could not see anything six inches below this child's knee. This is a local road that is taking school children to school. This is a local roadâand I am sure the honourable member for Corangamite, who is sitting beside me, will be acutely of aware of thisâthat is not only transporting children but also transporting families and transporting agricultural produce. This is the lifeblood of rural communitiesâthe lifebloodâand they have been starved of funds.

In 1991, all three tiers of government got their heads together and said that federal government would fund national highways, state governments would fund state roads and local government would fund local roads. The simple fact is that that agreement has not worked. That agreement has seen an extraordinary deterioration in local road infrastructure throughout rural and regional Australia. It is a significant matter for all Australians because all Australians have both an economic and a social investment in local roads. They may well be 2,500 kilometres away from where people live, but we all have an investment in local roads. They are pivotal to this country's economy. They are the lifeblood socially and economically of rural and regional communities, and the state of deterioration is absolutely appalling. In fact, I would go so far as to say that it is a matter of national shame that our local road network has got to this stage. Local government, as hard as it tried, simply could not spend the money that was required. That is why the federal government, in consultation with local government, has given a $1.2 billion boost over four years to local roads.

Members of parliament get phone calls about many things: some not so complimentary, some complimentary. My phones have been ringing off the hook in relation to this with people desperately urging me to get their local roads fixed. I have told those people that we are directing the money straight into local government, so that local government can determine their priorities. If you look at people like those in the Shire of Hepburn, they have already done that work. They know where the money is to be spent. They know it is desperately needed and they know it will be money very well spent.

I think this is one of the greatest achievements of this government because it addresses everything across the board. It is a national program with national benefits. I say to those people who are waiting for their local roads to be fixed: this is a partnership. It is a $1.2 billion partnership from the federal government; local government is making its contribution; and I call upon the states to match this funding, because they have as much investment in local roads as local government does and as the federal government does. I urge them, I plead with them, to please match this funding so that we can make a significant difference to what I think is a national issue. Given the time constraints and the number of my colleagues who wish to speak on this bill, I draw my comments to a close.

talk.start.para: âI will attempt to follow the honourable member for Ballarat's lead in keeping my comments short to ensure that all members of this House have an opportunity to speak on what is a very important bill, but I will have some difficulty in following his rhetoric because my views differ somewhat from those of the member for Ballarat with respect to the Roads to Recovery Bill 2000. This bill is about a broken promise. The Prime Minister gave an ironclad guarantee prior to the last election that the GST would not cause petrol prices to rise, and it was a promise that he reaffirmed after the election. This bill is the second of the government's political responses to the fallout it is encountering as a result of that broken election promise.

speech.para: It is a serious broken election promise and one that affects all people from all walks of life. As many members would be aware, over the last few weeks I have been participating in the federal opposition's fuel inquiry. It is an inquiry that is designed to establish the extent of the Prime Minister's GST induced fuel tax windfall and how best that can be returned to the Australian people. It has been a very interesting exercise because, wherever we go, particularly in regional Australia, we are overwhelmed with people who are keen to share their petrol experiences with us. Not only individuals, families and small business operators but also, indeed, a number of community groups ranging from Meals on Wheels through to community transport are keen to share their story with us, keen to let us know how John Howard's broken election promise is affecting them.

We have had local government bodies before us, as well. The member for Ballarat spent a fair bit of time sharing with us how happy local government is about the Roads to Recovery Program. Many of those local government representatives are with us in the building tonight and we welcome them. We are hearing a different story at the petrol inquiry. We are hearing numerous stories about the manner in which higher fuel prices are affecting the operations of local government. For example, council bodies that have fixed contracts for work they do for state roads bodies are not compensated in terms of those contracts for increases in fuel prices.

So there is a mixed message out there. In particular, owner-driver truckies have approached our inquiry in great numbers, explaining how they are being squeezed at both ends and how they are being asked to pass on fictional embedded wholesale sales tax savings and, at the same time, bear the brunt of higher fuel prices. This is an issue hurting people badly in the regions in particular. It is going to get worse.

talk.start.para: âI rise on a point of order, Deputy Madam Speaker. The member for Hunter has been going for four minutes now and has made no reference to the bill at all, let alone its context. I ask that you bring him back to the subject matter of the bill.
âAs I listened to the Chief Government Whip, I am listening to the member for Hunter. There is no point of order.

âThank you, Madam Deputy Speaker. I will make sure that I get my 20 minutes now. I thank the member for Ballarat. As I was pointing out, this is the government's political response to its failure to keep its election promise on fuel prices. I was about to say before I was rudely interrupted by the Chief Government Whip that the situation for the government is about to get worse. I heard the AAAâthe Australian Automobile Associationâtalking this morning about the prospect, due to maybe an easing in the price of world oil, of petrol prices coming down a bit.

speech.para: I beg to differ for one particular reason. No-one has considered this yet, but we all know that each year during the Christmas period the major oil companies take the opportunity to exploit the sudden increase in demand for petrol. They exploit the desire of families to travel on holiday. Every year it is the same: surprise, surprise, the price of petrol goes up by between 5c and 10c in late December. There is no solid reason or real explanation for this other than the fact that the major oil companies seize the opportunity to take excessive profits throughout the Christmas period when they know that demand is high and that the purchase of fuel is essential if Australian families want to holiday by car.

Let us consider what will happen this year. When the major oil companies force up petrol prices by five per cent in their attempt to take excessive profits by exploiting the Christmas holiday period, what will happen to the GST? It will also increase. This year there will be a compound effect. We have experienced higher petrol prices throughout the Christmas period for decades, but, because the GST is an ad valorem tax, the situation will be compounded this year. Ten per cent on 95c is less than 10 per cent on one dollar. The government need not kid itself that the political pressure is about to ease; I believe it is about to get even tougher.

What was the government's first reaction to its failed election promise? Its first response was the so-called Fuel Sales Grants Scheme designed to ensure that motorists in rural and regional Australia received a rebate of between 1c and 2c. It was a desperate attempt by the government to deliver on its pre-election GST petrol promise, but that initiative has failed. Throughout the short history of this scheme, a number of anomalies have indicated that it is flawed. The first triggered an ACCC inquiryâthe results of which are still pendingâinto suggestions that the fuel grants scheme is not being passed on to those for whom it is intendedâthe motorists of rural and regional Australia.

In the mid-year budget review, we learnt that the cost of the fuel grants scheme had blown out considerably. It appears that, rather than costing the government $500 million over four years, it will now cost more like $1 billion. The question is: why has the fuel grants scheme blown out so extensively? The government's response is that Treasury simply underestimated the number of retail outlets that were likely to be eligible for the scheme. That is absolute rubbish. A simple five-minute telephone call to the Motor Traders Association would have given Treasury the information that it required to assess the number of service stations adequately and to do a by-volume assessment of the cost of the scheme. I suggest that there is a little more to this than meets the eye and that some in the regions who are not eligible for it are claiming that grant. I question also how much of the money is going to bodies not originally considered by the governmentâsuch as mining companies operating in regional areas that might have a number of related entities that retail fuel to each other. Of course the fuel grants scheme covers not only petrol but also diesel.

I intend today to put some questions on the Notice Paper for the Treasurer. They include: how many large corporations other than the major oil companies have received money under the fuel grants scheme in the first three months? I hope I get a better answer than I did to my question of 30 August when I asked the Treasurer what proportion of the fuel grants scheme had gone to the major oil companiesâBP, Shell, Caltex and Mobilâin its first three months of operation. Despite the major oil companies' claim that they cannot pocket the grants scheme money because it has to go to the retailers, the fact is that they are the retailers and they have an enormous share by volume of retail petrol. If those companies run service stations, they are retailers; if they deal with a service station proprietor on a commission agency basis and the ownership of the fuel does not change hands, they are retailers. If people purchase their fuel with a Shell card or a BP card, the ownership of that fuel reverts to the major oil companies. Under all those circumstances, the fuel grants scheme money goes straight to the major oil companies.

How much do you suspect the major oil companies have received under the fuel grants scheme? It has been suggested to me that they have each received about $5 million, three months in advance. Yet when I asked the Treasurer to confirm that figure, what answer did I get? The answer reads:

quote.para: This information is not available due to the privacy restrictions of Section 47 of the Product Grants and Benefits Administration Act 2000.

speech.para: That is a non-answer. What is section 47 designed to do? It is designed to protect commercial-in-confidence information that agents of the Commonwealth gather when auditing the fuel grants scheme. To audit the scheme properly, they must have an in-depth knowledge of the operations of the retailer involved, and of course they should not return to Canberra and share that commercially sensitive information. But section 47 is not designed to deny the Australian taxpayer information about what taxpayer-funded grants are going to private corporations in this country. That is not what that section is about. That is the most outrageous answer to a question on notice that I have ever seen, and we must ask: what has the Treasurer got to hide? Why does the Treasurer not want the general public to know how much of their money is being forked out to large, private corporations in this country under the fuel grants scheme? What has he got to hide?

That was the government's first response to the political crisis that flowed from John Howard's broken election promise. This bill, the Roads to Recovery Bill 2000, is its second response. I must say that I agree with the member for Ballarat on this point: all government bodies around this country will welcome the money allocated to them under this particular program. I was on the Cessnock Council for eight years. I know, as well as anyone in this place, the challenge faced by local government in terms of meeting the demands placed upon them by local roads programs; they are always behind, always struggling with that situation. In my own electorate, some of my councils did relatively quite well: Cessnock, $2.6 million; Singleton, $1.8 million; Muswellbrook, $1.4 millionâand the list goes on.

But the question has to be asked: should all Australian motorists continue to bear the brunt of high petrol prices and petrol taxes so that the few who live in that relatively small number of streets can benefit? To put it another way: having identified or acknowledged a shortfall in local roads funding, shouldn't the government just have funded it anyway, without resorting to this conditional approach? That harks back to the old sale of Telstra: Natural Heritage Trust money, but only if you agree with the sale of Telstra. That is unacceptable, totally unacceptable. The government needs, first, now to acknowledge its broken promise and to move to reduce the petrol tax burden on the Australian motorists.

I have one quick point before I close. We are talking tonight about $1.2 billion under the Roads to Recovery Program. But what about the other $400 million? The government claims that the $1.2 billion we are talking about tonight will be shared equitably amongst councils. There is some question about that, but we will just accept that for a moment. What about the balance, the $400 million that the government says will be spent on the national highway and roads of national significance? How will those priorities be determined? If the government is fair dinkum about this, it will set a proper list of priorities and address the problems that have been caused by years of funding cutbacks to the national highway system. It will fund projects like the Kurri Kurri Corridor, a very important road project in the Hunter that would link the F3 freeway to the New England Highway north of Branxton; it will fund the Muswellbrook bypass; and it will fund the intersection where Weakley's Drive meets the New England Highway. It will fund other important projects that promote economic growth, such as local roads projects in Hunter wine country, in the Pokolbin area. It will fund projects that will create economic growth in high-growth tourism areas. If the government is fair dinkum about that balance of $400 million, it will set proper priorities and fund projects like the ones I have just mentioned.

talk.start.para: âI thank the member for Hunter for his dissertation on fuel pricesânothing to do with roads. I remind the member for Hunter that fuel prices have risen because of the OPEC oil prices rising 300 per cent. Maybe he would rather overlook that.

speech.para: Let me just strongly commend to the House the Roads to Recovery Program. Through this program, money will be allocated to local councils throughout the whole of Australiaânot just country, but city and country. It is a program for the allocation of $1.2 billion over four years, with an extra $300 million per annum going to local councils throughout Australia, as I have said. Through the financial assistance grantsâand there has been some argument about the methodology in allocating this moneyâthis current financial year, the government has injected into local councils throughout Australia an amount of $406 million; and next year, it will inject another $300 million.

The important things to note are the criteria for this allocation of money: length of road and population. That makes a balance between those councils with bigger numbers of people and those councils that have longer roads in rural Australia. I think the formula is very fair, it will affect all electorates and it basically works out very well. The grant will be tied to local councils for road funding. That will ensure that the money the federal government has put forward will be spent on roads. It will also ensure that local councils can make their own priorities. Madam Deputy Speaker, you would be aware of that; local councils can make the decision at the local level and not blame the federal government for some of the roads that might need repair but which do not fit their priorities.

I would encourage the states to fund the maintenance and construction of state roads for which they have a responsibility. Under this program, the states cannot move away from their current commitments under the guise of the federal government having provided more money. As we all would be awareâdisregarding the comments of the previous speaker, the member for Hunterâthe GST will provide a growth tax to state governments. Nobody would deny that. So, in four or five years time, state governments will find sufficient revenue to support their road funding programs in a better way than they can now. I would also encourage local councils to maintain their rate base to support their own funding programs and, again, not move away from the road programs that they had planned because of the federal government's injection.

It is worth putting on the record that this Roads to Recovery Program has been made possible by the sound economic management of the Howard government. We have a low inflationary situation, we have a budget surplus, and the government has seen fit to return some of these funds to infrastructure at all levels.

Just very briefly, I will refer to a House of Representatives standing committee that inquired into road funding and that produced a report entitled Planning, not patching. That committee tabled its report in October 1997. I was a very active member of that committee. We inspected roads throughout Australia, and we identified the ongoing problems of federal funding, state funding, local funding and the never ending problem of allocating funds to those three sectors. We looked at the private sector contribution and the possibilities of BOOT funding: build, own, operate and transfer. This, again, represents a very interesting set of possibilities, which have been implemented in New South Wales with the M15, the M14, the M2 and the Sydney Harbour Tunnel; and in Victoria with the CityLink project of $1.2 billion. With these developments, the private sector provides the capital, the motorists pay a toll and, after a period of timeâin the case of CityLink I think it is 35 yearsâthey return to public ownership. Also on that committee we had a good look at the relationship between the federal government, state governments and local governments in terms of planning, ensuring that the projects were properly evaluated, that their design and construction were first class and that the taxpayers and ratepayers got value for their money.

I notice the member for Corio has entered the chamber, and I will be referring to him in a minute because he is a very good supporter of road funding in rural Australia and he does support this package, I am very confident. Road funding in Australia amounts to about $6 billionâand I emphasise thatâfrom all sources, so roads receive a lot of money compared to railways, which receive virtually nothing in terms of maintenance and capital spending. The revenue sources for that amount of spending are somewhere in the range of $12 billion to $13 billion from excise and road related registration fees and local rates. We see the interesting scenario where hypothecation does not really exist in the Australian road funding situation, but I put on the record that a lot of money is spent.

If we look at the federal government's responsibility for road funding, over the years the federal government has taken on the responsibility of the federal highway system. I give a clear definition of that: capital city to capital city roads. The federal government is prepared to pay, organise, construct and maintain those important national arterial highways. The second sort of responsibility is for roads of national importance. The member for Corio would understand that, because the Geelong-Melbourne road is a road of national importance. The federal government contributed $120 million of the $240 million project. Thirdly, there is the Black Spot Program, which has been very effective in identifying the parts of all roads that are a dangerous part of the road link and that should be repaired. I note in passing that the federal contribution to the Geelong road is not very well signposted and that the $120 million federal government contribution is not fully recognised. I will be drawing that to the attention of the minister so that motorists on that road will understand that the federal government is contributing half the funds and that the road is not just a Victorian government project.

Madam Deputy Speaker, I draw to your attention and the attention of the House the councils who received money from this program. At the local level, the various councils in my electorate are very pleased with the funding that will help them enhance their program. The Borough of Queenscliffe, whilst it is a very small borough, is very efficiently run and very frugal in the way in which it spends money. It has a very good road structure. Fundamentally, there is no moisture under the road, because of the sandy nature of the soil, and the road structure will go on and on, unlike other roads in my electorate. Over four years, the Borough of Queenscliffe will receive $280,000; that will be very helpful to that small municipality.

The Surf Coast Shire, on the other hand, have a major difficulty. They have drawn to my attention that the FAGs are based on a census taken in August; they have a smaller population in August but in the summer period their population doubles so there is tremendous pressure on their road infrastructure, both for their main highways and for their smaller roads. I have been very aware of that problem, and very happy to represent their point of view as from time to time they have sought a change in the formula that leads the Surf Coast Shire to suffer. They will be receiving $2.4 million over four years, and they will be very happy about that.

The City of Greater Geelong is represented by the member for Corioâand ably represented, generally, when he is there. He is not there very much these days because he is representing the farmers throughout Australia. The City of Greater Geelong is going to receive $8.4 million from the Howard government, which I am sure the member for Corio will acknowledge at the local level. He will ensure that that money is spent in the rural part of the city of Greater Geelong, not in the urban area where he lives. That is where they need the extra money. The city of Geelong enjoys a good rate base, solid industry and an ability to generate considerable funds of its own.

The Golden Plains Shire are going to receive $3 million over the four-year period. We have a farming community where there is heavy traffic with fertiliser, timber, grain and wool, where again the important formula of the distance of road and lesser number of people will come into play to allow the municipality, which again has done a good job over the years, to maintain its road infrastructure. It will be very pleased with this allocation from the federal government.

The Colac Otway Shire will receive $3.1 million over the four years. It is in a high rainfall zone. Weeaproinah has 70 inches of rain a year. That shire has great difficulty in maintaining its road infrastructure because of the poor foundation and the extra wetness that comes through the winter months. It needs that money to maintain its current infrastructure, let alone build new roads. It has problems with timber vehicles and milk tankers. Some of the roads are gravel and the high rainfall does not help to maintain them. It has considerable disadvantages because of its geographical location.

The Corangamite Shire is a neighbour of the Corangamite electorate. My good friend Mr Hawker is the member there. Again, it has problems with milk tankers, high rainfall and the roads collapsing because of the foundation. It will appreciate, I know, the $3 million that the federal government has allocated to it.

I finish by putting on the record the concerns of the Great Ocean Road funding. We have 800,000 tourists per annum. They are of an international character and it is a bit unfair for the local municipality to have to take all the funding and maintenance of that road.

I hope that the state government will continue to match the funding, that there will be no cost shifting by state governments or local governments and that local councils will not apportion blame to the federal government having made this very good allocation to improve the roads. Money will be left on local roads and the local councils will continue to look after local roads for local people and for those local motorists who move throughout the electorate of Corangamite. I commend the legislation, I commend the allocation, and I hope after the next four-year period the roads of Corangamite will be in a much better state because of this allocation from the federal Howard government.

talk.start.para: âMembers of this House with an understanding of rural and regional Australia know the importance of local roads to rural dwellers. From an agriculture point of view, the maintenance of local roads is important not only to the economic efficiency of Australia's agricultural sector but also in preserving its social fabric. Most agricultural produce is transported in the first instance by road, either to another transport connection or to the marketplace directly. The run-down in the nation's road transport infrastructure over the past five years under the Howard government has impacted adversely on the efficiency of Australia's agricultural sector. I have travelled extensively throughout Australia in my capacity as shadow minister for agriculture, and there has been one constant message that has come through from farmers, local councillors and rural communities: the need to maintain roads and bridges in country areas. That is why over recent years rural communities have reacted with dismay at this government's failure to adequately resource the maintenance of Australia's road infrastructure. That is why they have reacted angrily while the government has lined the pockets of Sydney and Melbourne advertising agencies to the tune of half a billion dollars to advertise a GST that people in those communities did not want, while they watched their roads deteriorate. Now the member for Corangamite and the member for Ballarat and other members on the other side want to be applauded for their past negligence. They think that this Roads to Recovery Program will wash away their past sins of silence on this matter. The fact is that the funding of this program is based on a broken promise, a gross deception that was perpetrated by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer on the GST's impact on the price of fuel. Now the government wants to fiddle the figures in the Geelong region with a slick bit of double counting on the funding allocation.

speech.para: Firstly, to the Prime Minister's broken promise: members will recall the Prime Minister's promise that the GST would not increase the price of petrol. This is a Prime Minister who cannot lie straight in bed. He promised to keep Telstra in public hands, and then he sold 49 per cent of it. He promised never, ever to introduce the GST, and then he broke that promise and introduced it. He promised the pensioners of this country $1,000 compensation for the GST, and he ratted on that promise. He promised that the GST would not increase the price of petrol, and he has been caught out in violation of that promise, like a kid in a lolly shop, by the automobile associations of this country and the National Farmers Federation.

What came with the violation of the fuel promise was a massive billion dollar windfall, and it is that windfall which is now funding this particular package so applauded by members opposite including the member for Corangamite. Of course rural people welcome any expenditure on their roads. But do not treat them arrogantly. Do not treat them like fools by dressing this package up as evidence that this government have any real concern about the needs of people in rural areas. Budget after budget this government ripped the heart out of rural Australia, and now they want to be applauded for putting something back. The National Farmers Federation got it in the neck from the Howard government ministers for having the temerity to point out that the package was funded by a broken promise and for demanding that the government honour its original word.

The member for Corangamite is happy to support not only this deception in this parliament today; he also supports the government's rorting of the figures in the Geelong area. In the government's own document the allocation for the seat of Corio, which encompasses the City of Greater Geelong, is $8.4 million over four years. But you would not believe it! When you come to look at the figures for Corangamite, included in the $20.89 million for the electorate of Corangamite is a figure of $8.4 million over four years. So the allocation to my electorate in Corio is being double counted in Corangamite to save the skin of the member for Corangamite at the next election. It has happened not only in Victoria in the seat of Corangamite. It has happened all over Australia, especially in Queensland. The government knows it holds Corangamite by a slender margin of 4.5 per cent. The demographics are changing; the issues on people's minds are of substance. The fortunes of this tired, arrogant, out-of-touch government are on the wane and the Prime Minister is trying to save one of his stalwarts, the member for Corangamite, one of the loyal supporters who missed out on a frontbench position and was rewarded for his loyalty with the deputy whip position. Let us not forget that the member for Corangamite's loyalty to the Prime Minister was rewarded in this way. The people of Corangamite know that the GST, fuel prices, Telstra and industrial relations all have the potential to retire the member for Corangamite at the next election.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: âI am concluding my comments on the government's Roads to Recovery Program. I was speaking about the dickying of the figures that seems to have occurred by the member for Corangamite with reference to the funding allocation in the Geelong region. I know the coalition is full of rorters. We have seen several ministers prematurely retired from service on the front bench because they were rorting their travel allowance and, of course, more recently we have had the case of a senior member in the coalition rorting his phone cardâor having others rort it for him, having lent it to his son. I must admit that I know the honourable member for Corangamite is a good friend of the minister for small business and employment relations or whatever it is that he is a minister for these days, but I did not think he would stoop so low as to attempt to double-count the road funding figures in the Geelong region. I call on the honourable member for Corangamite to publicly state in the Geelong region that the funding allocation for the seat of Corangamite is not the $20 million that has been portrayed in government literature but is something more in the region of perhaps $12 million or $13 million. When he does that, I suggest he will have some real credibilityâeven though he is only restoring some of the funding that has been ripped out of Corangamite by the coalition over the last five years and the funding is being financed by a deception on fuel.

speech.para: The opposition have been critical of many aspects of this particular legislation. We have been critical of the way in which the funds have been raised, and the deception therein. We have also been critical of the fact that this particular legislation program has been dumped on the electorate for basically electoral gain. There is no real planning in this. There is no national transport plan behind this expenditure, merely some more pork-barrelling by the National Party and the Liberal Party, especially in rural and regional seats. It is interesting to note that 17 government seats will receive $25 million or more. I do not begrudge those regional areas funding from this programâafter all, they had the insides ripped out of the funding for their roads over the last five yearsâbut I do take exception to the fact that the honourable member for Corangamite comes in here claiming $20 million of expenditure in Corangamite when, in fact, he is double-counting the particular figures that are in my electorate.

I conclude with these remarks: the honourable member for Corangamite was saying that the coalition was not getting recognition for the $100 million or so that it is putting in to the Geelong road. I have to remind the honourable member for Corangamiteâand the people of Geelong know thisâthat it was only after Labor at the federal level and the state level had committed to funding the road that the Liberal Party came out of the woodwork and wanted a piece of the action. I am not one to look a gift-horse in the mouth. We will take the funding, and we will get the extra lane on the road. But, as a matter for the public record, it was Labor that flushed the coalition out on this: after we had made the funding commitment and committed to that road, it was then, as usual, Labor with the vision and, of course, the coalition falling in behind.

I find it interesting that the member for Corangamite lectures local and state governments on maintaining their funding programs. I thought he would have had a little more cognisance of the Prime Minister's comments in question time when the Prime Minister said that local governments, if they spend the money that they get on roads, could then divert their expenditure in other directions. The Prime Minister was giving them the clue to basically maintain their road funding and spend this money in other areas. I ought to mention, in conclusion, that the coalition cannot even tell this parliament the formula, the basis, on which these funds have been allocated. That is an absolute disgrace and it really points to the fact that this is a fly-by-night government, a desperate government, a government that has ripped the insides out of rural and regional Australia and now wants to curry a bit of favour with its Roads to Recovery Program.

talk.start.para: âThis government's recently announced $1.2 billion funding package for local country roads represents one of this administration's finest accomplishments for regional areas. Despite what the previous speaker says, it is all very well to have vision; but, if you cannot pay for it, forget about it. It is apparent that those opposite are unfamiliar with the challenges that are faced by country people, and that may be because they hold very few seats in country areas. They do not appreciate the challenges that country people, such as those in my electorate of western New South Wales, face and they have failed to appreciate what this stark turnaround in funding will mean to communities in my region. The people in my region, especially the local governments, are not foolish enough to be conned by any outlandish announcement that a government may make. There is no better barometer to be measured against than the jubilation of local government officials in my electorate of Parkes, which has been so long starved of sufficient funding to maintain the huge and crumbling local roads network. One ALP mayor in my electorate, whom I will spare the embarrassment of naming, was among those singing the economic and social praises of this radical reform of funding for minor country roads. In fact, the local newspaper did not run his commentsâas he told meâonly because he was praising the government.

speech.para: To assist those with scant awareness of what is consistently the number one issue in rural areas, alongside health care, it must be remembered that the roads that we are talking about are not necessarily bitumen. They are most often gravel or dirt, stretching for many thousands of kilometres, with hazards that city motoristsârepresented by those oppositeâcould only dream of, and they are often unpassable after rain. At their worst, local roads inhibit commerce and reduce the quality of life. It is as simple as that. Yet long-suffering country motorists are not seeking the same luxury of door-to-door paving enjoyed by their city cousins. They simply want roads that are passable a day or so after rains instead of a week after rains. They want a road on which they can travel at nearly 100 kilometres an hour between towns without literally risking life and limb.

Tourism is often touted as an alternative revenue source for some embattled outback communities, but it takes a lot of country hospitality to attract a family from blemish-free coastal highways onto dusty deathtraps or quagmires five or six hours away. In the same vein, attendance at a third of country schools is affected by wet weather isolation. So people on properties or in far-flung areas send their children away to school, only to have them stuck in nearby towns when they try to return for school holidays, due to a downpour that cuts them off the last few kilometres from home.

A CWA study nominates roads as the top priority of almost 70 per cent of country women, while getting stranded on a darkened country road, ferrying a sick child to medical help, is listed among their greatest fears. But those days will hopefully become a thing of the past when this funding acts as a circuit-breaker in the cycle of frantically patching up roads while others fall to pieces to the extent that local councils indicate that, at the rate they were being funded before, the job of resheeting roads would take 200 years. It just goes to show the absolute ignorance of those opposite, such as the previous speaker, who suggested that local councils might use this money to fund their roads, because it is tied, and spend what was previously their roads funding in other areas. There would not be a single council in the electorate of Parkes who does not spend more than the allocated amount on their rural roads. They are most welcoming of this package.

Let me inform those misguided critics of the benefits this funding reappraisal will bring to people in my electorate. Consider the economic benefits from improved transport routes for rural producers to get their goods to market faster and in better condition. In addition, this funding will not only make life better in terms of access to towns and the services, luxuries and friends they contain but also go a long way to improving the education prospects of our children, for the reasons outlined above. Of course, these improvements to the region's economy, its social network, its educational standards and comfort levels for travellers will also enhance the prospects of communities attracting professionals, such as doctors or nurses. Those opposite may be surprised to learn that there is one nursing home in the town of Tullamore in my electorate whose number one reason for being unable to attract nursing staff to their aged care facility is simply the road between Tullamore and Dubbo. The nursing staff simply will not risk their lives and their carsâand, therefore, their hard-earned moneyâtravelling along the roads to work in Tullamore.

The wider view of the road network's value has been a cornerstone of many National Party members' efforts to secure this funding. Credit should goâI feel a little bit of a Johnny-come-lately standing hereâto the member for Riverina, along with the member for New England, Stuart St Clair, the member for Kennedy, Bob Katter, and the member for Hinkler, Paul Neville, for their extensive and successful efforts in bringing road funding to the position in the government's sight in which it is in today. Along with groups like the CWA, local government can take credit for highlighting the importance of this issue to their federal representatives. In my area, that applies to Ray Longfellow from the Central Darling Shire, Rex Wilson and Ashley Weilinga from the Warren Shire, Ray Donald and Paul Wearne from the Bogan Shire, Peter Yench and Russ Pigg from the Cobar Shire, Peter Felsch and Angelo Pippos from the Brewarrina Shire and Wally Mitchell, Wayne O'Malley and Alan McCormack from the Bourke Shire. These and many others are the ones that have raised this issue time after time with me.

The pressure that has, quite rightly, been brought to bear on the government by many members of the public and by the local shires has resulted in this forward thinking plan. Individual members of the public who have added weight to calls for more funding include Louise Fisher from Nyngan, whose child missed 10 days of school due to impassable roads, and also Andrew and Jenny Paul from Cobar, and especially Gary Langley and James Harris from the Tullamore-Narromine district. Ladies and gentlemen, this is the time to take the effort to approach your local governments. This is the time when the local governments have the money to spend to upgrade the roads that you have brought to my attention.

Appropriately, it was last year's Roads Forum in Moreeâinstigated by the Local Government Associationâthat set the stage for the roads issue to emerge from National Party leader John Anderson's Regional Summit as a major priority. After turning all its guns onto the issue of dwindling country health services at the last budget, this government has now launched an all-out attack on the country's shabby local road network. The ability of federal funding to reach its local government target more effectively than when it first sifted through the agendas of state governments leads me to believe that such a direct approach should be implemented more often. This comment has been gathering momentum in my electorate as I speak to more and more people, especially those in local government.

I would admit that many people in regional centres such as Dubbo are not familiar with the importance of rural roads. But you do not have to go far out of Dubbo to run into people every one of whom knows how important this funding is. The message that is coming back through to me and that I convey to those in the chamber tonight and to those listening is: thank goodness that this government is controlling the purse strings. Yes, there has been some pain. Yes, there has been some restriction on government spending. How else would a governmentâany governmentâcope with an inherited $90 billion deficit? The word coming through very strongly is: thank goodness that there is a government that has been able to steer us through the Asian economic crisis and that has some money to spend on rural roads. It is going to be in a position to provide some much needed relief funding for those affected by the floods and heavy rains in the area of western New South Wales.

Driven by public comment and National Party input, the government have shown both the will and the ability to attempt to turn the tide, first on country health and now on country roads, and that constitutes a good day for regional Australia. I have been inundated with calls and letters from people in my electorate praising the government and thanking them for the work that they have done to deliver this road funding. I might just finish this evening with a brief quote from the Bourke Shire Council. It reads:

quote.para: This excellent news was received with much appreciation and a good deal of relief. This will allow council to catch up on maintenance work we have not been in a position to do. Council has been contemplating reducing our planned fleet by one grader ... and associated staff in order to remain within our budget.

speech.para: It is interesting that the opposition are having trouble even finding speakers to speak on this bill, such is the importance they give to country roads. The final paragraph says:

quote.para: This funding will allow us to maintain this unit and more importantly the jobs associated with its use. Council is most grateful for your support and that of your government.

talk.start.para: âI must admit I am very pleased to have the opportunity to speak. I thought at one stage that the government might not even allow me to speak. There are a number of points I want to raise in speaking on the Roads to Recovery Bill 2000. The point I think we have to concentrate on is really the failure of the government to develop a national infrastructure strategy and a national transport plan. Of course, we are talking about construction of the Western Sydney Orbital road in my electorate. The Western Sydney Orbital covers a number of electorates in Western Sydney. Since this government came to office, they have continually delayed the major announcement of the Transport and Regional Services portfolio until they have found themselves losing support in the bush because of their broken promises on the GST and on petrol.

speech.para: The government has only now announced this $1.2 billion of taxpayers' money to be spent in rural, regional and metropolitan areas of Australia. I do not begrudge the $850 million going to the rural areas, nor the $350 million going to metropolitan areas throughout Australia. What I did find offensive is, as I brought to the attention of the Speaker last Tuesday when I read it in Sydney's Daily Telegraph, a comment about how fortunate the electorate of Prospect was because the electorate of Prospect was going to receive over a four-year term the sum of $13-odd million. I could have got up in my electorate and said, `I'm a very hardworking member'âof course, my electorate believe that anywayâand taken the credit for that $13.2 million. But, Mr Deputy Speaker, as you and every other member of this House would be aware, we then got a breakdown from the minister's office on what was happening with the distribution of these funds. When you go to the breakdown of this $13.2 million over four years coming to the seat of Prospect, you find the one sum of $13.2 million is coming to seven federal electorates in Western Sydney. I went right through the listing to see whether I was perhaps exaggerating when I first read it. Of course I was not. I found that Blacktown City Council receives $4.877 million over four years, which is wonderful for that city. It is one of the largest cities in Western Sydney and one of the largest cities in Australia with the population that it has to cater for. But I share that money. The member for Greenway has it included in his electorate as well. I went further and found that it is the same money that the member for Lindsay, the Minister for Sport and Tourism, has for her electorate. The Penrith City Council has $3,637,225 for the Roads to Recovery Program. Again, I share it. I have that amount for my electorate of Prospect.

I then went further and decided I would have a look at the seat of Chifley, another close neighbour of mine. Not only did he share with me the Blacktown City Council's and the member for Greenway's sum of $4.877 million but also he shares with me and the member for Lindsay Penrith City Council's $3.637 million. I thought I would go one further and have a look at what is happening in Parramatta. I find that I am sharing with the member for Parramatta and he is sharing with me, as we share with other members around, the same amount of money. We are sharing the Holroyd City Council's sum of $1.473 million. We share Blacktown, Fairfield, Holroyd and Penrith. Then of course there is Reid. Reid has Fairfield, Holroyd, Parramatta and Strathfield.

What I am trying to say is, if we are going to talk about money being distributed, however it is spent, let us have a little bit of honesty in the reporting of it. This is one of the anomalies we have seen in the road program. Local government will welcome any money they possibly can get to assist and help them with their road infrastructure, but we have to have a little bit more honesty when we are talking about every electorateâ148 electorates around Australiaâand how well off they are going to be, when I find that one amount of money is being shared in seven federal electorates just in my area. I think that is deceitful and, more importantly, it is not telling the electorate at large exactly where the money is being spent. That is the thing I have a problem with. I would like to see a little bit more honesty and a little bit more concern about what is going to happen with road programs in the future.

As we know, $1.2 million has already been allocated, and we have $400 million yet to be spent. I have heard the Prime Minister time and time again talk about where he is going to spend the money in Western Sydney to improve the area, particularly looking at the orbital road. It is a major road. It is a major road announcement we have all been waiting for for a long time in that area. In fact, the only road that now connects the major freeways is the Cumberland Highway. If you travel on it for an hour and a half in the morning and an hour to two hours at night, it is nothing but a parking station. We are talking about growth, we are talking about expansion and we are talking about bringing more and more industry to the west to create more and more jobs. You cannot do that unless you have access to transport. You cannot do that unless you build the infrastructure, and the infrastructure has to be the roads to connect that region. We have the highwaysâthe M4, the M5 and the M2âbut there is no interconnection except the Cumberland Highway. If you are not going to build the connections between those areas, you are not going to provide the transport and therefore cater for the area's needs. I think we should be concentrating a little bit more on how we allocate money.
I was very concerned when the Prime Minister, on radio 4BC on 21 November, only days I might add before this package was announced, statedâand I would like to repeat these words in the House:

quote.para: I am not giving any secrets away to say that there was already enough in the budget to cover the Western Sydney orbital.

speech.para: If there was enough money in the budget that has already passed this House to cover the Western Sydney Orbital, one of the questions that I ask, that every council that is waiting for the Western Sydney Orbital would ask and I feel sure that every federal member that feeds into that area is asking is: when is it going to be built and when is the decision going to be made? We have not heard any of that, and that is why I think the Prime Minister needs to be reminded occasionally of exactly what motorists think of him and, more importantly, where he thinks he is going to have to take the money from. If it is already in the budget, why are we not getting some decisions made as to having that Sydney Orbital built?

The budget, I repeat, was handed down in May. I think the Prime Minister might have a little trouble remembering the date. I would like to remind him that it is now December. I can go through other records and find time and time again of instances when the building of the orbital was announced, yet we have no orbital and still have $400 million in this roads program unallocated. I just wonder whether we are ever going to get a decision from the Prime Minister and from this government as to where we are going to go with the Western Sydney Orbital. We have had a deputation down here from WSROCâthe Western Sydney Regional Organisation of Councilsâattended by a number of members on both sides in the Western Sydney region. It was certainly a non-political representation. We are all of the one voice. One of the most urgent needs in the infrastructure of roads in the whole area of Western Sydney catering for something like 1.4 million population is the building of that particular road. Without that road we are not going to see further advancement take place at the pace that we would all like it. I have no problem at all with what they are doing in the regional areas but, as I say, when we are looking at metropolitan areas we also have to look at the population and where it is located geographically and, more importantly, we have to look at how those dollars are being distributed.

I believe that if we are going to stop flood mitigation programsâand we have seen the flooding that has occurred in New South Wales, and we still experience flooding in our metropolitan areas when the creek systems that govern and go through our areas overflow and damage our roadsâand if we are going to give local government the money to build the roads, I think we should first correct some of the problems that are being caused by flooding and then maybe we will be able to maintain some decent roads.

I believe the government itself over time has been very quick to deny suggestions that the funding will favour coalition seats or even target the marginal seats in the coalition areas of rural and regional Australia, but one only has to take some time to read those figures again. I know the member for Canberra will not mind me mentioning it, but when I drive around Canberra it seems extraordinary that $20 million has been allocated over a four-year period for the road system here. The seven federal electorates in Western Sydney are going to share over four years $13.2 million, yet here in Canberra something like $20 million has been allocated for the same period. One would have to query the funding decisions that have been made for this area. One would also have to consider how the money is going to be spent and where it is going to be spent. I realise that it is the decision of the councils and I appeal to my councils to make sure the money is spent wisely and well. But, more importantly, I say to the Prime Minister, to the Deputy Prime Minister and to the government that you have to look at the allocation of resources. Infrastructure is an important thing and local governments are crying out for it. More particularly, we must have the means of transporting people and we must get industry moving. Then we will be able to create more jobs. The Western Sydney councils are constantly growing in size. The Western Sydney area of New South Wales is expanding at a rate far exceeding any other local government area around Australia. A number of our councils are here now at a local government conference, and our councils are saying that their need is so great and their populations so largeâand, more importantly, the rating structure is not as they would like itâthat they need the help of government at all levels. I would appeal to the government to make a decision on the orbital, make a decision on Badgerys Creek and, for goodness sake, start making decisions and spending money where the need is.
Debate interrupted.

talker.name: Kelly, Jackie, MP
Miss JACKIE KELLY
talker.role: Minister for Sport and Tourism and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

talk.start.para: âI seek your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker.
(Mr Hawker)âPlease proceed.

âDuring question time today a number of assertions were made by opposition members. I undertook to make inquiries and advise the House. I am now in a position to do so. With respect to the election conducted for the Penrith City Council in 1999, I can advise the House that, on 23 September that year, Senator Steve Hutchins, the state President of the ALP in New South Wales, wrote to my colleague the Special Minister of State, Senator Chris Ellison, requesting an investigation into various allegations. I am advised that Senator Ellison referred Senator Hutchins's correspondence to the Australian Electoral Commission. The Australian Electoral Commission referred the complaint to the Australian Federal Police on 15 October 1999. On 3 July 2000, the Australian Federal Police gave the results of their investigation to the Australian Electoral Commission. On the basis of the Australian Federal Police investigation, there was no further action by the Australian Electoral Commission. My colleague the Special Minister of State has today issued a statement outlining the above details.
âWas that ever reported?
âSit down and shut up.
âAnd I table a copy of that statement. For the recordâ

âMr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: you have given the minister indulgence. It is not helping the matter if the minister at the table, Mr Tuckey, who is supposed to be in charge of government business here, starts telling the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to shut up. Is that the way we are going to conduct this little exercise or are we going to have the minister just hold his tongue for a while?
âMr Deputy Speaker, on the point of order: my response was to an interjection that was totally unnecessary in the first instance andâ
âAbsolutely necessary, and you know it.
â`Absolutely necessary.' You have heard it, Mr Deputy Speaker. All you need to do at this stage of the game is see that there are no interjections from either side.
âOrder! The point is upheld and I think the Deputy Leader of the Opposition understands that the minister has the call. Therefore, I call the minister.

âFor the record, I draw the attention of the House to a previous statement by my colleague the Special Minister of State relating to allegations regarding the Lindsay by-election in 1996. That statement demonstrated that, following a complaint by the ALP, the matter was referred to the Director of Public Prosecutions on 23 January 1997. On 31 January 1997, the Director of Public Prosecutions provided advice to the Australian Electoral Commission. The Australian Electoral Commission decided not to proceed with the matter any further. I table a copy of the statement from my colleague to this effect.

speech.para: With respect to allegations relating to a former staff member, I have now had the opportunity to speak to him, and I advise the House as follows. He worked for me from December 1996 until earlier this year when he left to work in the private sector. The circumstances are that when he first came to work for me he lived at West Lindfield. This is a considerable distance from my electorate office in Penrith, and it was clearly impracticable for him to commute on a daily basis. Accordingly, because I had a residence which I was already sharing with a former RAAF colleague and had spare accommodation, he began living there and enrolled in Lindsay. He told me after question time today that he remained on the roll in Lindsay until October 1998. Until my conversation with him this afternoon, we had never discussed details of his electoral enrolment.

Following a media report on this evening's news, I should also advise the House that I have absolutely no knowledge of alleged printing of how-to-vote cards of a candidate who ran under the name the Grim-Reaper at the time of the Lindsay by-election. Earlier this evening, that candidate provided my office with a copy of the how-to-vote cards he alleges were produced for him. In his own handwriting he annotated names of candidates he alleges preferenced me as part of some anonymous deal.

Vicki Aird's campaign manager was a member of the Labor Party. She did not preference me before Ross Free. Rodney Franich was the candidate for the Shooters Party, and it is a matter of public record that he also preferenced Ross Free before me. Brian Grigg, the candidate for Call to Australia, did preference me. Such a preference is not exactly unusual, given the values of the Call to Australia Party. Kay Vella is, in my experience, a person of the utmost personal integrity who has had a consistent public stance of opposition to a second airport at Badgerys Creek. Given the former Labor government's attitude on this issue, her preference decision is also not surprising. I table a copy of the how-to-vote card provided by the candidate who called himself the Grim-Reaper.

talk.start.para: âMr Deputy Speaker, I seek indulgence.
âMr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. There is no indulgence entitled to a member of the opposition when a minister adds to an answer, which is what the minister has just done.
âThe point of order is upheld. There is no indulgence in regard to that reason.
â I move:

motion.para: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Deputy Leader of the Opposition from responding to the Minister for Sport and Tourism.

speech.para: I move this motion fundamentally on this basis: firstly, why was the AFP report never reported back and, secondly, why did this question of abuseâ
Motion (by Mr Tuckey) put:

talk.start.para: âThis is a statement that left more questions unanswered than it answered and it needs to be responded to.

speech.para: Motion (by Mr Tuckey) put:
