talk.start.para: âI rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. Prior to that series of resolutions and divisions, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition sought your indulgence to respond to the statement which the minister had made under indulgence. There was a point of order raised to say that there was no entitlement to indulgence to respond when a minister had added to an answer, which in fact is not what occurred. You upheld that ruling for some reason, which I do not quite understand, but the fact of the matter is that indulgence is at your discretion; it is not a question of a point of order.

âNo. That was not what was sought nor what was granted, nor what was sought by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Mr Deputy Speaker Hawker, the point of order of the Minister for Forestry and Conservation which you upheld was quite wrong. There is a discretion for you to give the Deputy Leader of the Opposition the option to respond. You just cannot rule it out of order; you have to exercise that discretion. He has sought it and you should consider whether you wish to grant it, and I believe you should grant it.

âThe member for Fraser has made his point of order. It is true that indulgence was granted to the minister and indulgence was not granted to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition chose then to use other forms of the House, which he exercised.

âI rise to talk tonight on the Roads to Recovery Bill 2000. I would like to welcome $16.75 million to shires in the electorate of Blair. That money, a Howard government initiative, comes from the Roads to Recovery Programâsomething I think that all members on both sides of the House would welcome. It turns my mind to thinking about what great things can be done with that kind of money, when we talk about local roads.

speech.para: In my electorate we have the shires of Kilcoy, Kingaroy, Nanango, Esk, Gatton, Laidley and Rosalie, as well as the City of Ipswich. We have all kinds of needs across that area for this money. Certainly, when it comes the Kingaroy Shire, I am sure the councillors will be looking at developing the tourism industry, particularly wine tourism which is really on the go. In particular, we have many difficult dirt country roads that serve those cellar door locations, and I think it would be a great opportunity to be able to use some of this money to assist the developing wine tourism industry in the Kingaroy Shire.

Turning to the Nanango Shire, we have many small roads across that areaâan entire network of roadsâthat deal with small communities and small holdings, and once again we have many underdeveloped dirt roads that require the expenditure that we can now undertake with money contributed through the Roads to Recovery Program. Another point that I would like to raise in relation to the Nanango shire is that, for many months now, heavy trucks have been regularly sent from Ipswich up to the Tarong power station in the Nanango area to provide it with the sort of coal they need to be able to keep the power station running. They use what they call `environmental coal', which comes from the Ipswich district, to keep the emissions from the power station down. All that transportation of coal by road is a real burden on local residents and a real burden on the roads themselves because those roads are being pounded by the coal trucks. There is an opportunity here for the shires, should they so desire, to contribute some of their money towards what is in fact a state road, the D'Aguilar Highway, and to provide that road with some extra support to meet the demands placed on it by all these coal trucks roaring up and down to supply the Tarong power station.

I should also mention the Esk Shire Council. In Esk, we have recently seen evidence of good cooperation between the state and Commonwealth governments. That area was very badly affected by the floods we had at the beginning of not this year but last year, when a great number of bridges along the Brisbane River were wiped out, absolutely destroyed by heavy flooding. Good cooperation between the state and federal governments resulted in those bridges being rebuilt to a very high standard. In fact, I was speaking today with the Mayor of Esk Shire, and she told me that they have been able to replace the timber bridges with concrete structures that will be of long-term advantage to the whole Brisbane valley, and that is of course very welcome news there. The Esk Shire now is in a position to be able to use some of the money from the Roads to Recovery Program to develop some of the networks that link with those new bridges and to provide support to local farming communities and also to the tourism industry which is developing around the Wivenhoe and Somerset dams.

I should also mention in passing the Kilcoy Shire, which has a great deal of difficulty with many dirt and unmade roads that are at times quite rough. This money will assist the shire with the upkeep of those roads. For example, the back road from Linville to Nanango is quite rough but it is very important to people in the Mount Stanley area who use it regularly. Funds are being channelled in that direction through the Roads to Recovery Program, and that is just one example of how the money can be used very effectively. Roads in quite remote areas such as Stockyard Creek in the Gatton Shire are under a lot of pressure and that shire will certainly welcome the moneys being provided through the Roads to Recovery Program.

We have seen roads in Laidley Shire with completely substandard drainage that turn into rivers when it rains. We need sufficient money to overcome those sorts of problems, and we will be able to do that only through schemes such as the Roads to Recovery Program. Another example is the Rosalie shire and the Blackbutt to Crows Nest road and the road through Anduramba. Some dirt roads in that area are washed out every time it rains. We will now be able to do something about culverts and provide a good, graded surface to support the people in that area.

The Ipswich City Council area is quite significant because it is part of the growing Brisbane greater metropolitan area. All kinds of feeder roads in that area bring traffic both to the Ipswich motorway and to the new road out through Springfield, which provides an alternative route for people commuting from Ipswich to Brisbane. While there has been some recent work on the road through Springfieldâwhich, as I said, provides a very good traffic route from Ipswich to Brisbaneâwe now need improved feeders to take people to that road. Each one of the shires that I have mentioned has an established and prioritised list of road works. We are providing $16.75 million to shires in the electorate of Blair, which will allow them to go that much further down their priority list when allocating that extra money.

The program is welcomed by every single shire in my electorate. I have spoken to each mayor and every one is absolutely thrilled with their allocations from the Commonwealth. I cannot understand some of the strange comments by members opposite. Before the recent fracas, I was listening to the member for Prospect complaining about the fact that the Blacktown council area had been mentioned in relation to a number of different electorates. The fact is that there is only one Blacktown councilâI am not from Sydney, but I know that. If members cannot figure out for themselves which Blacktown council the government is referring to, they should go homeâthey should not be here.

I have looked at the boundary surrounding the electorate of Blair and noted the areas that will receive money under this program. Some $40.4 million is being allocated to the electorate of Oxley, which will share in the allocation for the city of Brisbane. Some $28.6 million will be made available to the electorate of Ryan, which is basically the Brisbane City Council allowance. Ryan lies totally within the Brisbane City Council area, so I do not know what the government could say apart from, `Refer to the Brisbane City Council allocation'. Dickson will receive $32.8 million, and the member for Dickson cannot complain because she will be getting a share of the quite significant Brisbane City Council moneys. The electorate of Longman will receive $7.5 million. Wide Bay will receive $19.1 million; Maranoa, $51.3 million; and Forde, $22.5 million. All those electorates bordering the electorate of Blair are doing extremely well under this program.

I state here and now my support for this wonderful program, which is long overdue. The Roads to Recovery Program is aptly namedâit suits the purpose to which the government has put itâand I call on opposition members to support it 100 per cent.

talk.start.para: âI am very pleased that the member who has just resumed his seat is very happy with all the road funding going to his shires, and I am sure that all his shires are happyâalthough not as happy as he thinks they are. While local government will always be pleased to receive more moneyâif it is offered, of courseâone wonders what this government is really doing. Is this a cover-up for its concern at the extent of community feeling about the cost of petrol?

speech.para: There was a very interesting debate about road funding on the radio the other day. It took place with the announcement being made about the buckets of money that were to be rolled outâwhich were perceived as being a sop for not freezing the excise on the GST. The figure announced came out as `$1.6 billion extra in road funding'. Presumably that meant that all of the extra money that had gone to the federal budget would be spent on roads and that perhaps it was a compromise come to by this government for people having to pay the GST on fuel. But then the next line said that it would be over four years. So here lies the rub. There will be an amount of $400 million a year, and the government is getting an extra $1.5 or $1.6 billion. That means that this government is keeping three-quarters of that money. That does not sound reasonable to me. It was thought to be a con job by a number of the commentators thenâand I am sure they still believe that now. It will average out to be only $40 million a year. This is a classic pork-barrelling exercise, as those commentators have said.

What that really means is that the government is putting money into the electorates that give it the best chance of winning at the next election. Mr Deputy Speaker, you only have to guess at whose electorates will get the biggest boostâand surprise, surprise, there is the Deputy Prime Minister, John Anderson, who is also the Leader of the National Partyâa trouble spot, I understand, these days. His electorate will get one of the top allocations: a whopping $42.3 million.

It does appear that some of our parliamentary colleagues on the government side do rather better than those on the Labor sideâand it is not true to say that these are the electorates that are the most needy in the regional areas. Perhaps some of the most needy areas with regard to road maintenance are those on the fringes of the bigger urban areas, where roads have been neglected for years and there has been a failure to recognise certain roads as national roads.

The report on regional Australia Time running out highlighted the plight of regional Australian roads; it made a number of significant recommendations dealing with regional infrastructure, roads being one part of that infrastructure. There does not seem to be any proper provision for assisting with the specific repairs of bridges and culverts; new truck weights have not been considered in much of the planning; and there needs to be a national policy to deal with the general usage of roads, as well as the linkages of roads with other transport systems.

The motor car is the ordinary person's freedom, enabling them to live in places where it was not possible before. This has allowed industry to move out and labour to be more footloose; and people's independence from mass transport has been a part of Australia's culture. But technology changes and then that independence becomes skewed to those who have money. Whereas a few cents on petrol is nothing for those who earn $75,000 a yearâand many of those who work in management in local government earn more than the average personâthe cost of petrol is of enormous importance to those on low incomes, such as young families, and those on fixed incomes, such as retired people, single women, et cetera. These people may only use a vehicle for recreational time or for vital trips where there is no public transport. They are the people who are hurting with the price of petrol as it is.

Although at first glance the figures for the Lyons electorate in Tasmania seem reasonable, when you see who gets what and why, there are a number of questions to ask. Apart from anything else, it is just not enough. One of my mayors on the west coast of Tasmania, Mayor Darryl Gerrity, was scathing in his assessment of the funding. Councillor Gerrity said that it was disappointing but completely predictable, knowing that the State Grants Commission was involved. Gerrity said that it was stated at the weekend that it would be needs based, but needs were never considered; it was worked out by someone in Canberra with a calculator. I really have to agree with him: I do not think need came into it at all.

The government's letter advising of these grants stated that we have even got to have a network or series of signs basically saying how good this is. There are signs all over the place from previous federal government road programs. Apart from being an environmental nightmare and a traffic hazard, they are useless bits of information. When one is driving along the road looking for a nonexistent direction sign, who cares who paid for the road?

Anyhow, the government has made its decision. This funding is obviously a sweetener aimed at trying to suppress the anger of motorists because of the broken promise on the price of petrol and the GST. But, on that score, I believe it has failed dismally. Individualsâand they are the ones who vote, not the councilsâare still having to pay too high a price for their petrol. They will not be able to afford to use the roads. It is a good pork-barrelling exercise and it does not cut with the electorates. They see it as a conâand that is what it is. Yes, there is a case for increased local road fundingâbut not just local road funding. What about railways and ports? What about road safety and the issues surrounding road accidents? Where the program is weakest is that there is still no national infrastructure and transport plan. That is the problem with pork-barrelling: you do not want to have an overall plan because that takes away your right to fiddle around the edges and to manipulate the political systemâand that is what the Prime Minister is all about.

Yes, we need local road funding, but the government should face up to its responsibilities for a national transport plan. More importantly, the Prime Minister should understand that the Australian electorate is not stupid. People are not to be bought off. The amendment put by the shadow minister for this area, Martin Ferguson, shows the bill for the sham that it is. It fails to help those people who most need the fuel prices to be kept at an affordable rate. The goods and services tax has hit low income people in thousands of ways. This is one of the worst. We will have no national strategy for infrastructure development to deal with the thousands of changes that have occurred in both funding and technology. We desperately need such a strategy, particularly the development of a national transport plan that includes all means of transport. Australia is lagging so far behind other nations it is laughable. Our infrastructure status is holding back development in this country.

Government's role is to provide the means by which the private sector can develop our economyâthe interface between government and private money. This role is clearly not on the agenda of this government; the government are failing to assist business and industry build that infrastructure. The government ought to be exposed for the frauds that they are. It is all a matter of personal gainâkeeping personal powerânot the greater good of the country. I can only support wholeheartedly the substance of the amendment despite the fact that any money being given to rural and regional areas has to be a plus even if it is only a drop in the ocean of need.

talk.start.para: âIt is a great pleasure to be able to speak on the Roads to Recovery Bill 2000, an initiative by the coalition of $1.6 billion. That is the coalition's response to the need for urgent expenditure on Australia's local roads. The government understands the importance of local roads to the economy and to social amenity.

speech.para: In listening to the member for Lyons, I could not help but feel sorry for him, because he is actually caught between a rock and a hard place. On the one hand, he has to put out the lines that his leadership team have asked him to put out on this bill, and that is to complain that it is not enough, that it is pork-barrelling. On the other hand, he has to welcome the measure because he knows that the contribution of his own state government, the government of the state he represents, is actuallyâwhat is it, member for Lyons? Zilch! It is absolutely zero. Here he is. He has to support this bill, because, unless he supports it, the local governments in Tasmania will be the losers. On the other hand, he cannot support it too much because his leadership team will say, `You have to toe the line and somehow confect a rage.' In his speech, the member for Lyons struggled to be very sincere about his opposition to the bill. It was one of those speeches that you know the person just does not mean. Of course he does not. Every member in this chamber, if they go around and do polling in their electorates, if they go out and do doorknocking, knows that one of the consistent messages that comes out, whether they are in country Tasmania or suburban Melbourneâwherever they may beâconcerns the state of the roads. Often the complaint is very much one that can be dealt with only by the local council, whether it be a speed hump, a controlled intersection, a black spotâwhich we can now deal with through the Black Spot Programâor a pedestrian crossing here and there. It is a consistent message, particularly from the elderly and those who rely on their cars to travel to work or to the local shopping centre, to pick up their kids from school, to drop their kids off at school or to use their cars for the various activities which are required in living in suburban and regional Australia.

I know that in Deakin this is a most welcome bill. I know it is going to be a most welcome bill in the electorate of Bruceâneighbouring the electorate of Deakinâwhich is the electorate represented by the parliamentary secretary to the shadow minister for health, who is at the table. I also know it will be welcome down in Tasmania. People there recognise that the state of our roads requires urgent attention. In Deakin we have been winners out of this package. It is very gratifying to see the Commonwealth's contribution to the two councils that make up the electorate of Deakin.

Through this announcement, over the next four years the Roads to Recovery Bill will provide $1.2 billion in additional funding to local councils for local roads. This funding, it must be recognised, is over and above the current Commonwealth local road funding. It is an investment in Australia's roads has been made possible by the coalition's sound economic management. The member for Lyons talks about pork-barrelling and perhaps appeasing our conscience about the petrol tax. There will be a lot of motorists out there who will say, `If we have to put up with higher than normal petrol prices due to the fluctuations in the world market and the fluctuations in the Australian dollar, at least let me feel I am making a contribution to my roads.' We are making a contribution through $1.6 billion, $1.2 billion of that going into local councils and the other $400 million being additional funding for major arterial roads, roads of national importance and national highways.

It has been brought about, as I mentioned, by the coalition's sound economic management. We are now in a stronger budgetary position that allows the government to return a dividend to the whole community through the substantial investment package. Of the $1.2 billion, $250 million has been allocated to Victoria. Once again we can look at the state government's contribution. It is a little more than the contribution the Tasmanian state government is making to local councils. The contribution of the Bracks government, the government that is heralded as the people's government, is $14 million to local council roads.

I say to the local councils, `Why are you letting the Bracks government off the hook? Why are you allowing them to pull the wool over your eyes over road funding that should be allocated to you?' It is not as if the state government of Victoria does not have the finances. The money is there. We have been told about how cash rich they are. It would be great if they could make an increased contribution to our local roads, because I certainly have a list of roads a mile long that they could start working on.

The two councils in Deakin, the Maroondah City Council and the Whitehorse City Council, have been big winners out of this obviouslynot in the same proportions as those in regional Australia but, even though I am a suburban member of parliament and I have the interests of the suburbs at heart and as some of us on this side often say, suburban toil is well and truly alive in Melbourne, I do recognise that regional Australia has a much larger need. Their roads really have been in disrepair. Essentially they were built in the 1950s if not the 1940s and they have been going downhill rapidly since those days.

Maroondah City Council will receive just over $1.9 million over the next four years. It is an increase in their funding of $483,659 in the next financial year at least. That is a welcome boost to those people in Ringwood who will be smothered or choked by the traffic that will be coming out of the Eastern Freeway once it is finished being built in 2005. The City of Whitehorse will be receiving just over $2.5 million over the next four years, and in the next financial year $648,496. The additional allocation of funds will enable these two councils to bring forward numerous projects that are currently on their capital budgets. It will make a real difference to their existing plans to construct, maintain and improve roads. One of the councils recently told me that their five-year out plans will be halved by the Roads to Recovery Program. That is great news for the local residents. It is great news to know that a road that is projected not to be even looked at for the next five years can be brought forward and perhaps be attended to within the next two or three years. They will be able to see, for example, extra funding going into their local roads, in terms of reconstruction, kerbing, undertaking major repairs, resurfacing, building roundabouts, measures to slow traffic down and pedestrian crossings. I urge all Deakin residents, if you have a road that you believe has not been attended to for whatever reason, to make sure you go out there and put it to the council for their consideration. At the end of the day it still has to pass the criteria and still has to go through the council's own priority listing, but put it to the council because they certainly cannot turn around and say, `We just don't have the funds.' Sure, they might say, `We'd like more money,' but I would say there wouldn't be a council in Australia that would ever say that what they had received was enough. There will always be a need to have even more. So go out there. Nominate projects for urgent attention. For my part, as the member for Deakin, I will be reviewing these road plans and asking the council from time to time to give me feedback on the progress of the projects.

In the last minute or so that I have available, in order to facilitate continuing debate on this topic, can I simply say one other thing. The $400 million that has been allocated as extra contribution to the development of arterial links in outer metropolitan areas is welcome out in the east. We have had a proposed road that has been discussed and debated and raised in parliament by me and my colleagues the member for Dunkley and the member for Aston on numerous occasions as well as in the party room. We have met with three roads ministers since 1996. I am referring to the Scoresby Transport Corridor. We have been strong advocates of this project and we look forward to Peter Batchelor, the state Minister for Transport in Victoria, making sure that he crosses the t's and dots the i's, completes the design project and starts actually allocating money in the state budget. If the state government is really serious about the project and not simply pulling the wool over the eyes of the people in the east by saying, `We approve the concept,' then the efforts of the federal members in the eastern suburbs will be enhanced. We will continue to go in to bat not only for the eight councils affected by the Scoresby Transport Corridor but more importantly for the people in the area who have been calling for a link between Ringwood and Frankston for many years. It is a project which does need funding, which does need support, and I look forward to that part of the allocation in the Roads to Recovery Program considering the Scoresby Transport Corridor as a priority road for development in Victoria.

talk.start.para: âI am supporting this bill this evening, but not as the Minister for Transport and Regional Services might like me to. I am supporting it in the same vein as one of my local council representatives. His response to the funding when we had a conversation about it last week was, `It's better than a poke in the eye with a burnt stick.' That is a pretty fair assessment of this Roads to Recovery package and what it contains for regional and rural Australia. It is the reason that the Labor Party is supporting the bill but also taking the opportunity through our second reading amendment to highlight the issues and opportunities that the bill and the government's new roads package leave unaddressedâthings like the high price of petrol and diesel in regional and rural Australia and the failure of the government to compensate motorists for the effect of the GST on fuel prices; the failure to develop a national strategy for infrastructure, particularly in the area of transport; and the overall neglect and lack of interest that this government has shown towards regional development and infrastructure over its five years in office.

speech.para: Of course, local councils are pleased to receive more funding to help with the enormous job of keeping their road infrastructure up to scratch. It is the assistance they have been calling out for for five years, ever since this government's first king hit to rural and regional Australia when the bush paid for Peter Costello's surplus in the 1996 budget. He is now telling us that the surplus is up to $4.3 billionâand we are still paying in the bush through higher fuel taxes and a continued withdrawal of services. When you look at the $22 million of road funding announced for Capricornia in that light, you can understand that the general reaction of councils has been `Thanks, but ...'. The `but' refers to the years when councils have struggled along in an environment of neglect and indifference from the federal government. The federal government's belated concern for local councils is welcome, but it is hard not to be sceptical about its motives and timing. The `but' also refers to the opportunities missed in this funding package. Infrastructure is an essential factor in regional development and the future prosperity and quality of life of a place like Central Queensland. That is why we need a long-term strategic approach to planning and developing infrastructure. It is an approach that has to involve local councils identifying their needs and opportunities so that transport links and other infrastructure are designed for maximum economic and social benefits and not for maximum votes.

I was at a community forum in the town of Moranbah last Monday when the details of the road package were released to the various councils in my electorate. Many of the rural councils of the region were represented at the forum. Part of the forum was for the councils and other members of the communities to sit down and identify the strengths and weaknesses of our region, as well as the support needed to make the most of our opportunities in the future. Naturally, road priorities came up in the context of that discussion. The main priority is the roads that link upâor, more accurately at the moment, fail to link upâthe mining communities.

The shires of Nebo, Bowen and Belyando all stressed the importance of the roads linking the mines and communities from Collinsville in the north through to Glenden and Nebo and down to Moranbah in the south. I have spoken previously in the House about the Cerito-Newlands road, and that is a big part of this link. A road linking those communities and mines would make it much easier for miners to access employment from a number of coalmines, as well as allow easier access to services for them and their families. It would help to encourage people to stay living in the mining communities and keep those towns viable. Those linking roads identified in the northern end of the Bowen Basin would also be a boost for tourism in the area. Currently, there are too many roads to nowhereâroads that finish at a particular mining town and do not link upâwhereas it is a quite spectacular area with a beautiful environment which would be an attractive alternative route for tourists visiting the area, who are currently restricted to only the coastal road. If there were a reliable road through that area, I am sure that it would attract a lot of attention from tourists.

As I understand it, the emphasis on local roads in this government package would not fund the creation or upgrading of those roads that would create the strategic links for those small related communitiesâlinks that could bring those communities closer together in a practical way and allow each of them to benefit as individual communities from the growth and development occurring in other parts of their immediate region. For example, one council told me that the money would allow them to fix some existing local roads and address problem areas, such as sections of road that get boggy and cause problems for cattle trucks in the wet season. So that is why I say, `Thanks, but ...' Yes, it is good that councils in my area will be given assistance to repair local roads. But, after listening to the same councils and knowing that they have sat down and strategically analysed their infrastructure needs in terms of capitalising on their future opportunities, it is still very disappointing that the federal government has not taken regional development seriously enough to do the same thing.

Another road in my electorate that I would like to mention specifically is the Aramac-Torrens Creek Road in the west of my electorate. The road is a 270-kilometre link from Aramac to Torrens Creek and, as such, creates a link between the Landsborough Highway and the Flinders Highway between Townsville and Mount Isa. At present less than 100 kilometres of the road is sealed. The Aramac Shire Council, together with other councils along the route of the road, is anxious for the road to be sealed to give residents of Aramac and the wider Central West a quick and reliable route to Townsville, as well as opening up the other economic benefits that such a link would bring. The council is concerned that the Roads to Recovery package may not allow for the funding to be applied to the Aramac-Torrens Creek Road because it is not a local road. I know that representatives of the council are in Canberra this week and will be seeking clarification of that point so that the council can continue the upgrading work on the Aramac-Torrens Creek Road. I hope that the minister can reassure the council that the scheme is flexible enough to accommodate the priorities determined by the council and the people of Aramac.

My response to this bill might be different if we were in a situation where the government had developed a strong and strategic policy for infrastructure and development in regional Australia, including Central Queensland, and if this particular package were just a bit of a top-up filling in some gaps. But, when this is the pinnacle of the government's achievements or aspirations for regional and rural Australia, I have to say that it is too little, too late. My response to this bill is similar to the reactions that I have picked up anecdotally around my electorate: `Thanks for the funding, but ...' Thanks, but where has your commitment to regional and rural Australia been for the last five years? Thanks, but how about taking infrastructure policy and planning seriously and involving local governments in a long-term process with strategic objectives and outcomes? Thanks, but there are strategic infrastructure needs that are outstanding in Central Queensland. And, finally, thanks but we still have not forgotten about your government's broken promise on the GST and fuel, so you are still not off the hook for high fuel prices in my part of Queensland.

talk.start.para: âI am very happy to rise and speak on the Roads to Recovery Bill 2000 which will allow local councils all over Australia to do much needed extra work on their own roads, not just this year but for the next four years. There are three local governments in my own electorate of Gilmore: the Kiama Municipal Council, the Wingecarribee Shire Council and the Shoalhaven City Council. Each of them has plenty of work on roads in their local area, given the funding, as we all know that roads in most of the council areas have reached their use-by dates. That is probably true of all Australia. The three councils have very different road funding needs from one another. The Kiama Municipal Council has a high rate base and a smaller geographical area than the other two. Its urban roads are generally in good condition, and this is because the council has been able to efficiently manage its resealing program over the last 15 years.

speech.para: However, there are some rural and regional roads that would certainly benefit from this extra funding. Obviously no council has had time to develop a plan for spending the extra funding as yet. The roads I am talking about now are the kinds of roads that would most likely be in contention for receiving the benefit of the extra funding from this government. I know that Kiama's first thought would probably be for road safety. These roads could include the Jamberoo Mountain Road, which already has a safety audit done on it and needs guardrails and other work. The Saddleback Mountain Lookout Road also needs guard rails. The sort of roads with resealing needs might include the Sand Trackâor, as it is known, the Crooked River Roadâfrom Berry Beach Road to the Seven Mile camping area.

Then, of course, there are rural roads that have not yet been sealed. Roads in this category could include Mitchells Lane at Rose Valley or Wallaby Hill Road and Burra Creek Road at Jamberoo. Of course, there are also traffic facilities that could do with some extra funding, and these too would have a road safety element in their construction. They could include the proposed roundabout for the intersection of Allowrie and Churchill roads in Jamberoo, especially as the plan for this has already been basically approved by the RTA. Safety aspects at Kiama Primary School and Minnamurra Primary School could also be addressed. Kiama Municipal Council has an extra $174,453 per year to spend specifically on local roads, totalling almost an extra $700,000 over the four years of this program. This is in addition to the $1 million provided in the federal government's financial assistance grants over the same period.

Wingecarribee Shire has a much lower rate base than Kiama and covers a significantly larger area. Consequently, it has not been possible for this council to even consider getting all of its roads up to the standard it would like. With careful management, Wingecarribee Shire Council has made the best of a very difficult job. I was a councillor on the Wingecarribee Shire Council for five years and participated in many of those decisions, and I know just how hard the engineers and planners have tried to extract maximum value out of every dollar. Wingecarribee Shire Council will receive $680,549 extra per year for the next four years, totalling over $2.7 million extra in local road funding all-up. This is on top of the FAGs over the same period of almost $3.8 million.

The kinds of roads in the Wingecarribee shire that might be in contention for the extra funding are Belmore Falls Road in Robertson and Tugalong Road in Canyonleigh, which have a length and usage that could make them a priority. Belmore Falls Road in Robertson is a major tourism trail and is also used by many locals. Residents have been calling for its upgrade for over 10 years. Mr Archer last Sunday pointed out to me and to state member Peta Seaton the condition of this road, which has almost disintegrated along its edges. Tugalong Road in Canyonleigh is well known for its numerous rollovers, where drivers have lost control at speed on its gravel surface. There are large housing developments right along this road and the traffic is increasing dramatically. Village roads that might also have a high ranking would be Wildes Meadow Road and Nowra Road between Moss Vale and Robertson. Roads in commercial areas that may attract the extra funding could include Erith Street in Bundanoon and Station and Boolwey streets in Bowral.

Shoalhaven City Council is the largest of the local government areas in Gilmore. Over 60 per cent of its land is owned by State Forests, National Parks and Wildlife Service and other like authorities, with a consequent difficult rate base. This means that the council does not get rates for much of the land in its boundaries, which makes it difficult to fund major items like roads. However, the Shoalhaven City Council, just like the others, has made a considerable effort to ensure a sound plan of road management continues each year, despite funding difficulties. One of the exacerbating problems is that many of the 49 towns and villages that make up the Shoalhaven are on the coast at the end of long stretches of road off the Princes Highway. Shoalhaven City Council will receive an extra $1.2 million per year for local road funding. This is an extra $4.8 million over the four years, on top of the FAGs over the same period of over $6.6 million. Council is very excited and pleased with the government's announcement on the additional road funding.

It is a major infusion of funds to local government, gives council an opportunity to respond to a number of very critical issues in terms of its bridge and road network and will allow these projects to be brought forward for funding and for council to provide a far better service to the city. Council has a number of existing timber bridges that have reached the end of their lives, which require the spending of $900,000 per annum over the next five years. One such project is the Badgee Bridge at Sussex Inlet, and the provision of this funding by the federal government will allow the council to consider bringing this project forward. Shoalhaven council is also looking at upgrading a number of roads that have deteriorated. These could include the road from the Princes Highway to Huskisson, Sussex Inlet Road, Coolangatta Road between Shoalhaven Heads and Berry and St Vincent Street in Ulladulla.

All the councils in Gilmore are very happy to have this funding. Make no mistake, it matters not what political flavour they are. We are all working together to get the best value out of the Roads to Recovery funding. This federal government's initiative is the best thing since sliced bread in our area. Roads and their conditions are constant topics amongst the locals and a constant headache for local government. I welcome the Roads to Recovery Bill and commend the minister and his department for providing just what this country needs. Next for Gilmore, of course, we shall be continuing to call on the state government to fund Main Road 92 and we shall be continuing our push for the North Kiama Bypass to be declared a road of national importance.

The Labor state member, Mr Wayne Smith, today put out a press release. Does he say, `Thank you for the funding'? No. He whinges and gripes. He wants the federal government to do this; he wants the federal government to do that. Nothing is enough. But does he call on his own state Labor government and say, `Come on, Mr Scully, let's build Main Road 92'? No, not him. He calls on us to give more funding, when we have already put a whole lot of funding into areas that are not even the federal government's responsibility. So I say to Mr Wayne Smith: get back in your box. Try and do some of your own work instead of calling on us to do it all for you.

talk.start.para: âMy colleagues speaking before me have welcomed the extra $1.2 billion for local roads coming from the federal government, but we must question why Australia needs a Roads to Recovery Program. We need a Roads to Recovery Program because, over the last five years, this government has decimated the infrastructure, services and living standards of all Australians in regional Australia. Australia has seen five years of neglect in infrastructure and regional development. We have seen the government's refusal to act on the withdrawal of regional servicesâthat is, government servicesâand the closure of banks. We have seen the government's broken promise on petrol prices, we have seen cuts to local government and community jobs programs and we have seen massive cuts to social policy and attempts to run down our public schools and hospitals. Over the past five years, this government has completely neglected infrastructure and regional development. Over 12 months ago, the Institution of Engineers produced a report card on Australia's infrastructure which slammed this government's record in relation to infrastructure and slammed the government for failing to provide leadership in this area.

speech.para: If we go to the allocation of the Roads to Recovery funding, nine out of the 10 electorates which received the most funding from this program are held by Liberal-National Party members. The division which tops this list is none other than the federal division of Gwydirâthe division which is represented in this parliament by the Leader of the National Party and the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, who announced this policy. I thought that the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry was going to introduce this bill when I read in last Thursday's Notice Paper that Mr Truss was introducing `a bill for an act relating to the pig industry'. We have heard a lot about the stench of pigs and the stench of pork about this program, and many others in this debate have spoken of pork-barrelling and the like.

One of the reasons for this, as I have just mentioned, is that nine out of the 10 electorates receiving the most funding are held by Liberal Party or National Party members. We have the announcement of this policy 12 months out from an election and 12 months after that damning report card from the Institution of Engineers about the decimation of regional services in Australia. The government is keeping its options open to make further major announcements regarding roads closer to the federal election. The letter I received from the Minister for Transport and Regional Services and Leader of the National Party says there is:

quote.para: ... an additional $400 million in total over four years from 2001-02 for developing key arterial link roads in outer metropolitan areas. The Government will provide details of this programme next year once it has assessed and prioritised potential projects.

speech.para: To me, that reeks of pork-barrelling, and more roads announcements are going to be made by the government much closer to the election to enhance their doomed electoral prospects. As I said, I welcome this road funding, but I emphasise, as many speakers before me have done, the double counting that has been used by the government in relation to the allocation of the funds. Many examples have been provided. I will mention just one that has been provided by the shadow minister for transport and regional services. It says:

quote.para: The documents reveal that Brisbane Council gets $28.6 million over four years, but that money has been double counted in each of the Federal seats of Bowman, Brisbane, Dickson, Fadden, Griffith, Lilley, Moreton, Oxley, Petrie, Rankin and Ryan.

speech.para: This is a huge example of double-counting, and it happens to a huge extent not only in the capital cities but also in my own region, the Newcastle-Hunter area. Last Tuesday, after the announcement was made, the front page of the Newcastle Herald had the headline `$44m roads boost'. This was announced by the Hunter based Liberal senator, John Tierney, and it was reported by the Newcastle Herald. I attempted to clarify that position and to say that the good senator as well as the Newcastle Herald double counted those figures and neglected to add up the exact amount that each of those councils was allocated. It took the figures that came from the minister and added those together to come to a figure of $44 million. But, if you actually add together the figures that were allocated to each of the councils in those five federal electorates, they come to $25,789,780. That is almost $19 million less than that proposed by Senator Tierney and reported by the Newcastle Herald. As I said, I tried to clarify the matter with the Newcastle Herald in a letter to the editor on that Tuesday. That has not been published. I clarified it with the political reporter from the Newcastle Herald on Friday. He said, `This will make a good story, Kelly,' but that has not been published. I just wonder where the Newcastle Herald actually lies in its reporting of government policies. Does it want the truth or does it want the double counting propaganda which is coming from this government?

What this country needs, particularly in regional Australia, is the establishment of a national infrastructure advisory council, a council which was announced by the member for Batman. It is an announcement which has been applauded by those with a commitment to Australia's infrastructure and those who will be represented on the advisory council. They are representatives from industry, finance, engineering, planning, academia, local government and regional Australia.

During this debate, there has been a lot of discussion of the formula used to allocate this $1.2 billion to local governments. The government claim to be using a formula developed by Labor in 1991 in relation to state grants. However, they are yet to actually disclose to the opposition and to the public the particular formula that they have used. It is interesting to note that during this period my predecessor, Bob Brown, was the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support. We can have a look at what Labor had in place as part of a national infrastructure strategy at that time. That period saw an expansion of the national roads system from 16,000 kilometres to 18,000 kilometres. That period also saw the construction of the highways linking Adelaide and Sydney, and Melbourne and Brisbane.

The national highway system was an initiative of the Whitlam government, and it meant that all of the major highways linking capital cities were taken completely out of state government budgets when the federal government accepted responsibility for supplying every cent that was spent on construction and maintenance, initially on the 16,000 kilometres of road and eventually on the 18,000 kilometres of road. The results of those policies were dramatic improvements in our roads. We saw dual divided highways, overpasses, cloverleaves and all of the contemporary characteristics of roads which make them both more efficient and safer now.

As a result of all these improvements in the national highway and road infrastructure, literally thousands of lives were saved. We do not know exactly whose lives those are, but we do know with absolute certainty that they are there. We know that the lives that have been saved are those of our parents, our children, our aunts and our uncles, our friends and our grandparents. While we welcome this extra funding for roadsâbecause it is going to save further lives; it is going to save the lives of our families and our friendsâwe call on the government to come clean with the formula that has been used to allocate it and to prove to the electorate that they are not pork-barrelling and are not using this to win the next federal election. Then we would be happy to support it.
Motion (by Mr Wakelin) agreed to:

talk.start.para: âIn addressing the Roads to Recovery Bill 2000 in detail, I say that the Australian electorate should understand that this evening the occupants of the government benches have yet again voted against the call for petrol price excise reform to take the pressure off motorists. That was the nature of the second reading amendment moved by the Labor Party. With this bill the government has made the call that community concerns about petrol prices will be allayed by road funding. I would argue that that has not been a good call out in the electorate. The community wants petrol price relief, and that message will continue to be hammered by the Labor opposition. The truth of the matter is that the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Transport and Regional Services was hoping that the Labor Party would oppose this bill. We sought to establish that the debate is not just about the issue of road funding but also, importantly, about the Howard government's broken promise that the impact of the GST on petrol prices would be virtually non-existent.

speech.para: The bill is a rushed, sloppy bill. Speaking as someone who was required to consider the bill in detail, I am fully aware of the lack of understanding of the nature of the bill and the fact that it was developed without proper consideration from a legislative point of view. I also indicate to the House that the government have allowed the bill and the requirement for additional road funding to be tainted by their attempt to overly politicise the introduction of the bill into the parliament and the law. The minister for transport has done almost everything possible with this bill to force the opposition to vote against it. For example, the minister has ignored requests from the opposition for basic clarification of and information on the bill. The minister has allowed his office to issue deceptive media releases and information that inflates how each electorate will receive money. The minister has also allowed an inaccurate explanatory memorandum to circulate without correction. And, finally, the minister has provided misleading and improper information on how the money was allocated to particular states and territories and within those states and territories.

From the opposition's point of view, I indicate that there is concern in the community about the fact that the government still lacks an integrated approach to transport reform and planning. Calls have been made in recent days from other transport sectors, such as rail, for a proper analysis of the difficulties constraining road funding in Australia and for an ongoing commitment to improve our access to rail infrastructure. The message from the road, rail, aviation and shipping industries is the need for national leadership and an intermodal approach to transport funding. Throwing a significant amount of money at roads is important, but it is just one part of what is needed. We need a proper analysis of transport planning and an overall strategic framework to go forward.

Going to the bill itself, I point to obvious and apparent deficiencies. In Senate estimates last Friday, Senator Ian Macdonald failed to answer questions posed by Senator Mackay relating to those deficiencies. I also remind the House of the fact that Senator Ian Macdonald refused to answer other questions about information in the minister's media release about breakdowns in rural and metropolitan spending which adds to the concerns of the Labor Party. Some of the deficiencies in the bill were raised last Wednesday evening in a briefing from the department and the minister's office. That was the first opportunity for the Labor opposition to see this bill, which was introduced into the parliament on Thursday morning and guillotined without proper consideration in debate this evening.

The actual explanatory memorandum was not available until after 10 p.m. on the Wednesday preceding its introduction into the House. If the government had put any thought into the package, it would have been better prepared and organised than that. At the meeting last Wednesday afternoon, the first time we saw the bill, my office identified some obvious deficiencies and requested additional information from the minister's office and the department. None of that information has been forthcoming. For that reason, on Thursday, 30 November, I wrote to the minister to formally request that clarification and information. Unfortunately, that information has still not arrived. I only hope that the minister in responding this evening is prepared to answer those questions raised by me by way of correspondence last Thursday and in the briefing between his office, the department and my office on the Wednesday evening preceding the introduction of the bill. (Extension of time granted)

Labor's concerns with the bill also go to the lack of clarity about the ability of the minister to change the conditions of the funding under the bill. The bill at subclause 7(1) requires the minister to gazette the conditions to apply to the funding under the act. Subclause 7(2) goes on to list the conditions that must be included; namely, those that restrict the expenditure to road funding. Subclause 7(3) empowers the minister to impose other conditions, such as recovery for breaches and compliance with the administrative guidelines. Then, somewhat curiously, given the apparent effort to ensure this money is spent on roads, subclause 7(4) gives total discretion to the minister on what he can include in those conditions. Then subclause 7(5) gives the minister open slather, with minimal scrutiny, the ability to revoke or vary any of the conditions. The explanatory memorandum is in gross discord with the wording of the bill. The explanatory memorandum says:

quote.para: In varying any conditions, the Minister will have to ensure that the compulsory conditions in subclause (2) are maintained.

speech.para: As I have said, this is not what the bill says. So there is all this talk about the funds going to roads, but the conditions are not there and the minister has a lot of flexibility.

I also remind the House that in estimates last Friday, the impression pushed by Senator Macdonald and the department was that the flexibility is all with the councils in terms of priorities and the direction of their spending. However, the bill says at subclause 6(2) that the amounts and timing are to be determined by the minister. That gives the minister a lot of ability to influence this process. While we have been told by the department that the allocation will be quarterly in advance, that is not spelt out to help with planning purposes or to give them flexibility. The explanatory memorandum also says that small or local government bodies will receive their full entitlement in one instalment. That may make sense, but the bill and the explanatory memorandum are light on detail and process. I believe the minister should clarify these issues this evening.

The government also keep insisting that this program is not pork-barrelling, but they cannot tell us the exact formula applied to allocate funding between the states and territories and cannot guarantee that the local government bodies will have the autonomy over those funds that they think. If you do not think it is pork-barrelling, then you cannot have serious reservations about a process, the details of which they will not release, that delivers the highest amounts of money, the top 17 amounts, to government seats. The laws of probability are challenged by those statistics. To top it off, they apply a process to bring in this legislation that at best pushes the boundaries of procedure and ethics of this House.

In conclusion, Labor will support this bill because we understand that local government wants the work to start as soon as possible, but Labor will not stop the pursuit of transparency and accountability. We also demand that the details of the formula and its application and implementation are put out in the public domain for proper debate and consideration. Labor will not stop doing whatever we can to ensure that the funds are spent according to the nation's needs. I also remind the House that, in voting against the Labor Party's second reading amendment this evening, the government rejected a proposition which was about implementing the promise made by the government at the last election on the issue of petrol prices. That promise was that the GST on its implementation would have no impact on the price of petrol around Australia.

I remind the House that the member for Makin sought to create the impression today that she was lobbying very hard on the issue of petrol prices because she presented a petition which was collected in her electorate. The member for McEwen also sought to big-note herself to her electorate, saying that she was basically going to stand the government up on the issue of petrol prices. But despite the presentation of that petition by the member for Makin and despite those words of the member for McEwen, when push came to shove this evening, the member for McEwen joined with the member for Makin in actually, I suppose, misleading their electorates about what they were going to do when it came to putting their hands up in Canberra to vote in favour of relief on the issue of petrol prices. I think it comes back to honesty and integrity in government. This bill and this debate this evening clearly prove that when it comes to a vote, there is a group of government backbenchers who say one thing in their electorate and do another thing in Canberra. The Labor Party will continue to hound these people in these electorates and continue to tell their electors that it is about time honesty and integrity actually prevailed in government. The Deputy Prime Minister and others who are part of this government promised at the last election that, yes, they would do something on road funding but they would also make sure that the price of petrol would not increase because of the GST. They failed yet again. (Time expired)

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
Mr ANDERSON
talker.role: Deputy Prime Minister

talk.start.para: âThe opposition has launched a baseless attack on the allocation of $2.5 billion to local government authorities under the federal government's Roads to Recovery Program, which delivers funding for local roads.
âThe pork is sizzling.
âThe pork is sizzlingâdear, oh dear! Will you listen to it! Each council in Australia has been given a Roads to Recovery allocationâ
âPut your notes away and speak from the heart.
(Mr Nehl)âThe member for Braddon is not in his place and will be silent.
âWhere did the other $1.3 billion come from? You just said $2.5 billion.
âThe member for Prospect! The Deputy Prime Minister has the call.
âWhere's the formula?
âEach council in Australia has been given a Roads to Recovery allocation based on the federal assistance grants, or the FAGs, formula that applies in their respective state.
âThe member for McMillan is not in his place and will be silent.
âWhy do you hate Tasmanians?
âI warn the member for McMillan.

âFAGs are determined on the basis of allocations made by local government grants commissions in each state and territory. The commissions are statutory bodies headed by an independent chair appointed by the state or territory government. Other members may include representatives of local government or state government departments responsible for local government matters. FAGs are distributed each year as part of the federal budget. They have two components: a general purpose component and an identified roads component. The identified roads component varies from state to stateâI emphasise that: it varies from state to stateâand is based on calculations relating directly to the cost of maintaining existing roads.

speech.para: We have, as I have said, allocated $1.2 billion for this program. The state by state breakdown is as follows: New South Wales, $340 million; Victoria, $250 million; Queensland, $250 million; Western Australia $180 million; South Australia, $100 million; Tasmania, $40 million; the Northern Territory, $20 million; and the Australian Capital Territory, $20 millionâ$1.2 billion over the level of funding that Labor has been providing historically and no doubt would have been providing to this point in time. The distribution was based onâone minute they are howling for an explanation and when you offer it they are not interested in itâhistorical precedence, length of roads and population. When we worked it through, we took the opportunity to correct some historical anomalies in the division of grants such as the undeniable fact that South Australia has got a raw deal in the past.

talk.start.para: âOrder! Mem-bers on my left!
âMembers opposite will not even commit themselves to the principle of Roads to Recovery. Every state and territory is a heap better off and they will not evenâ
âThey are not rorters like you.
âMr Deputy Speakerâ
âYou rorted this package.
âThe member for Batman has had his turn.
âHe accused me of being a rorter.
âYou rorted the formula.
âI did not rort the formula.
âThe member for Batman will withdraw.
âThank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker.
âWhy? It is a rort and everyone knows it. The formula is not the formula he is claiming it to be.
âMr Deputy Speaker, he called me a rorter.
âI did not. I said you rorted it.
âNo. You said he was a rorter and you will withdraw.
âOn a point of order, Mr Deputy Speakerâ
âNo, I am dealing with the member for Batman. You are defying the chair.
âYou will get your point of order after he has withdrawn.
âThe point of order is about your ruling.
âThe Manager of Opposition Business.

âThank you. Are you saying that we cannot now use the word `rort' or `rorter' in this parliament, that that is unparliamentary or that that is disorderly? What is the context in which you are requiring this allegation to be withdrawn, given the history of failures of ministers to withdraw much more serious allegations, Mr Deputy Speaker.
âCome on, Bob.
âYou are not saying that that is not true!

âNo, the point that I am making is that the member for Batman accused the minister of being a rorter. After the business of the House last week, I believe that is unparliamentary and I have asked the member for Batman to withdraw.

âMr Deputy Speaker, the issue of rorting does not relate to the member's own personal standards; it relates to a bill that is put in place that rorts the formula going to the question of road funding, which he has admitted in the House is not the formula which previously existed. He personally is not a rorter; his government is a rorter.
âMember for Batman! Order! I do not want to have a further debate on this.
âYou called me a rorter, Martin.

âI will withdraw the reference to the minister as a rorter.
âNo, no qualification.
âBut the system he is speaking about is rorted.

âI have indicated that I have withdrawn the reference to the minister as a rorter, but the system he is speaking about tonight is rorted.
âThank you. The minister has the call.
âSo, Mr Deputy Speakerâ(Time expired)
âI just want to confirm that the Northern Territory will receive $20 million; the minister's electorate will get $42 million. That is a rort.
