talk.start.para: âI have a serious matter to raise in the House tonight and it relates to an important infrastructure project in my electorate which has been ignored by the Howard government, and I am talking about the Pakenham Bypass. The Pakenham Bypass has been identified by all of the municipalities that make up the Gippsland local government network as the key infrastructure priority for the entire Gippsland region.

speech.para: The Beaconsfield-Pakenham section of the Princes Highway, which is what we are talking about, is the worst accident area in the state. Accidents over the past five years have now grown to more than 100 and are increasing exponentially. The Princes Highway near Army Road in Pakenham has been identified by the RACV as the state's worst accident black spotâ48 crashes and seven deaths in five years. This section of the highway is twice as deadly as any comparable road and its accident rate is five times the national average. In the Shire of Cardinia alone, hundreds of families travel to and from schools along the highway in and near Pakenham five days every week, and there is considerable parental concern at the extreme accident risk.

Despite this and the obvious need for this project, we have seen almost no action at all being taken by the Howard government in relation to this project. As I mentioned before, the Gippsland local government network, as the representatives of some 280,000 people, have identified this as the number one infrastructure priority right across the Gippsland region. So this is not something which is not considered seriously by the people in Gippsland or by the people in Pakenham; it is something which is thought of as being our number one priority. Despite this fact, we have seen hardly any attention at all given to this project by the Howard government. And despite the number of people who are increasingly having accidents and even dying on this bit of road, we have seen hardly any attention given to this project by the Howard administration.

The state government has committed to construct the $200 million Pakenham Bypass on a dollar for dollar basis by 2005. So we have the money from the state government; it is the federal government that is the problem. The current federal government has seen fit to declare the Princes Highway East as a road of national importance but has committed only $30 million as its contribution to funding construction of the bypass, with the completion date estimated to be 2005. Although the documentation we have seen from the Howard government says that there will be a $5 million allocation in 2001-02 and $25 million in 2002-03, nothing has been committed beyond that time. This is obviously something which the Howard government needs to start to take a bit of initiative on and interest in, and I call on it to seriously consider funding this project in the budget to be brought down next year.

I point out that, whilst many people in the Howard government have said, `Oh, look, we are providing money for roads because we are putting money into the so-called Roads to Recovery project,' this is nowhere near enough. I note that the Cardinia Shire at the western end of my electorate has received only a very small amount of money from the federal government under the Roads to Recovery Program. It has received in the order of only $3.7 million over the entire length of the program. The Cardinia Shire is not happy with this at all, and it said in an article in the Pakenham Gazette:

quote.para: The $3.7 million earmarked for Cardinia Shire over four years as part of the Federal Government's Roads to Recovery Program is not enough, according to chief executive Don Welsh.
Mr Welsh said the shire had over 1000 kilometres of overloaded local roads and the money would make only a slight impression.

speech.para: It is amazing that the members opposite think that, by putting a little bit of this money into local roads, that will make up for all of their deficiencies. It has not pleased Cardinia Shire. It has done nothing to address the key infrastructure priority for the Gippsland regionâthe building of the Pakenham Bypass. I say to the Howard government: let's get serious about roads; let's get serious about key infrastructure priorities for regions like Gippsland and build the Pakenham Bypass. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âLike rancid pus oozing from a carbuncle waiting to be lanced, so the tales of corruption in the Queensland ALP continue to ooze from the Shepherdson inquiry across the life of Queensland. Today we have seen even more extraordinary scenes come out of that particular inquiry. We have seen the resignation of the ALP candidate for the seat of Thuringowa; we have seen the resignation from the ALP of the member for Springwood today; at the weekend we saw the resignation of the ALP candidate for Redlands; and last week we saw the resignation of the Deputy Premier of Queensland, tied up in this seething corruption that is sweeping the Labor Party throughout Queensland.

speech.para: One of my great disappointments at the weekend was at a press conference yesterday at which the Queensland Premier suggested that the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters of this parliament was undertaking a witch-hunt. I was disappointed in that because, if anything, the Queensland Premierâwho is now displaying himself as the man of virtue, the man who is going to clean up the rubbishâhas said that he has no intention of cooperating with that inquiry. He called for the resignation of the honourable member for Sturt as chairman of that inquiry because, allegedly, he was going to conduct this witch-hunt.

I remind the Queensland Premierâand I remind the Queensland parliament that they are not quite as strict with their committees as this place isâthat if he wants to get up there and propose 8-point plans, if he wants to be the man of virtue, he should be volunteering to come to that committee to tell us just what is wrong with the Electoral Act, because the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters has one purpose in life: to protect the Commonwealth Electoral Act. Its sole inquiry is going to be just how to protect the Electoral Act. It really makes you wonder what the Queensland Premier has to hide.

It was very interesting today that, in the Shepherdson inquiry, the focus moved back to 1986 to a particularly bitter preselection battle between then Labor minister Anne Warner and current Labor MP Mr Jim Fouras. Accusations of stacking in that preselection came out. The stories of Anne Warner going to none other than Mike Kaiser, the state member for Woodridgeâwho also has been adversely drawn into this particular inquiryâresulted in a number of people being taken off the roll for that particular preselection.

It is getting very close indeed to the Queensland Premier who served for so long as state secretary of the Labor Party in Queensland. Does anyone honestly believe that somebody who was state secretary for about six years and deputy leader of the party and Premier for about five years did not know what was going on within the Queensland Labor Party? I think it is timely to remind the House of the very words that the Queensland Premier wrote in his book, In The Arena, about his bid for preselection in the state seat of Redlands in 1985 when he stood against the current member for Bowman. In that book, he admits:

quote.para: Con had the big advantage of being a local boy. He claimed that I would find it difficult to get any support from branch members in the area and that I would be seen as an interloper.

speech.para: So what did Peter Beattie do as the prospective ALP candidate for Redlands? On page 86 of his book, he says:

quote.para: During the preselection campaign I was supported strongly by a lot of loyal and devoted people in Alexandra Hills although my support in other parts of the electorate was less encouraging. I took some time off work for the plebiscite. Doorknocking the area was an interesting experience. One female party member was not at home when I called on her at the vacant allotment where she purportedly lived. To my not particularly great surprise she later voted in the preselection. Another party member was a seaman operating somewhere north of Cairns. I contacted him by radio so that he knew where to send down his postal vote.

speech.para: They are the very words of the Queensland Premier: the man of virtue who is trying to clean up a system that has been rotten and absolutely corrupt.

talk.start.para: âAnd he knew about it.
âThe member for Hindmarsh is not in her seat.

âThe absolute corruption of the Australian Labor Party will continue to be revealed as the Shepherdson inquiry progresses. I wish the member for Sturt and committee members from both houses and all political parties the very best in getting to the bottom of this corruption in Queensland over the coming months so that at least we can have complete and utter integrity regarding the electoral rollâsomething that the Queensland Premier does not seem too keen to bring about. (Time expired)

âThe encroachment of information technology on our lives can be seen everywhere. One has only to look around this chamberânow that it is wiredâto see honourable members using their portable laptop computers and the like. However, one concern about the introduction of information technology is that the Australian community and society could soon become divided between the information rich and the information poor.

speech.para: Those who believe this phenomenon is not developing in Australia should examine a survey produced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics that was released late last month entitled `Use of Internet by Householders'. Let us look at the figures based on income for those who have access to computers and to the Internet at home. In August 2000, 37 per cent of households with an annual income of between zero and under $50,000 had access to computers at home compared with 75 per cent of those households with an income of $50,000 or more. Some 19 per cent of those on an annual income of below $50,000 and 51 per cent of those with an annual income of more than $50,000 had access to the Internet at home. Those figures should concern us because information technology is an important tool in enhancing people's education and retraining opportunities.

Furthermore, one can consider the way in which people access information technology. In its report the ABS studied the use of computers and the Internet by children. Children aged from five to 14 predominantly access computers and the Internet through school. There is of course computer access at home, access at someone else's home and, to a smaller degree, access through public libraries. Before its electoral defeat, the Keating government understood that public libraries played an important role in giving the community wider access to information technology. Under the Creative Australia program, it planned to provide money to all 1,400 public libraries around Australia to ensure that they had Internet access. This program was to cost only $11.4 million but, regrettably, the Howard government saw fit to throw it away.

Fortunately, many agencies throughout the community understand that peopleâfor reasons of income, unemployment and so onâhave difficulty accessing computers and the Internet. Innovative programs have been introduced by community information servicesâthe old CABs. In fact, in my electorate, Community Information Diamond Valley based at Greensborough decided to self-fund an Internet access centre that allows people to come in off the street and access the Internet and personal computers to perform a whole range of tasksâthe unemployed are able to search for jobs, prepare their resumes and the like. I am pleased to note that Community Information Whittlesea made a submission under the federation community grants program to establish what it described as the `federation community computer resource room'. That resource room, which cost $30,000 under the Commonwealth government's Centenary of Federation community grants program, is now in place. It gives people who have no such access at home both personal computer and Internet access and the opportunity to use information technology.

It will be a great challenge for us as a society to ensure that, down the track, the gap revealed by the figures in this ABS study does not widen. People must not be denied access to information technology and the Internet on the basis of their income. They must not be denied such access because they live in rural and regional areasâmany of my colleagues tell me that disparity of access to new technologies is a problem in rural and regional Australia. I hope that governments will treat this matter seriously. It is an important equity issue that, if it develops further, will become an even more pressing problem in this country. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âThe issue of road funding has received some attention in the last week.
âDid you apply the gag?

âThrough you, Mr Speaker: I should explain that I applied the gag because other matters of the House had to proceed. I am quite happy to be speaking on this now, and I thank the member for Hunter for his interjection.

speech.para: The matter of roads, which has received some attention in the last week, is a celebration of great economic management by the Howard-Anderson-Costello government. It is a celebration of the stronger company tax revenue, which has allowed this to occur as much as anything. It is a celebration of the stronger employment, the lower interest rates, the lower taxes, the lower capital gains taxes, the high wages, the record exports, the stronger apprenticeships and the stronger health delivery systemsâto name but a fewâwhich we now have in this country.

I also remind those opposite, in particular, that this injection in this current round over the next four years of $1.2 billion, this 75 per cent increase on the current Commonwealth contribution to local roads, as I say, is a tribute to that management of the last 4Â½ years that has allowed this to occurâthat Charter of Budget Honesty that we so much needed in this country, when we recall the deficit financing and the Commonwealth debt that had been run up in the previous period of the alternative government. I should say also that the rural and regional parts of Australia will receive $850 million of the $1.2 billion. There is, of course, a $400 million fund that can be allocated in a priority manner on outer metropolitan and other roads as time passes. But certainly the lion's share of this $1.2 billion is going to rural and regional Australia.

I just focus briefly on the South Australian experience. It is conceded that South Australia had suffered some disadvantage on the historic basis of allocation of local roads funding from the Commonwealth. That does not excuse state governments and local governments for focusing on this issue as well because it is very limited. In fact, it is understood that Tasmania and South Australia do not contribute any money at all to local roads from their own budgets. I am happy to listen to the states on that to see whether that is indeed the case. But certainly that is the belief within the Commonwealth and from the evidence that is provided to the Commonwealth: that South Australia and Tasmania do not provide money for local roads in those states.

So this funding is particularly welcome in South Australia, where we have received a 112 per cent increase. That is a recognition by the Howard governmentâby the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister and those people in the cabinetâI believe, that there was an issue about fairness for South Australia which they were prepared to recognise and not wait for some long inquiry to try and reach some agreement with the ALGA. They were prepared to allocate the money and just get on with it. For their foresight and their capacity to give proper balance to this matter, I thank the executive. In conclusion, can I say that in response to the regional summit so ably led by the Deputy Prime Minister last year, as a former local government elected member I am particularly delighted to see this great input of revenue or expenditure on this much needed infrastructure that is so important to the local government areas of this nation.

subdebateinfo.title: Stirling Electorate: Commonwealth Recognition Awards for Senior Australians

talk.start.para: âI am very pleased to be able to stand here tonight and bring to the attention of the House the eight people who have been nominated in the Stirling electorate for the Commonwealth Recognition Awards for Senior Australians. Mr Speaker, as you would be aware, these awards were created last year in the International Year of the Older Person. This year they were continued, so that the work of acknowledging the important contribution of senior Australians that is undertaken in the community could again be recognised. I would like to talk a little bit about the eight people who have been nominated in the Stirling electorate for these awardsâand I am very pleased to be able to say that, before Christmas, they will be presented with their medal and with their certificate.

speech.para: The first person I would like to talk about is Mr Reginald Devenish of Innaloo. Mr Devenish has contributed for many years to the wellbeing of people in the neighbourhood by helping them with community transport, assisting with many repairs around the houseâeverything from mowing lawns and fixing small broken itemsâand providing support when people are ill and need that little extra bit of assistance.

The second person is Mrs Margaret Erickson of Karrinyup, who again has contributed to the community through many, many years of involvement in local community groupsâin particular, her involvement in the Scarborough and District Progress Association as well as in the Scarborough High School Open Space Action Group. They are just two of the many, many organisations of which she has been a member and through which she has provided support not only to older people in the community but also to younger people and families through her community activities.

I would like to also acknowledge Mrs Mary Haddow of Innaloo, who is a very active member of the community; she has not given her age, but she is well and truly a senior. Mary has done much wonderful work. She has been involved again with the founding of many organisationsâwith the P&C when her children were going through school, on local Home and Community Care Program committees and with the Innaloo Combined Pensioners Association as well as the Innaloo Autumn Club activities.

Mrs Lisette Nigot of Trigg has contributed greatly, particularly as a member of Friends of Trigg Bushland to the preservation and conservation of a last remnant bit of native bushland in the Stirling electorate. She was also part of the group that fought to save the bushland and keep it for future generations. Lisette is also involved with the Northern Suburbs Historical Society and a number of other organisations in the neighbourhood with a particular focus on heritage, conservation and recording the history of the local areaâagain, for the benefit of those who preceded her and for future generations.

Another wonderful lady who needs special mention is Mrs Bruna Piotta, who has been a long-term member of the Italian Senior Citizens Association WA. She has contributed many hours of volunteer work and much of her time and effort to Italian senior citizens. With her children growing up, she has also contributed at an extremely significant level with various other groups in the neighbourhood.

The eighth person is Mr Vic Radis of Balcatta. Mr Radis is a member of the Macedonian community. He migrated out here after World War II. He has been active in the community and instrumental in founding many Macedonian organisations in my electorate, including Ilinden, the cultural centre, the Macedonian soccer club, the Macedonian United Society and St Nikola Macedonian Orthodox church. As well, he has become quite famous for inventing a valve that goes on a prosthesis that has been most helpful for people with disabilities.

I would like to quickly mention two people who were on the committee and helped to oversight the process. They are Bert Verrier, who was the winner last year, and Margaret Clements, who is a senior herself and has contributed to the community in many ways on many committees.
These are wonderful people. I think they need to be acknowledged and I thank you, Mr Speaker, for my having the chance to bring their names before this place.

talk.start.para: âTonight I wish to bring to the attention of members, and the parliament generally, the fantastically successful Relay for Life event held in the Deakin electorate over the weekend of 18 and 19 November. The Bill Sewart athletics track in Burwood East was the venue for the latest fundraising activity of the Anti-Cancer Council of Victoria, the ACCV.

speech.para: Regrettably, few Australians can say that they have never been touched by cancer. It is a frightening fact that one in three Australians will experience cancer or its effects at some stage of their lives. I think it is fair to say that we all know someone who has been affected by one form of cancer or another. It may be something as simple as skin cancer that thankfully does not become life threatening, or a more major form that spreads throughout the body. Unfortunately, different people have different experiences. For some the cancer takes over virtually overnight with no advance warning. For others, the spread is slow and excruciatingly painful. In my own family, my father-in-law, Bernie Green, lived a good life, much loved by all his friends and family. That the disease ultimately took his life so soon after I entered the family was a major tragic loss not only for the family but also for me as a new son-in-law.

The Relay for Life was an opportunity to remember those that suffered or died as a consequence of this disease. Over a 24-hour period commencing at 12 p.m. on Saturday, over 1,500 people from 54 teams participated with great enthusiasm, endeavour and commitment to raise money for the fight against cancer. As people did their bit by walking or running, a host of musicians and bands played live music and generally entertained all those present. The middle of the track was filled with the tents of the various teams, where seemingly hundreds slept and rested overnight. In a positive sign, there were young people everywhereâas organisers, entertainers, walkers and runners. From my observations, they were having a great time whilst contributing to a great cause and remembering people that had been afflicted by cancer.

The event had the support of many, particularly the Rotary Club of Box Hill Central. It was their members' drive and commitment that made the event the success that it was. A number of well-known public figures lent their support, as did Australian sporting identities. At times, there were hundreds of people walking and running around the track. Being Melbourne, the weather was perfect, although the humidity levels experienced were higher than usual. An important component of the weekend was when the survivors of cancer were acknowledged, along with the carers of cancer sufferers. Those who had, sadly, passed away were remembered in a fitting tribute, with individually inscribed bags placed around the edge of the track.

The Anti-Cancer Council of Victoria, one of a number of state and territory based organisations, and the Australian Cancer Society do a great job, raising awareness and providing funds for research. Relay for Life events are being held regularly all over Australia. On the same weekend, events were held in Frankston, in the electorate of DunkleyâDunkley by the bay, as my colleague keeps reminding meâalong with other locations in New South Wales and the ACT.

Relay for Life began in America in 1985. Since then, it has developed into the world's biggest fundraising event. The East Burwood event has as of today raised just over $100,000. I am glad to report that the ACCV continues to receive donations on a daily basis. The funds that were raised on the day go to various programs, including population studies through the Centre for Behavioural Research in Cancer. Some $7.5 million was allocated to cancer research, making the council the largest non-government provider of research funds for cancer in the state. Other education and prevention programs were also funded.

I wish to place on record my appreciation and thanks to those who participated in Team Barresi. There were around 50 people actively involved and many that made a donation. I would particularly like to thank Midge Coll from my office for her hard work in helping make the weekend a success, and Ian Pritchard, a local Brumby's baker and business owner, along with his staff and their friends, for enlisting a large group of walkers. Also I want to acknowledge Yarra Valley Water for their kind donation of 500 bottles of drinking water. Team Barresi walkers were Maree Luckins, Bruce Atkinson, Ron Wilson, Edmund Carew, Vasan, Peter Goujon, Catherine Rees, Lauren Zelunka, Amanda Dinsdale, Vivienne, Paul, Carla and Davidâthe little three-year-oldâBarresi, Ros and Malcolm Clowes, Heidi Mitterlehner, Jeff Victoria, Charles Hogarth, Chris Tann, Tim and Benjamin Neve, Loretta Gibson, Midge and Chaz Coll, Allan Dunn, John Atkinson, Bev and Jack Bailey, Andrew Munroe and Andrew Rawlings. Mr Speaker, I would particularly like to acknowledge those who donated the $2,335 that was raised for Team Barresi, including the Speaker of the Parliament of Australia and many of my colleagues on this side of the House. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âA couple of weeks ago I was contacted by a couple of recreational fishermen known to meâa couple of fellows that like to take their boat, go outside the heads at Port Stephens, dangle a line and catch a fish. They contacted me because in fishing for live bait in the traditional bait grounds off Port Stephens they experienced something they had never experienced before: a number of large boats were there purse seining for the slimy mackerel that have traditionally been used as live bait by these fishermen. They took time to contact me and to ask, `Why have we suddenly been invaded by very large boats'âI am talking about boats 70 feet longâ`which are overfishing our bait grounds and taking all our live bait?' I made a few inquiries and it was not long before I had charter boat operators and dolphin cruise operators all coming back to me with the same story: there is not a slimy mackerel to be had, and small yellowtail are being taken by the tonne for live bait for the long-line tuna fishing boats that are currently in Port Stephens. I believe there were seven at the weekend. We have one home boat that operates out of that port. There are currently seven boats there and they are catching tonnes. They berley when the school comes in, around goes the net and they take every fish.

speech.para: The tragedy is multifaceted, because Port Stephens is home to the biggest game fishing competition in the world, and next month people will come from all over the world to game fish off Port Stephens. They will be after live bait. They will be out there to catch marlin. If the marlin is not of a size that warrants going into the record books, it will be tagged and released. The reason long-liners are using live bait is that, unfortunately, the tuna are now an endangered species. They are in such small numbers that no longer can you catch them simply by using a piece of fish bait; you have to put a live bait on to entice the tuna to take it. Normally, if you use a piece of fish, a marlin will not go for it. The by-catch of long-liners today includes many marlin being caught. They cannot be brought into the market, but if they are on the line all night, by the time the line is brought in in the morning, they are dead. They are simply thrown overboard, discarded. There is extreme concern as to whether in the game fishing competition to be held early next year any marlin will be caught at all and what the situation will be. Only time will tell, of course.

But further inquiry has shown that these long-line boats are there as a result of federal intervention. Because of the closure of the cannery at Eden, a licence has been given by the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, the Hon. Wilson Tuckey, to allow slimy mackerel to be caught in Australia. The trigger catch was 5,000 tonnes. It has now been reduced to 2,500 tonnes, but that is only a trigger catch, and once that trigger is caught an inquiry is supposed to be triggered. Who is the inquiry going to be done by? It will be done by AFMA, which is the professional arm of the fishing industry. It is a bit like asking Dracula to check the supply of blood. We know what they are going to say: they are going to say that in this Commonwealth fishery that has been identified by the minister everything is okay. No-one knows the sustainable limit that can be caught and that will allow this fish to survive. I believe that the slimy mackerel in Australia is the last known fishery anywhere in the world of these fish in any quantity. They are being fished out. I urge the minister to hurry up and get on with the inquiry while we still have some of these in our coastal waters, because if it is allowed to go on and these fish continue to be caught in the quantities they currently are there will be none left. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to welcome the mayors of local councils in the catchment of the Scoresby transport corridor who have wandered up to Canberra for the ALGA annual conference. I am not sure what you call a collection of mayors: let us call them a community bus load of mayors. They have come up to the capital to participate in that conference. As part of their program, I with the support of my friend and colleague the member for Deakin and my friend and colleague the member for Aston have organised a meeting between the mayors and the federal Minister for Transport and Regional Services. The issue at hand is the Scoresby transport corridor and our undying efforts to see that supported by Victorian and Commonwealth governments. Members might be aware that that has been going on for nearly four years now, and we are slowly starting to make progress. Our progress, though, is being hindered greatly by the inactivity and the blatant misrepresentations of the Bracks government in Victoria and in particular Minister Batchelor. The Bracks government and Minister Batchelor parade around Victorian media claiming that they have made a substantive submission to the federal government seeking almost half a billion dollars worth of funding. What they have done is to have sent up a glossy brochure which basically summarises all major road projects in Victoria, and there are four paragraphs relating to the Scoresby transport corridor. Four paragraphs! My three-year-old son I think would work harder trying to get a sleepover at home than four paragraphs. But that is all the Bracks government have managed to offer as justification for almost half a billion dollars worth of funding.

speech.para: We have been making this point through the media, and nameless spokespersons on behalf of Minister Batchelor and others have been saying of course they have made a submission. We have found out, though, that at last Minister Batchelor has written to Minister Anderson a letter dated 28 November indicating for the first time that the Scoresby transport corridor is a top priority for Victoria and seeking to commence some dialogue. At last we are getting somewhere. Minister Anderson will meet with the mayors tomorrow, and we can share with the local government mayors what action needs to be taken in Victoria if we are to have any prospect of securing road of national importance funding for this project.

talker.name: Reith, Peter, MP
Mr Reith

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) to (5) The Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has an extensive and complex online presence which provides a variety of services to the public. All of these services could be classed as transactions of a sort but some are rather different to the classical definition. For example, these transactions vary from the availability of information/advices, electronic publications and static information, through to the functionality that exists on the Australian JobSearch site allowing users to search for a vacant position online, and the services the department provides for registering and searching for an ABN on behalf of the Australian Taxation Office.

The number of these transactions is difficult to quantify and forecasts don't exist. Indeed the type of online transactions are difficult to quantify and not comparable. While statistics exist for the usage of a particular website, these are based on the number of pages viewed by an individual visiting the site.

I refer you to my department's recently completed Online Action Plan: http://www.dewrsb.gov.au/department/keyCorporateDocuments/onlineActionPlan/default.asp. The Online Action Plan outlines our achievements and future directions in online service delivery. It contains details of all the services currently offered via our websites and extranets, and how these will be enhanced. The Action Plan has identified that over 90% of the department's information is now available online.
The table below sets out the websites operated by the department:

These services have been well-received by the public. Our achievements include over 500,000 Australian Business Number (ABN) registrations received via the Business Entry Point website - over 15 per cent of the total registrations - and over 100 million page views on the Australian JobSearch website during 1999-2000. Page views for all departmental websites total in excess of 135 million for the same period.

Alternatives to online service delivery are provided where required. For example, the Australian JobSearch site lists vacant positions, but these are also available through Job Network member offices. Similarly, registration for an ABN is available via the Internet, but it is also available directly from the Australian Taxation Office or from accountants via their electronic lodgement systems.

The total cost of administering the services provided in this environment has not at this stage been fully assessed, however there have been significant savings achieved by the Commonwealth in bringing services online. For example, with the introduction of the Australian JobSearch system (both web and touchscreen units) there has been greater public access to jobs, with over 50,000 jobs online and over 500,000 actual searches performed per day. The overall costs involved have also decreased even though the number of physical sites has increased from 500 (under the Commonwealth Employment Service) to over 2100 (Job Network). These savings would not have been possible without the use of online delivery.
Given the nature of their services, some of the department's portfolio agencies have been able to provide more specific answers. These are set out below.

quote.para: Notes:
The costs set out above:
are only those incurred by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (DIMA) directly in providing immigration services and processing at airports, broken down on a regional basis.
encompass salary costs, general administrative expenditure and estimates of related state/territory corporate support costs.
do not include costs such as central office and legal support, visa systems and other related expenditure.

do not equate to the costings used in the past in determining the amount of the Passenger Movement Charge - specifically, they do not factor in the costs of short stay visitor visas which are not part of the immigration services or processing which takes place at airports.
The Australian Customs Service (ACS) also conducts immigration processing on behalf of DIMA. Those costs are incurred by ACS and are not included in the figures set out above.

All states except Queensland and Western Australia have only one international airport and therefore the figures set out above relate to the airport in that state. Queensland's costs include airports Brisbane, Cairns, Coolangatta and Townsville, at which immigration services were provided for all or part of the period covered by the question. Western Australia's costs include airports in Perth and Broome, at which immigration services were provided for all or part of the period covered by the question.

entry.para: Overall costs for 1995/96 are estimates - costs specific to airports are not accessible for this period.
Costs for administrative expenditure from 1995/96 to 1997/98 are estimates because compliance and airport operations were combined in this period and no airport specific figures have been retained.
Because flights are infrequent, ACT does not have resources dedicated directly to airport operations. Costs are estimates based on a nominal allocation of resources to the task of airport operations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 October 2000:

quote.para: If, as stated, the ASM with clasp Vietnam 1975 is only cancelled once eligibility for the AASM has been established, why has the Director Honours and Awards, Air Force Medals Section, Defence Personnel Executive, advised recipients that the ASM with clasp Vietnam 1975 is no longer recognised under the Australian Honours System and must therefore be cancelled.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: On 18 August 1998, the Governor-General revoked the Instrument of Declaration and determination for the ASM with Clasp `Vietnam 1975' and approved a similar Instrument which established the AASM with Clasp `Vietnam 1975'. This was as a result of a Defence Review which changed the service in Vietnam at the time from non-warlike to warlike. As the AASM and the ASM recognise warlike and non-warlike service, respectively, they cannot both be awarded for the same operation. As the Instrument for the ASM with Clasp `Vietnam 1975' has been revoked, it is no longer a valid award. It should be pointed out that this change was effected following representations from those veterans claiming that their service should have been recognised by the AASM, not the ASM.

To receive the AASM with Clasp `Vietnam 1975', recipients of the ASM with Clasp `Vietnam 1975' are required to surrender their award when applying for the new award. The ASM with Clasp `Vietnam 1975' is then individually cancelled once entitlement to the AASM with Clasp `Vietnam 1975' is established.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) Does he regard the current practice of providing Australian troops serving in East Timor with one free telephone call to Australia each week of 5 - 10 minutes as adequate.

(2) Has he, his Department or the ADF received complaints from Australian troops in East Timor about the adequacy of this service in terms of the ability of these troops to maintain contact with families and loved ones back in Australia.

(3)What are the current charging rates for calls from East Timor to Australia on commercial mobile phones provided by OPTUS and Telstra that are available to Australian troops and are these rates comparable to other international mobile rates over similar distances.
(4) Does he intend to take any action to encourage OPTUS and Telstra to provide more affordable charging rates for soldiers in East Timor.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes.
(3) Both Telstra and OPTUS have satellite pay phone facilities in East Timor for the use of Australian troops. Only Telstra operates a mobile telephone (GSM) network.
(a) Calls made on Telstra pay phones are charged at $1.00 per minute.
(b) Calls made on OPTUS pay phones are charged at $1.20 per minute.

(c) With respect to Telstra mobile telephone calls, East Timor is treated as a part of Australia for billing purposes. The call costs will vary depending on the individual plan that soldiers have selected and the location that is called. Indicative estimates are between $0.30 to $1.20 per minute. These rates are excellent in comparison to international roaming rates which would otherwise apply, which vary between $5.50 and $6.50 per minute.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 30 October 2000:

quote.para: In correspondence to one of my constituents, Mrs M Goodenough, did his Senior Adviser estimate the cost of reinstating War Widow's pensions to widows who remarried prior to 1984 at $65 million over four years; if so, on what basis was this figure calculated.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: My Senior Adviser advised Mrs Goodenough by letter dated 28 August 1998 that the cost of recommencing payment of a war widow's pension to widows who had remarried prior to 1984, and thus relinquished their pensions, would be $65 million for the first four years.

This estimate was calculated on the basis that there were some 4,500 former war widows alive on 28 May 1984. The average age of war widows on 28 May 1984 was approximately 64 years of age. By applying the average mortality rates drawn from the Australian Life Tables 1990-92, the number of surviving widows in 1997 was estimated to be about 4,100 with an average age of 77 years.

The estimate of $65 million over a four year period was based on providing war widow's pensions to these 4,100 former widows. The calculation took into account that most of the widows would already be in receipt of age pension and Pensioner Concession Cards. The average value of these benefits was deducted from the costs of providing war widow's benefits.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 31 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) Is he able to say whether the Chinese Government recently agreed to pay US$13m to Papua New Guinea and sent a military delegation there in July?
(2) Is he able to say whether the Chinese Government has a military training regime with Tonga?
(3) Is he able to say whether the Chinese Government has a missile tracking station in Kiribati?
(4) Is he also able to say whether the Solomon Islands is on the verge of terminating its relationship with Taiwan and that its Foreign Minister was recently in Beijing?

talker.name: Downer, Alexander, MP
Mr Downer
talker.role: Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) A delegation from the People's Liberation Army (PLA) visited Papua New Guinea (PNG) in early July 2000. Following the visit it was announced that the PLA would provide logistic aid to the PNG Defence Force. This was to include the provision of basic stores and non-lethal equipment. The value of the Chinese logistic assistance is in the order of $3 million.

(2) The Tongan Government announced this year that a Memorandum of Close Cooperation had been concluded in July between the Tongan Defence Service and the PRC's People's Liberation Army. Tonga will receive military clothing, gym equipment, training, and the services of an expert in martial arts instruction.

(3) Press reports announced the opening of the China Space Tracking, Telemetry and Command Station in Kiribati on 6 October 1997, which will be operated by the Chinese Government as part of its monitoring and control network for supporting satellite and carrier rocket launchings.
(4)The Solomon Islands Government has announced it will maintain its relationship with Taiwan. The Solomon Islands Foreign Minister recently visited Hong Kong SAR, not Beijing.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) How many Australian service personnel contracted dengue fever while serving in East Timor.
(2) Were Australian troops provided with appropriate preventitive medication for dengue fever.
(3) If so, was this medication provided prior to arrival in east Timor; if not, how many personnel were not provided with medication until after their first day of service in East Timor.
(4) If medication was not provided, why not.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) As of 1 November 2000 there has been a total of 227 known clinical cases of dengue fever.
(3) Not applicable.
(4) There is no preventive medication effective against dengue.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 6 November 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has there been communication between the government and the WA Government over the possibility of part of the Pyrton site at Eden Hill in Perth being used as a detention centre for illegal immigrants.
(2) Has there been communication between the Government and the WA Government about the use of that site, other than as a women's prison.
(3) Does he have, or is he considering, proposals for the site, other than as a women's prison.

talker.name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
Mr Ruddock
talker.role: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Reconciliation

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) to (3) There are no plans to develop an Immigration Detention Centre at Pyrton or to locate such a facility within a Western Australian State Prison or rehabilitation centre.

The Commonwealth Government has Immigration Reception and Processing Centres for unauthorised boat arrivals at Port Hedland and the RAAF Base at Curtin. The Government also has a small immigration detention centre located at Perth Airport. The only plans for the construction of a new immigration detention centre are for a larger centre at Perth Airport in a few years time.
